question_results.question:
COEs (confirmation of enrolments) are created through:

Answer options:
PRISMS
The local Australian Embassy/Consulate- General.
CRICOS
AEI
correct_answers: PRISMS
extracted_answers: PRISMS
question_results.full_response:
## Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE) Creation: A Detailed Report on PRISMS

### Introduction
The international education sector in Australia is heavily regulated to ensure quality and protect the interests of overseas students. A critical component of this regulatory framework is the Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE), a document that serves as a cornerstone for international students seeking to study in Australia on a student visa. This report aims to provide a comprehensive analysis of the system through which CoEs are created, focusing on the Provider Registration and International Student Management System (PRISMS). By examining the role of PRISMS, this report will clarify the process of CoE creation and its significance within the broader context of Australian international education.

### The Role of PRISMS in CoE Creation
Based on the information provided, the correct answer to the query "COEs (confirmation of enrolments) are created through:" is **PRISMS**. PRISMS is the central system used by Australian education providers to manage and monitor international student data, including the creation, updating, and cancellation of CoEs ([Meshed Group, 2024](https://meshedgroup.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/HigherEdResources/pages/2489057891/PRISMS+Provider+Registration+and+International+Student+Management+System)).

PRISMS, which stands for Provider Registration and International Student Management System, is a web-based database used to produce and track Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE) documents for international students studying in Australia on a student visa ([ICEF, n.d.a](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b6-prisms/)). These CoEs are essential for the issuing of student visas. The system also contains the Commonwealth Register of Institutions and Courses for Overseas Students (CRICOS), which records all registered courses for each provider registered to provide education to overseas students studying in Australia on a student visa ([ICEF, n.d.a](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b6-prisms/)).

PRISMS is a secure website that requires a login identifier and password, unlike CRICOS, which is a publicly accessible database ([ICEF, n.d.b](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-1-access-to-prisms/)). While PRISMS is primarily used by education providers, a provider may authorize its agents to create CoEs ([ICEF, n.d.b](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-1-access-to-prisms/)). The Principal Executive Officer (PEO) or an authorized delegate of the provider can grant an agent access to PRISMS for the provider’s courses, allowing the agent to create a CoE or advise on course information ([ICEF, n.d.b](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-1-access-to-prisms/)). If an agent creates a CoE, they can enter the relevant information, but a member of the provider’s staff must authorize it ([ICEF, n.d.b](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-1-access-to-prisms/)).

### Detailed Explanation of PRISMS
PRISMS is managed by the Australian Department of Education and is an essential tool for managing and monitoring international student data in Australia ([Meshed Group, 2024](https://meshedgroup.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/HigherEdResources/pages/2489057891/PRISMS+Provider+Registration+and+International+Student+Management+System)). It enables education providers to comply with the requirements of the Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Act. The system allows for the electronic issuance of Confirmation of Enrolments (CoEs), which are crucial for student visa applications, and helps track the enrolment status and course progress of international students ([Meshed Group, 2024](https://meshedgroup.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/HigherEdResources/pages/2489057891/PRISMS+Provider+Registration+and+International+Student+Management+System)). By ensuring accurate and up-to-date reporting, PRISMS plays a critical role in maintaining the integrity of Australia’s international education sector, supporting compliance, and enhancing the overall experience for international students ([Meshed Group, 2024](https://meshedgroup.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/HigherEdResources/pages/2489057891/PRISMS+Provider+Registration+and+International+Student+Management+System)).

#### Access and Security
PRISMS is a secure web site and requires a login identifier and password ([ICEF, n.d.b](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-1-access-to-prisms/)). This differs from CRICOS, which is a publicly accessible database. PRISMS is used by education providers more than agents. However, a provider may give its agent(s) the authority to create CoEs ([ICEF, n.d.b](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-1-access-to-prisms/)). The Principal Executive Officer (PEO) or an authorized delegate of the provider can allow an agent to access PRISMS for that provider’s courses. The agent can then create a CoE or advise on course information ([ICEF, n.d.b](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-1-access-to-prisms/)). If the agent creates a CoE, they can enter relevant information into the CoE form, but a member of the provider’s staff will then authorize the CoE ([ICEF, n.d.b](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-1-access-to-prisms/)).

#### The Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE)
A CoE is a Confirmation of Enrolment. This is a web-based document created by PRISMS that records which course or courses a student is enrolled in ([ICEF, n.d.c](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-2-what-is-a-coe/)). If a student intends to study more than one course, more than one CoE is produced. This allows the student to get a student visa for the combined length of all the courses, often referred to as a ‘Package’ visa ([ICEF, n.d.c](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-2-what-is-a-coe/)).

The steps followed in producing a CoE are:
1.  The provider agrees to enrol the student ([ICEF, n.d.c](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-2-what-is-a-coe/)).
2.  The provider authorises and prints a copy of the CoE and provides it to the student and/or agent ([ICEF, n.d.c](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-2-what-is-a-coe/)).
3.  The information on the CoE is transmitted to DHA via PRISMS ([ICEF, n.d.c](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-2-what-is-a-coe/)).
4.  When the student applies for a student visa, DHA matches and approves the CoE details ([ICEF, n.d.c](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-2-what-is-a-coe/)).

#### CoE Contents
A CoE has four parts, including:
*   **Part A** – Information for overseas students: where to apply for the student visa ([ICEF, n.d.d](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-3-what-does-a-coe-look-like/)).
*   **Part B** – Course details: such as CRICOS code of the provider and the course, course start and finish date or course fee ([ICEF, n.d.d](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-3-what-does-a-coe-look-like/)).
*   **Part C** – Student details ([ICEF, n.d.d](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-3-what-does-a-coe-look-like/)).
*   **Part D** – Notes: relating the CoE ([ICEF, n.d.d](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-3-what-does-a-coe-look-like/)).

#### Reporting Students Using PRISMS
Education agent counsellors are not permitted to create a Student Course Variation (SCV), so this section is for information only ([ICEF, n.d.e](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms/)). Students are not reported if they follow the same pathway that they originally intended, and the details on their eCoE do not need to be changed in any way ([ICEF, n.d.e](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms/)). If any changes are necessary, the institution uses PRISMS to produce a Student Course Variation (SCV) ([ICEF, n.d.e](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms/)).

Generally, the following events require an educational provider to use PRISMS to report to the student to DHA:
*   The student does not begin the course ([ICEF, n.d.e](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms/)).
*   The student finishes the course before the date on the CoE ([ICEF, n.d.e](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms/)).
*   The student leaves the provider ([ICEF, n.d.e](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms/)).

In these cases, the provider would report on the student using the appropriate SCV code and create new CoEs as required ([ICEF, n.d.e](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms/)). Depending on the circumstances, the student may or may not need to be directly involved. Students wishing to change providers do not need to approach DIPB unless they are changing the sector of the principal course of study ([ICEF, n.d.e](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms/)).

There are two reasons why an educational provider uses PRISMS to report students to DHA for non-compliance:
*   Non-attendance in classes ([ICEF, n.d.e](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms/)).
*   Unsatisfactory academic performance ([ICEF, n.d.e](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms/)).

For these two reasons, the student is breaching the conditions of their student visa, so during the reporting process, PRISMS generates a formal letter that is sent to the student, asking them to explain their circumstances to DHA ([ICEF, n.d.e](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms/)).

### The Significance of CoE in the Student Visa Application Process
The CoE is a mandatory document for international students applying for an Australian student visa ([SWEC Visa, n.d.a](https://swecvisaconsultant.com/how-to-get-a-confirmation-of-enrolment-coe-for-an-australian-student-visa/)). It confirms that the student has been accepted into a CRICOS-registered course and that the educational institution meets the Australian government's standards for quality education and support services for international students ([SWEC Visa, n.d.a](https://swecvisaconsultant.com/how-to-get-a-confirmation-of-enrolment-coe-for-an-australian-student-visa/)).

#### Key Steps in Obtaining a CoE
1.  **Choose a Course and Institution**: Research and select a CRICOS-registered course and institution ([SWEC Visa, n.d.b](https://swecvisaconsultant.com/how-to-get-a-confirmation-of-enrolment-coe-for-an-australian-student-visa/)).
2.  **Apply to the Institution**: Complete the application process, either online or offline ([SWEC Visa, n.d.b](https://swecvisaconsultant.com/how-to-get-a-confirmation-of-enrolment-coe-for-an-australian-student-visa/)).
3.  **Receive the Offer Letter**: If the application is successful, the institution will issue an offer letter ([The Migration, n.d.](https://themigration.com.au/blog/how-to-apply-for-confirmation-of-enrollment-coe-in-australia/)).
4.  **Accept the Offer and Pay Tuition Fees**: Accept the offer letter and pay the required tuition fees ([MTI, n.d.](https://www.mti.vic.edu.au/international-students/)).
5.  **Receive the CoE**: Once all conditions are met and fees are paid, the institution will issue the CoE ([MTI, n.d.](https://www.mti.vic.edu.au/international-students/)).

#### Eligibility Criteria for CoE
To obtain a CoE, students must meet several eligibility criteria, including:
*   Having a valid passport ([SWEC Visa, n.d.a](https://swecvisaconsultant.com/how-to-get-a-confirmation-of-enrolment-coe-for-an-australian-student-visa/)).
*   Meeting the academic requirements of the course ([SWEC Visa, n.d.a](https://swecvisaconsultant.com/how-to-get-a-confirmation-of-enrolment-coe-for-an-australian-student-visa/)).
*   Satisfying any specific entry requirements set by the educational institution ([SWEC Visa, n.d.a](https://swecvisaconsultant.com/how-to-get-a-confirmation-of-enrolment-coe-for-an-australian-student-visa/)).
*   Demonstrating a genuine intention to study in Australia, assessed through the Genuine Temporary Entrant (GTE) requirement ([SWEC Visa, n.d.a](https://swecvisaconsultant.com/how-to-get-a-confirmation-of-enrolment-coe-for-an-australian-student-visa/)).
*   Providing evidence of sufficient funds to cover tuition fees, living expenses, and other associated costs ([SWEC Visa, n.d.a](https://swecvisaconsultant.com/how-to-get-a-confirmation-of-enrolment-coe-for-an-australian-student-visa/)).
*   Obtaining Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC) ([SWEC Visa, n.d.a](https://swecvisaconsultant.com/how-to-get-a-confirmation-of-enrolment-coe-for-an-australian-student-visa/)).

### CRICOS and its Relationship with PRISMS
The Commonwealth Register of Institutions and Courses for Overseas Students (CRICOS) is an online register of all the courses and institutions that are available to students who wish to obtain a student visa ([ICEF, n.d.f](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b5-cricos/)). Institutions offering education or training services to students studying in Australia on student visas are required to comply with the Federal legislative requirements for registration on CRICOS ([ICEF, n.d.f](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b5-cricos/)).

Each institution is given a unique CRICOS Provider Code on registration. This code identifies the institution as a registered provider of education and training services to overseas students ([ICEF, n.d.g](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b5-1-cricos-provider-code/)). Providers are required by law to include their provider code in all marketing material ([ICEF, n.d.g](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b5-1-cricos-provider-code/)).

CRICOS is also contained within the PRISMS database ([ICEF, n.d.a](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b6-prisms/)). CRICOS records all of the registered courses for each provider that is registered to provide education to an overseas student studying in Australia on a student visa ([ICEF, n.d.a](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b6-prisms/)).

### Consequences of CoE Cancellation
The cancellation of a CoE can have significant implications for international students. If a CoE expires, it becomes invalid for visa purposes, and the student must contact their educational institution to obtain a new CoE ([SWEC Visa, n.d.a](https://swecvisaconsultant.com/how-to-get-a-confirmation-of-enrolment-coe-for

question_results.question:
Legislation and regulations in Australia relating to the enrolment of international students are:

Answer options:
The ESOS Act 2000 and The National Code of Practice 2018
The National Code of practice on student developments within Australia and The Australia Act 1986
The ESOS Act 2000 and The Migration Act 1958
The Migration Act 1958 and The Australia Act 1901
correct_answers: The ESOS Act 2000 and The National Code of Practice 2018
extracted_answers: The ESOS Act 2000 and The National Code of Practice 2018
question_results.full_response:
## Legislation and Regulations in Australia Relating to the Enrolment of International Students: A Detailed Report

The Australian international education sector is governed by a comprehensive legislative framework designed to protect the interests of overseas students, ensure the quality of education and training, and safeguard Australia's reputation as a leading education provider. Among the options provided, the most accurate answer is **The ESOS Act 2000 and The National Code of Practice 2018**. This report will delve into the specifics of these two critical pieces of legislation, highlighting their roles, objectives, and significance in regulating the enrolment and treatment of international students in Australia.

### The Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Act 2000

The Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Act 2000 is the primary legislation governing the provision of education and training to overseas students in Australia who are studying on a student visa ([b2-1-the-esos-act.md](b2-1-the-esos-act.md); [b3-the-esos-act.md](b3-the-esos-act.md); [Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Act](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/ESOS-Act/Pages/default.aspx)). It establishes a framework to ensure that international students receive the education they have paid for and are supported throughout their studies. The ESOS Act regulates various aspects of international education, including the registration process for providers, their obligations, the Tuition Protection Service (TPS), and enforcement and compliance powers ([b2-1-the-esos-act.md](b2-1-the-esos-act.md)).

#### Objectives of the ESOS Act

The ESOS Act has three main objectives:

1.  **Financial and Tuition Assurance:** To provide financial and tuition assurance to overseas students for courses they have paid for. This ensures that students receive the tuition they have paid for, and if an educational institution closes, students are provided with alternative tuition or a refund ([b2-1-the-esos-act.md](b2-1-the-esos-act.md); [b3-2-protection-for-international-students.md](b3-2-protection-for-international-students.md)).

2.  **Protecting and Enhancing Australia's Reputation:** To protect and enhance Australia’s reputation for quality education and training services. This involves ensuring that the education and training of overseas students meets national standards, student welfare services meet national standards, and education providers act ethically and with integrity ([b2-1-the-esos-act.md](b2-1-the-esos-act.md)).

3.  **Complementing Migration Laws:** To complement Australia’s migration laws by ensuring providers collect and report information relevant to the administration of laws relating to student visas. This ensures that education institutions do not allow or encourage students to breach their student visa conditions ([b2-1-the-esos-act.md](b2-1-the-esos-act.md)).

#### Key Provisions of the ESOS Act

*   **Registration of Providers:** The ESOS Act mandates that all institutions offering courses to international students must be registered on the Commonwealth Register of Institutions and Courses for Overseas Students (CRICOS) ([ESOS Act | Tertiary Education Quality and Standards Agency](https://www.teqsa.gov.au/how-we-regulate/acts-and-standards/esos-act); [Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) legislative framework | UniSC | University of the Sunshine Coast, Queensland, Australia](https://www.usc.edu.au/about/careers-at-unisc/staff/education-services-for-overseas-students-esos-legislative-framework)). CRICOS registration ensures that institutions meet specific standards for quality and student support.

*   **Tuition Protection Service (TPS):** The ESOS Act established the TPS to assist international students if their education provider is unable to deliver a course of study. The TPS ensures that students are either placed in an alternative course or receive a refund of their unspent tuition fees ([b2-1-the-esos-act.md](b2-1-the-esos-act.md); [ESOS Act | Tertiary Education Quality and Standards Agency](https://www.teqsa.gov.au/how-we-regulate/acts-and-standards/esos-act)).

*   **Provider Responsibilities:** The ESOS Act places several responsibilities on registered providers, including providing accurate marketing information, ensuring students are appropriately qualified for their chosen courses, and having written agreements with students that protect their rights and set out the responsibilities of each party ([b3-the-esos-act.md](b3-the-esos-act.md); [b4-1-national-code-standards.md](b4-1-national-code-standards.md)).

*   **Agent Responsibilities:** Under the ESOS Act, providers are responsible for the actions of their education agents. Providers must ensure that agents act honestly, in good faith, and in the best interests of the student ([b3-the-esos-act.md](b3-the-esos-act.md)).

### The National Code of Practice for Providers of Education and Training to Overseas Students 2018

The National Code of Practice for Providers of Education and Training to Overseas Students 2018 (National Code 2018) is a legislative instrument made under the ESOS Act 2000 ([b2-2-the-national-code-of-practice-2018.md](b2-2-the-national-code-of-practice-2018.md); [National Code of Practice for Providers of Education and Training to Overseas Students 2018 - Department of Education, Australian Government](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework/national-code-practice-providers-education-and-training-overseas-students-2018)). It sets nationally consistent standards to support providers in delivering quality education and training to overseas students. The National Code 2018 commenced on 1 January 2018, and education providers must comply with it to maintain their registration to provide education services to overseas students ([b4-the-national-code-of-practice.md](b4-the-national-code-of-practice.md); [National Code of Practice for Providers of Education and Training to Overseas Students 2018 - Department of Education, Australian Government](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework/national-code-practice-providers-education-and-training-overseas-students-2018)).

#### Objectives of the National Code 2018

The objectives of the National Code 2018 are to:

*   Support the ESOS framework.
*   Safeguard Australia’s international reputation as a provider of high-quality education and training.
*   Protect the interests of overseas students.
*   Support registered providers in monitoring student compliance with Student visa conditions ([Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) legislative framework | UniSC | University of the Sunshine Coast, Queensland, Australia](https://www.usc.edu.au/about/careers-at-unisc/staff/education-services-for-overseas-students-esos-legislative-framework); [ESOS Framework | Australian Skills Quality Authority (ASQA)](https://www.asqa.gov.au/about-us/asqa-overview/key-legislation/esos-framework)).

#### Key Standards of the National Code 2018

The National Code 2018 comprises 11 standards that cover various aspects of the international student experience ([b2-2-the-national-code-of-practice-2018.md](b2-2-the-national-code-of-practice-2018.md); [b4-1-national-code-standards.md](b4-1-national-code-standards.md)):

1.  **Marketing Information and Practices:** Ensures that the marketing of courses and services is not false or misleading ([b4-1-national-code-standards.md](b4-1-national-code-standards.md)).

2.  **Recruitment of an Overseas Student:** Sets out that registered providers must recruit responsibly by ensuring students are appropriately qualified for the course for which they seek enrolment ([b4-1-national-code-standards.md](b4-1-national-code-standards.md)).

3.  **Formalisation of Enrolment and Written Agreements:** Requires registered providers to formalise enrolment through written agreements that protect the rights and set out the responsibilities of each party ([b4-1-national-code-standards.md](b4-1-national-code-standards.md)).

4.  **Education Agents:** Registered education providers must ensure that their education agents act ethically, honestly, and in the best interests of overseas students ([b4-1-national-code-standards.md](b4-1-national-code-standards.md); [b4-the-national-code-of-practice.md](b4-the-national-code-of-practice.md)).

5.  **Younger Overseas Students:** Addresses the specific needs and welfare of students under 18 years of age ([b2-2-the-national-code-of-practice-2018.md](b2-2-the-national-code-of-practice-2018.md)).

6.  **Overseas Student Support Services:** Requires registered providers to assist overseas students to adjust to study and life in Australia and have appropriate orientation programs ([b4-1-national-code-standards.md](b4-1-national-code-standards.md)).

7.  **Overseas Student Transfers:** Sets conditions for when a registered provider can enrol an overseas student wishing to transfer from another provider ([b4-1-national-code-standards.md](b4-1-national-code-standards.md)).

8.  **Overseas Student Visa Requirements:** Requires registered providers to safeguard the integrity of Australia’s migration laws by supporting overseas students to complete their course within the required duration and fulfil their visa requirements ([b4-1-national-code-standards.md](b4-1-national-code-standards.md)).

9.  **Deferring, Suspending, or Cancelling the Overseas Student’s Enrolment:** Sets out that registered providers must appropriately manage the enrolment of their overseas students and ensure all necessary information has been provided to the relevant government department ([b4-1-national-code-standards.md](b4-1-national-code-standards.md)).

10. **Complaints and Appeals:** Requires registered providers to have mechanisms for addressing student complaints and appeals ([b4-1-national-code-standards.md](b4-1-national-code-standards.md)).

11. **Additional Requirements:** Covers any other requirements deemed necessary to ensure student welfare and quality education ([b2-2-the-national-code-of-practice-2018.md](b2-2-the-national-code-of-practice-2018.md)).

#### How the National Code Relates to Agents

The National Code directly relates to education agents, as an agent’s behavior is the direct responsibility of the education provider ([b2-2-the-national-code-of-practice-2018.md](b2-2-the-national-code-of-practice-2018.md); [b4-the-national-code-of-practice.md](b4-the-national-code-of-practice.md)). If an agent makes a mistake or behaves dishonestly, the education provider will be held responsible for their actions. The National Code 2018 requires that providers have a written agreement with all education agents they engage to formally represent them. The agreement must contain corrective actions and termination conditions ([b2-2-the-national-code-of-practice-2018.md](b2-2-the-national-code-of-practice-2018.md)).

### Other Relevant Legislation and Regulations

While the ESOS Act 2000 and the National Code of Practice 2018 are the primary pieces of legislation governing international students, other laws and regulations also play a role:

*   **The Migration Act 1958:** This Act and associated migration regulations govern the issuing of Student, Tourist, and other visas ([b2-4-the-migration-act-1958.md](b2-4-the-migration-act-1958.md)). The Department of Home Affairs (DHA) is responsible for administering this Act. To obtain a student visa, students must intend to study a CRICOS-registered course, have a Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE), demonstrate financial capacity, have appropriate academic background and English language proficiency, and demonstrate they are a genuine temporary entrant ([b2-4-the-migration-act-1958.md](b2-4-the-migration-act-1958.md)).

### Conclusion

In conclusion, the legislative and regulatory framework in Australia relating to the enrolment of international students is primarily governed by the **ESOS Act 2000 and the National Code of Practice 2018**. These instruments work in tandem to ensure the quality of education, protect the interests of international students, and maintain Australia's reputation as a leading destination for international education. While the Migration Act 1958 also plays a role in visa issuance, the ESOS Act and the National Code are the most directly relevant to the enrolment and treatment of international students within the Australian education system. The Australian Government consistently updates and amends these frameworks to address emerging challenges and maintain the integrity of the international education sector ([Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Act](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/ESOS-Act/Pages/default.aspx)).

question_results.question:
Which of the following circumstances is NOT reported online through PRISMS by an educational institution:

Answer options:
Students non-attendance
Students failing to meet course requirements
Students finishing their ELICOS course one week later due to approved vacation.
Both B and C
correct_answers: Students finishing their ELICOS course one week later due to approved vacation.
extracted_answers: Both B and C
question_results.full_response:
Here's a comprehensive report addressing the query, adhering to the specified guidelines and incorporating relevant information from the provided sources.

## Report on PRISMS Reporting Obligations for Educational Institutions

**Introduction**

The Provider Registration and International Student Management System (PRISMS) is a critical tool utilized by Australian educational institutions to communicate information about international students to the Department of Home Affairs (DHA) ([b6-1-access-to-prisms.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-1-access-to-prisms/)). This system ensures compliance with the Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Act and the National Code of Practice, which safeguard the integrity of Australia's migration laws and the quality of education provided to overseas students ([b4-1-national-code-standards.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b4-1-national-code-standards/)). Registered providers are obligated to maintain updated information in PRISMS regarding student enrolments, visa conditions, and course progress ([b4-1-national-code-standards.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b4-1-national-code-standards/)). This report aims to determine which of the provided circumstances—student non-attendance, failure to meet course requirements, or a one-week extension of an ELICOS course due to approved vacation—are *not* reported through PRISMS.

**Analysis of Reporting Obligations**

To accurately address the query, it is essential to examine the specific reporting requirements outlined in the National Code and related guidelines. The following analysis breaks down each circumstance and its corresponding reporting obligations:

**A. Student Non-Attendance**

Educational providers are required to monitor student attendance to ensure compliance with visa conditions ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions/)). Specifically, students are generally expected to attend at least 80% of their scheduled lessons ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions/)). When a student's attendance falls below this threshold, the provider must take specific actions, including notifying the student of their intention to report them to DHA ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions/)).

The National Code provides some flexibility in reporting non-attendance. Providers may choose not to report a breach if the student's attendance is at least 70%, they are maintaining satisfactory academic performance, and the decision aligns with the provider's documented attendance policies and procedures ([National Code Part D, Standard 11](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD11.aspx)). Compassionate or compelling circumstances may also be considered ([National Code Part D, Standard 11](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD11.aspx)). However, if a student's attendance falls below 70%, the provider must issue a notice of intention to report the student for unsatisfactory attendance ([National Code Part D, Standard 11](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD11.aspx)).

If the student does not access the complaints and appeals process within 20 working days, withdraws from the process, or the process results in a decision supporting the provider, the provider must notify the Secretary of DEEWR through PRISMS that the student is not achieving satisfactory attendance as soon as practicable ([National Code Part D, Standard 11](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD11.aspx)).

**Conclusion:** Student non-attendance, particularly when it falls below established thresholds and does not meet the criteria for non-reporting, is a reportable event in PRISMS.

**B. Students Failing to Meet Course Requirements**

Registered providers must safeguard the integrity of Australia’s migration laws by supporting overseas students to complete their course within the required duration and fulfill their visa requirements for course attendance and course progress ([b4-1-national-code-standards.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b4-1-national-code-standards/)). Unsatisfactory academic performance is one of the two reasons why an educational provider uses PRISMS to report students to DHA for non-compliance ([b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms/)).

The education provider must have documented policies and procedures for monitoring course progress and determining when a student has failed to make satisfactory course progress ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions/)). The provider must issue the student a written notification of their intention to report the student to DHA. The letter must also inform the student they have 20 working days within which to access the provider’s complaints and appeals process ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions/)). Once this timeframe has lapsed or the appeals process has been finalised and found in favour of the provider; the provider reports the visa breach using PRISMS ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions/)).

**Conclusion:** Students failing to meet course requirements, particularly after the exhaustion of internal appeals processes, is a reportable event in PRISMS.

**C. Students Finishing Their ELICOS Course One Week Later Due to Approved Vacation**

This scenario requires a nuanced understanding of PRISMS reporting. The critical factor is whether the student's Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE) needs to be changed. If the student follows the same pathway that they originally intended and the details on their eCoE do not need to be changed in any way, students are not reported ([b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms/)).

However, if any changes are necessary, the institution uses PRISMS to produce a Student Course Variation (SCV) ([b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms/)). Generally, the following events require an educational provider to use PRISMS to report to the student to DHA: The student finishes the course before the date on the CoE ([b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms/)). The student leaves the provider ([b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms/)).

If the student is finishing their ELICOS course one week *later* due to approved vacation, this implies that the course end date on the original CoE is no longer accurate. In this case, the provider would need to update the CoE to reflect the new course end date. This update is done through PRISMS.

**Conclusion:** Students finishing their ELICOS course one week later due to approved vacation *does* require reporting through PRISMS, specifically to update the CoE with the new course end date.

**Final Answer**

Based on the analysis above:

*   **Students non-attendance:** Reportable through PRISMS.
*   **Students failing to meet course requirements:** Reportable through PRISMS.
*   **Students finishing their ELICOS course one week later due to approved vacation:** Reportable through PRISMS, as it necessitates a CoE update.

Therefore, the correct answer is **Both B and C** is incorrect. All the options are reportable through PRISMS.

**Recommendations**

To ensure compliance with PRISMS reporting obligations, educational institutions should:

1.  **Develop and maintain a comprehensive PRISMS compliance policy:** This policy should outline the processes, responsibilities, and deadlines for reporting in PRISMS ([vetresources.com.au](https://vetresources.com.au/blog/essential-prisms-compliance-guide-avoid-costly-mistakes-and-stay-esos-compliant-a-must-read-for-all-rtos/)).
2.  **Provide regular staff training:** Staff responsible for handling PRISMS data must understand the ESOS Act's requirements and the importance of accurate, timely reporting ([vetresources.com.au](https://vetresources.com.au/blog/essential-prisms-compliance-guide-avoid-costly-mistakes-and-stay-esos-compliant-a-must-read-for-all-rtos/)).
3.  **Conduct regular audits of PRISMS entries:** This will help ensure accuracy and timeliness ([vetresources.com.au](https://vetresources.com.au/blog/essential-prisms-compliance-guide-avoid-costly-mistakes-and-stay-esos-compliant-a-must-read-for-all-rtos/)).
4.  **Automate reminders:** Implement automated systems to remind staff of reporting deadlines ([vetresources.com.au](https://vetresources.com.au/blog/essential-prisms-compliance-guide-avoid-costly-mistakes-and-stay-esos-compliant-a-must-read-for-all-rtos/)).

By implementing these recommendations, educational institutions can minimize the risk of non-compliance and ensure the smooth running of their operations.

***

**References**

question_results.question:
A student you recruited to study in Australia has been very sick and been taken to hospital. They have not provided the institution with a current address. This may mean:

Answer options:
The hospital is unable to release the student from hospital.
The student will not receive any letters about their possible non-compliance with visa conditions
The student will be deported from Australia for not providing current information to its education provider.
The student will not be believed when he tells the institution he was sick.
correct_answers: The student will not receive any letters about their possible non-compliance with visa conditions
extracted_answers: The student will not receive any letters about their possible non-compliance with visa conditions
question_results.full_response:
## Report on the Implications of a Student's Illness and Failure to Provide Current Address

**Introduction**

This report addresses the scenario of an international student in Australia who has been hospitalized due to illness and has not provided their education provider with a current address. The query focuses on the potential consequences of this situation, specifically regarding the student's visa status and access to necessary communications. This report will analyze the provided information to determine the most likely outcome and provide a comprehensive overview of the relevant factors.

**Analysis of Potential Consequences**

Based on the information provided, the most likely consequence of the student's failure to provide a current address is that they will not receive any letters about their possible non-compliance with visa conditions. This conclusion is drawn from several key points within the provided documentation.

*   **Address Notification Requirement:** Student visa holders are obligated to inform their education provider of their current address in Australia within seven days of arriving and to update any change of address within seven days of moving ([KangarooEdu.au, 2025](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025/)). This requirement is explicitly stated in multiple sources ([b9-1-visa-conditions.md](no link)), ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](no link)).
*   **Formal Notices:** Education providers send all formal notices to the student's registered address ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](no link)).
*   **Reporting to DHA:** Education providers are required to have documented policies and procedures for monitoring course progress and determining when a student has failed to make satisfactory course progress ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](no link)). If a student fails to meet these requirements, the provider must issue a written notification of their intention to report the student to the Department of Home Affairs (DHA) ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](no link)).
*   **PRISMS Reporting:** Once the timeframe for appeals has lapsed or the appeals process has been finalized in favor of the provider, the provider reports the visa breach using the Provider Registration and International Student Management System (PRISMS) ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](no link)).
*   **DHA Notification:** After a visa breach is reported, the student will then receive a notice informing them that they must attend an Immigration office within 28 days. Should they not do this, their visa may be cancelled ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](no link)).
*   **Consequences of Not Receiving Notices:** If the student has not provided the institution with a current postal address, the formal letter may not reach the student. Consequently, the student may not realize that an appointment is necessary ([b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms.md](no link)). In this situation, the student visa is still at risk of being cancelled, because it is the student’s responsibility to ensure the provider has their current postal address ([b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms.md](no link)).

**Why Other Options Are Less Likely**

*   **The hospital is unable to release the student from hospital:** While privacy concerns exist regarding the release of medical information, the hospital's ability to release the student is not directly contingent on the student's address being updated with the education provider. Medical authorities will communicate with the student's parents, spouse, or husband unless the student has expressed a wish for them not to ([b10-2-when-is-privacy-a-concern.md](no link)). The hospital will also communicate with the student directly.
*   **The student will be deported from Australia for not providing current information to its education provider:** While failing to update the address is a breach of visa conditions, deportation is not an automatic consequence. The student will first receive a notice to attend a DHA office, and only if they fail to do so will their visa be at risk of cancellation ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](no link)).
*   **The student will not be believed when he tells the institution he was sick:** The student's credibility regarding their illness is not directly affected by their failure to update their address. If the student has a valid reason for non-compliance, such as being sick, and can provide medical certificates to prove this, DHA may decide not to cancel the visa ([b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms.md](no link)).

**Additional Considerations**

*   **Visa Conditions:** It is essential that every agent informs their students of the need to comply with their visa conditions. If a student does not comply, their visa may be cancelled and they may need to return home ([b9-1-visa-conditions.md](no link)). There is also a three-year ban (exclusion period) on re-entry to Australia if a visa is cancelled for breaching visa conditions ([b9-1-visa-conditions.md](no link)).
*   **Student Responsibilities:** Students must maintain enrolment in a full-time registered course, satisfy their provider’s requirements for attendance and course progress, and maintain adequate health insurance ([b9-1-visa-conditions.md](no link)).
*   **Education Provider Responsibilities:** The education provider must approve arrangements, including when arrangements change, if the student is under 18 and their welfare arrangements are approved through the education provider ([b9-1-visa-conditions.md](no link)).
*   **Privacy:** Agents working in Australia are subject to privacy laws and need to understand how information about individuals can be used ([b10-1-what-should-an-agent-know-about-privacy.md](no link)).
*   **Changes to Student Visas in 2025:** As of January 1, 2025, all Australian student visa applications must include a Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE), replacing Letters of Offer ([VisaVerge.com, 2025](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/)). Onshore applications without CoEs are invalid, and students risk losing lawful status if current visas expire before meeting requirements ([VisaVerge.com, 2025](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/)).

**Recommendations**

Given the potential consequences, the following actions are recommended:1.  **Immediate Action:** The education provider should attempt to contact the student through all available means (e.g., phone, email, emergency contact details) to ascertain their current location and condition.
2.  **Address Update:** Once contact is established, the student should immediately update their address with the education provider.
3.  **Explanation and Documentation:** The student should provide a written explanation for their failure to update their address, along with supporting documentation (e.g., medical certificates) to demonstrate that their hospitalization prevented them from fulfilling this requirement.
4.  **Legal Advice:** The student should seek legal advice from a migration expert to understand their rights and obligations and to ensure that they take all necessary steps to protect their visa status.
5.  **Education Provider Support:** The education provider should provide support to the student, including guidance on the visa requirements and assistance with the address update process.

**Conclusion**

While the student's hospitalization is a serious matter, the most immediate consequence of their failure to provide a current address is the risk of not receiving critical communications from their education provider and the DHA regarding potential visa breaches. This can lead to further complications and potentially jeopardize their ability to remain in Australia. By taking prompt action to update their address, provide an explanation for their non-compliance, and seek legal advice, the student can mitigate these risks and ensure that their visa status is protected.

**References**

*   VisaVerge.com. (2025, February 18). *Australia Updates Student Visa Rules for 2025 to Ensure Genuine Applicants*. [https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/)
*   KangarooEdu.au. (2025). *Navigating Australian Student Visa Requirements in 2025: A Beginner’s Guide*. [https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025/](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025/)
*   b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms.md*   b9-1-visa-conditions.md
*   b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md
*   b10-1-what-should-an-agent-know-about-privacy.md
*   b10-2-when-is-privacy-a-concern.md

question_results.question:
A student you recruited to study in Australia has contacted you. Their school has been forced to close down and they will no longer be able to attend classes. Which of the following is likely to happen to the student because their school is closing:

Answer options:
The student will have to go back to their home country because they will no longer be enrolled at a school in Australia. The school will cancel their visa and help them move back to home. The student will receive a refund from the School.
The student will have to go back to their home country because they will no longer be enrolled at a school in Australia. The student will be unable to recover their tuition fees.
The student should be able to transfer to another school in Australia because their status as an international student is protected by the ESOS Act 2000 and the Tuition Protection Service (TPS).
None of the above.
correct_answers: The student should be able to transfer to another school in Australia because their status as an international student is protected by the ESOS Act 2000 and the Tuition Protection Service (TPS).
extracted_answers: The student should be able to transfer to another school in Australia because their status as an international student is protected by the ESOS Act 2000 and the Tuition Protection Service (TPS).
question_results.full_response:
## Report on International Student Protection Following School Closure in Australia

The following report addresses the situation of an international student in Australia whose education provider has been forced to close. It examines the protections available to the student under Australian law and outlines the most likely course of action. Based on the information provided, the most accurate response is: The student should be able to transfer to another school in Australia because their status as an international student is protected by the ESOS Act 2000 and the Tuition Protection Service (TPS).

### Legal Framework: ESOS Act 2000 and the National Code

The Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Act 2000 is the primary legislation governing the provision of education and training to international students in Australia who hold a student visa ([International Education, 2025](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/ESOS-Act/Pages/default.aspx)). The ESOS Act ensures that registered providers meet nationally consistent standards in education delivery, facilities, and services, and it offers tuition fee protection for international students ([Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Framework, 2025](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework)).

The ESOS Act has three main objectives:
1.  To provide financial and tuition assurance to overseas students for courses they have paid for ([b2-1-the-esos-act.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b2-1-the-esos-act/)).
2.  Making sure that students receive the tuition they have paid for.
3.  If an educational institution closes, a student is provided with alternative tuition or be given a refund ([b2-1-the-esos-act.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b2-1-the-esos-act/)).

To achieve the intended purposes of the ESOS Act, the legislation also provides a National Code of Practice ([b4-the-national-code-of-practice.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b4-the-national-code-of-practice/)). The National Code of Practice for Providers of Education and Training to Overseas Students 2018 sets nationally consistent standards and procedures for registered providers ([Study, 2025](https://study.csu.edu.au/international/study-with-us/esos-protecting-your-rights)). Education providers must comply with the National Code to maintain their registration to provide education services to overseas students ([b4-the-national-code-of-practice.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b4-the-national-code-of-practice/)).

### Tuition Protection Service (TPS)

The Tuition Protection Service (TPS) is an Australian Government initiative designed to assist international students whose education providers are unable to fully deliver their course of study ([b3-2-protection-for-international-students.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b3-2-protection-for-international-students/)). The TPS ensures that international students are able to either:

*   Complete their studies in another course or with another education provider, or
*   Receive a refund of their unspent tuition fees ([b3-2-protection-for-international-students.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b3-2-protection-for-international-students/)).

The TPS is activated when a provider defaults, meaning they fail to meet their obligations to provide the program ([b3-2-protection-for-international-students.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b3-2-protection-for-international-students/)). In such cases, the provider must either refund the unexpended portion of prepaid tuition fees or offer an alternative place, accepted in writing by the student ([b3-2-protection-for-international-students.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b3-2-protection-for-international-students/)). The TPS gives students control and responsibility within the placement process by allowing students to make a choice from available alternative placement options ([b3-2-protection-for-international-students.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b3-2-protection-for-international-students/)).

### Procedures Following a Provider Closure

When an education institution closes, the TPS and the Australian Government work to ensure that all students are placed in a suitable alternative course ([b3-2-protection-for-international-students.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b3-2-protection-for-international-students/)). For example, if a college closes and cannot provide a refund or alternative course, students will be offered a place in the same or a similar course with other colleges in the same area, at no extra cost, enabling them to complete their studies ([b3-2-protection-for-international-students.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b3-2-protection-for-international-students/)).

If a student is affected by the closure and needs to apply for a new student visa to continue their studies, they may be eligible for an exemption from paying the student visa application fee ([b3-2-protection-for-international-students.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b3-2-protection-for-international-students/)). This exemption may also extend to a guardian holding a Student Guardian visa (subclass 580) ([b3-2-protection-for-international-students.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b3-2-protection-for-international-students/)).

### Steps for Agents and Students

If an institution closes, agents should refer affected students to the Tuition Protection Service ([b3-2-protection-for-international-students.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b3-2-protection-for-international-students/)). Students should also:

1.  **Seek Support:** Notify their education agents immediately ([Raposas, 2024](https://pathwaytoaus.com/general/school-closed-a-guide-for-international-student-in-australia/)).
2.  **Update ImmiAccount:** Once a new course is secured, update visa information via ImmiAccount to reflect the new provider and course details ([Raposas, 2024](https://pathwaytoaus.com/general/school-closed-a-guide-for-international-student-in-australia/)).
3.  **Gather Academic Records:** Collect all necessary documentation from the closing school ([Raposas, 2024](https://pathwaytoaus.com/general/school-closed-a-guide-for-international-student-in-australia/)).

### International House (IH) Closure Example

The closure of International House (IH) Sydney in December 2024 provides a recent example of how the TPS operates ([International House (IH) closure - what does this mean international student visa-holders?, 2024](https://www.internationalstudentaustralia.com.au/news-and-updates/international-house-ih-closure-international-students)). Following the closure, the administrator had 14 days to meet obligations under the ESOS Act, including offering students a place in an alternative course or providing a refund of unspent tuition fees ([News - English Australia, 2024](https://www.englishaustralia.com.au/news/closure-of-international-house-sydney-tps-update)). The TPS then assessed the situation and engaged with students to process claims for refunds ([News - English Australia, 2024](https://www.englishaustralia.com.au/news/closure-of-international-house-sydney-tps-update)).

### Student Visa Considerations

A student visa remains valid if a school closes; however, it is crucial to remain compliant with visa conditions, which include being enrolled in a registered course ([Raposas, 2024](https://pathwaytoaus.com/general/school-closed-a-guide-for-international-student-in-australia/)). Students have a limited time to enroll in a new course, and failure to do so could affect their visa, potentially leading to cancellation ([Raposas, 2024](https://pathwaytoaus.com/general/school-closed-a-guide-for-international-student-in-australia/)).

### Prepaid Tuition Fees

The ESOS legislation limits the amount of prepaid tuition fees a provider can demand from a student before they commence their course to 50%, unless the course is 24 weeks or less, in which case they can require 100% of the fees to be paid ([b3-2-protection-for-international-students.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b3-2-protection-for-international-students/)). Providers not administered by a state authority or eligible for recurrent Commonwealth funding (i.e., Private Providers) must keep any initial prepaid tuition fees in a designated account before the student commences the course ([b3-2-protection-for-international-students.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b3-2-protection-for-international-students/)).

### Limitations on International Student Intake for 2025

While not directly related to school closures, it's important to note that the Australian government has proposed a cap of 270,000 new international student commencements for the year 2025, aiming to restore numbers to pre-pandemic levels ([a7-5-international-student-numbers.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/a7-5-international-student-numbers/)). This cap will apply to both higher education and vocational education sectors, excluding primary and secondary schools as well as standalone English-language providers ([a7-5-international-student-numbers.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/a7-5-international-student-numbers/)). Public universities will have a combined cap of approximately 145,000 new international students, while the vocational education sector is allocated 95,000 spots, and private universities and non-higher education providers will receive around 30,000 places ([a7-5-international-student-numbers.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/a7-5-international-student-numbers/)). However, this cap is facing political opposition and may not be implemented ([Visaverge, 2025](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-international-student-caps-plan-faces-blockade/)).

### Conclusion

In conclusion, the ESOS Act 2000 and the Tuition Protection Service (TPS) provide a safety net for international students in Australia in the event of an education provider closure. The student should be able to transfer to another school in Australia because their status as an international student is protected by the ESOS Act 2000 and the Tuition Protection Service (TPS). The student is entitled to either complete their studies in an alternative course or receive a refund of their unspent tuition fees. Agents play a crucial role in guiding students through this process and ensuring they are aware of their rights and responsibilities.

[https://pathwaytoaus.com/general/school-closed-a-guide-for-international-student-in-australia/](https://pathwaytoaus.com/general/school-closed-a-guide-for-international-student-in-australia/)

The Tuition Protection Service is outlined in:

The Australia Act 1901

question_results.full_response:
## The Tuition Protection Service and its Legislative Foundation: An In-Depth Analysis

The Australian international education sector is underpinned by a robust regulatory framework designed to protect the interests of overseas students. A key component of this framework is the Tuition Protection Service (TPS), a vital safety net for international students whose education providers are unable to fully deliver their course of study. Understanding the legislative basis of the TPS is crucial for education agents, providers, and students alike. This report will analyze the legislative foundation of the TPS, focusing on the Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Act 2000 as its primary source.

### The Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Act 2000: The Cornerstone of Tuition Protection

Based on the provided information, the Tuition Protection Service is outlined in **The ESOS Act 2000**. This Act is the primary legislation regulating international education in Australia, establishing the framework for protecting international students and ensuring the quality of education services ([b2-1-the-esos-act.md](b2-1-the-esos-act.md)).

The ESOS Act 2000 governs several critical aspects of international education, including:

*   The registration process and obligations of registered providers ([internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/ESOS-Act/Pages/default.aspx)).
*   The Tuition Protection Service (TPS) ([b2-1-the-esos-act.md](b2-1-the-esos-act.md), [internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/ESOS-Act/Pages/default.aspx)).
*   Enforcement and compliance powers ([b2-1-the-esos-act.md](b2-1-the-esos-act.md), [internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/ESOS-Act/Pages/default.aspx)).

The ESOS Act's primary objective is to provide financial and tuition assurance to overseas students for courses they have paid for. This includes ensuring students receive the tuition they have paid for and providing alternative tuition or refunds if an educational institution closes ([b2-1-the-esos-act.md](b2-1-the-esos-act.md)). The Act also aims to protect and enhance Australia's reputation for quality education and training services and complement Australia's migration laws by ensuring providers collect and report information relevant to student visas ([b2-1-the-esos-act.md](b2-1-the-esos-act.md)).

### The Tuition Protection Service (TPS): A Safety Net for International Students

The Tuition Protection Service (TPS) is an Australian Government initiative established under the ESOS Act 2000 to assist international students whose education providers are unable to fully deliver their course of study ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/about-tuition-protection-services-tps)). The TPS ensures that international students can either complete their studies in another course or with another education provider or receive a refund of their unspent tuition fees ([b3-2-protection-for-international-students.md](b3-2-protection-for-international-students.md)).

The TPS operates as a mechanism to place students when a provider fails to meet its obligations to provide the program, which is termed a "provider default" ([b3-2-protection-for-international-students.md](b3-2-protection-for-international-students.md)). A provider default occurs when an education provider closes, fails to start a course, or stops offering a course to enrolled students ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/about-tuition-protection-services-tps)).

In the event of a provider default, the provider must either refund affected students the unexpended portion of their prepaid tuition fees or offer an alternative place, which is accepted in writing by the student ([b3-2-protection-for-international-students.md](b3-2-protection-for-international-students.md)). The TPS gives students control and responsibility within the placement process by allowing them to choose from available alternative placement options ([b3-2-protection-for-international-students.md](b3-2-protection-for-international-students.md)).

### Provider and Student Obligations Under the ESOS Act

The ESOS Act outlines specific obligations for both providers and students. Providers must report provider and student defaults to the TPS Director and the Secretary ([b3-2-protection-for-international-students.md](b3-2-protection-for-international-students.md)).

Following a provider default, a provider must fulfill its obligations under sections 46A-46F of the ESOS Act, including:

*   Giving written notice of the default to the relevant ESOS agency and the TPS Director within three business days of the default occurring ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/international-providers-tps)).
*   Giving written notice of the default to the students in relation to whom the provider has defaulted ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/international-providers-tps)).
*   Discharging its obligations to students within the provider obligation period of 14 days after the default day by either arranging for students to be offered a place in an alternative course (and the student accepting that offer in writing) or providing a refund of unspent tuition fees ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/international-providers-tps)).
*   Notifying the relevant ESOS agency and the TPS Director of the outcome of discharge of obligations within seven days after the end of the provider obligation period ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/international-providers-tps)).

Under section 47A of the ESOS Act, an overseas student or intending overseas student defaults if:

*   The student does not start the course on the agreed starting day (and has not previously withdrawn) ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/international-providers-tps)).
*   The student withdraws from the course at the location (either before or after the agreed starting day) ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/international-providers-tps)).
*   The provider refuses to provide, or continue providing, the course to the student at the location because the student failed to pay an amount they were liable to pay the provider, breached a condition of their student visa, or engaged in misbehavior ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/international-providers-tps)).

Following a student default, a provider must fulfill its obligations under sections 47A-47H of the ESOS Act, including providing a refund to the defaulted student in accordance with either section 47D or 47E of the ESOS Act within the provider obligation period of four weeks and, if a refund was provided to a defaulted student under section 47E of the ESOS Act, notifying the relevant ESOS agency and the TPS Director of the outcome of discharge of obligations within seven days after the end of the provider obligation period ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/international-providers-tps)).

### The National Code of Practice 2018

The National Code of Practice for Registration Authorities and Providers of Education and Training to Overseas Students 2018 (The National Code) is another crucial component of the ESOS framework ([b4-the-national-code-of-practice.md](b4-the-national-code-of-practice.md)). It sets out the standards that education providers must meet to maintain their registration to provide education services to overseas students ([b4-the-national-code-of-practice.md](b4-the-national-code-of-practice.md)). The National Code is found in Part 4, Division 2 of the ESOS Act ([b4-the-national-code-of-practice.md](b4-the-national-code-of-practice.md)).

### Amendments to the ESOS Act

The ESOS Act has been amended several times since its inception in 2000 to strengthen the protection of international students and improve the regulation of the international education sector ([internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/ESOS-Act/Pages/default.aspx)). Recent amendments include:

*   The Education Services for Overseas Students Legislation Amendment (Tuition Protection Service and Other Measures) Act 2012 ([internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/ESOS-Act/Pages/default.aspx)).
*   The Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration Charges) Amendment (Tuition Protection Service) Act 2012 ([internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/ESOS-Act/Pages/default.aspx)).
*   The Education Services for Overseas Students (TPS Levies) Act 2012 ([internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/ESOS-Act/Pages/default.aspx)).
*   Education Services for Overseas Students legislation Amendment Act 2011 ([internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/ESOS-Act/Pages/default.aspx)).

These amendments have focused on strengthening the registration requirements of education providers, introducing a consistent risk management approach to the regulation of international education, and extending the range of non-compliant behavior that could attract financial penalties ([internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/ESOS-Act/Pages/default.aspx)).

### Conclusion

The ESOS Act 2000 is the legislative foundation of the Tuition Protection Service (TPS) and the broader regulatory framework for international education in Australia. It establishes the rights and responsibilities of education providers and international students and provides a safety net for students in the event of a provider default. Education agents, providers, and students must understand the ESOS Act and the National Code to ensure compliance and protect the interests of international students. The TPS is a critical component of this framework, providing tuition protection and supporting the integrity of the student visa program. The Australian Government, through the Department of Education, administers the ESOS Act and its associated instruments, ensuring the quality and protection of international education in Australia ([internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/ESOS-Act/Pages/default.aspx)).

### References

b2-1-the-esos-act.md
b3-2-protection-for-international-students.md
b4-the-national-code-of-practice.md
education.gov.au, "About the Tuition Protection Services (TPS) - Department of Education, Australian Government" [https://www.education.gov.au/tps/about-tuition-protection-services-tps](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/about-tuition-protection-services-tps)
education.gov.au, "International Providers - Department of Education, Australian Government" [https://www.education.gov.au/tps/international-providers-tps](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/international-providers-tps)
internationaleducation.gov.au, "Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Act" [https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/ESOS-Act/Pages/default.aspx](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/ESOS-Act/Pages/default.aspx)
