question_results.full_response:
## Student Visa Application Locations: A Detailed Report

The process of obtaining a student visa is a crucial step for international students aspiring to study in Australia or the USA. Understanding where to apply and the specific requirements is essential for a smooth and successful application. This report aims to identify the correct location for lodging a student visa application, drawing upon information from provided documents and web sources.

**Opinion:** Based on the information provided, the correct location for a student to apply for an Australian student visa is **online through the DHA (Department of Home Affairs) website**.

### Australian Student Visa Application Process and Locations

The primary authority for Australian student visas is the Department of Home Affairs (DHA) ([Department of Home Affairs (DHA)|](c2-6-government-peak-bodies-and-other-organisations.md)). The DHA controls and maintains Australia’s visa requirements, and it is the main point of contact for any visa-related issues ([Department of Home Affairs (DHA)|](c2-6-government-peak-bodies-and-other-organisations.md)).

#### Online Application via ImmiAccount

The most consistent and emphasized method for lodging a student visa application is through the DHA's online portal, ImmiAccount ([Lodging An Application via immiAccount](b8-1-the-student-visa-application-process.md)). Here’s a step-by-step breakdown of the online application process:

1.  **Create an ImmiAccount**: All agents and students should create an online account on the ImmiAccount portal to lodge applications ([Lodging An Application via immiAccount](b8-1-the-student-visa-application-process.md)).
2.  **Start a New Application**: After logging in, select the "My applications" tab and click "New Application" ([Lodging An Application via immiAccount](b8-1-the-student-visa-application-process.md)).
3.  **Select Application Type**: From the application group, select the applicable student visa type ([Lodging An Application via immiAccount](b8-1-the-student-visa-application-process.md)).
4.  **Terms and Conditions**: Read and agree to the terms and conditions before proceeding ([Step 6](b8-1-the-student-visa-application-process.md)).
5.  **Answer Questions**: Answer all the questions in the application form and click "Next" after each section ([Step 7](b8-1-the-student-visa-application-process.md)).
6.  **Review and Payment**: Review the completed application and proceed to make the payment. As of July 1, 2024, the base application fee for student visas is AUD $1,600, with additional fees for applicants over and under 18 ([Points to Note](b8-1-the-student-visa-application-process.md), [As of July 1, 2024](b7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications.md)).
7.  **Submit Application**: Click "Submit Now" to submit the application ([Step 9](b8-1-the-student-visa-application-process.md)).
8.  **Payment Details**: Enter payment details and click "Submit" ([Step 10](b8-1-the-student-visa-application-process.md)).
9.  **Confirmation**: Confirm the payment and click "Next" to view a summary of the application ([Step 12](b8-1-the-student-visa-application-process.md)).
10. **Go to My Account**: Click "Go to my account" to see the updated status of the application ([Step 13](b8-1-the-student-visa-application-process.md)).

#### Role of Education Agents

Many students opt to use education agents to assist with their visa application process ([Apply for your visa on the DHA website](https://www.acu.edu.au/international-students/arriving-and-living-in-Australia/applying-for-your-student-visa)). These agents are experienced in making international student applications and can communicate with the DHA on behalf of the student ([Education agents](https://study.csu.edu.au/international/live-and-work/student-visa)). Education agents can help with:

*   Preparation and review of the Genuine Temporary Entrant (GTE) statement ([Their Student Visa Application service includes:](https://www.dreamstudiesabroad.com/articles/student-visa-australia)).
*   Drafting the application form and collecting necessary data ([Their Student Visa Application service includes:](https://www.dreamstudiesabroad.com/articles/student-visa-australia)).
*   Ensuring all documents are correct ([Their Student Visa Application service includes:](https://www.dreamstudiesabroad.com/articles/student-visa-australia)).
*   Organizing Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC) insurance if required ([Their Student Visa Application service includes:](https://www.dreamstudiesabroad.com/articles/student-visa-australia)).
*   Processing the visa application and coordinating any additional information requests ([Their Student Visa Application service includes:](https://www.dreamstudiesabroad.com/articles/student-visa-australia)).

#### Key Requirements for a Student Visa

To obtain an Australian student visa, applicants must meet several criteria ([B7. Student Visas: Basic Requirements and Processes](b7-student-visas-basic-requirements-and-processes.md)):

*   **Acceptance into Full-Time Study**: The student must be accepted into a full-time study program ([The student must be accepted into full-time study](b7-student-visas-basic-requirements-and-processes.md)).
*   **Genuine Temporary Entrant (GTE)**: The student must be a genuine temporary entrant, intending to stay in Australia temporarily for the purpose of study ([Genuine Temporary Entrant (GTE)](b7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications.md)).
*   **Health and Health Insurance**: The student must meet health requirements and have adequate health insurance, typically OSHC (Overseas Student Health Cover) ([The student must meet health and health insurance requirements](b7-student-visas-basic-requirements-and-processes.md)).
*   **Good Character**: The student must be of good character and not have any debts to the Australian Government ([The student must have a “good” character and not have any debts to the Australian Government](b7-student-visas-basic-requirements-and-processes.md)).
*   **Financial Capacity**: The student must demonstrate the financial capacity to cover tuition fees, living expenses, and other costs ([The student must have the appropriate financial capacity to study in Australia](b2-4-the-migration-act-1958.md)). As of 2025, demonstrating sufficient financial resources is pivotal to application approval ([Budget Accordingly:](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/)).
*   **English Language Proficiency**: The student must demonstrate appropriate English language skills ([The student must demonstrate appropriate English language skills](b7-student-visas-basic-requirements-and-processes.md)). A minimum score of 6.0 is generally required for most applicants ([The English language proficiency requirement for student visas has increased](b7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications.md)).
*   **Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE)**: As of January 1, 2025, all student visa applications must include a Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE) from an Australian educational institution ([1. Mandatory Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE)](https://blog.admission.ac/2025/01/05/australia-changes-rules-for-student-visas-check-new-requirement-for-a-student-visa-application/)). The DHA will no longer accept Letters of Offer as proof of admission ([1. Mandatory Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE)](https://blog.admission.ac/2025/01/05/australia-changes-rules-for-student-visas-check-new-requirement-for-a-student-visa-application/)).

#### Changes in 2025

Several changes to the student visa process have been implemented in 2025 to ensure visa integrity and attract genuine international students ([Australia changes rules for student visas: Check new requirement for a student visa application](https://blog.admission.ac/2025/01/05/australia-changes-rules-for-student-visas-check-new-requirement-for-a-student-visa-application/)). Key updates include:

*   **Mandatory CoE**: All student visa applications must include a CoE ([1. Mandatory Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE)](https://blog.admission.ac/2025/01/05/australia-changes-rules-for-student-visas-check-new-requirement-for-a-student-visa-application/)).
*   **Increased Financial Costs**: Upfront costs, including tuition fees required for the CoE and the application fee of AUD 1,600, must be considered ([Budget Accordingly:](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/)).
*   **Restrictions on Onshore Applications**: Onshore applications without CoEs are invalid ([Onshore applications without CoEs are invalid](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/)).

### USA Student Visa Application Process and Locations

For students interested in studying in the USA, the process and locations for applying for a student visa are different. The primary visa for academic studies is the F-1 visa ([F1 Visa](https://yocket.com/study-in-usa/usa-student-visa)).

#### Types of US Student Visas

*   **F-1 Visa**: For full-time students at universities (undergraduate and graduate) ([F1 Visa](https://www.spscanada.com/blog/usa-student-visa-guide-2025-all-you-need-to-know/)).
*   **J-1 Visa**: For exchange visitors such as scholars or students in short-term programs ([J1 Visa](https://www.spscanada.com/blog/usa-student-visa-guide-2025-all-you-need-to-know/)).
*   **M-1 Visa**: For students attending vocational or non-academic programs ([M1 Visa](https://www.spscanada.com/blog/usa-student-visa-guide-2025-all-you-need-to-know/)).

#### Application Steps

1.  **Acceptance at a SEVP-Approved School**: You must be accepted into a US institution approved by the Student and Exchange Visitor Program (SEVP) ([Acceptance at a US institution approved by SEVP.](https://www.spscanada.com/blog/usa-student-visa-guide-2025-all-you-need-to-know/)).
2.  **Receive Form I-20**: Upon acceptance, your school will provide you with a Form I-20, "Certificate of Eligibility for Nonimmigrant Student Status" ([Form I-20](https://www.alonereaders.com/article/details/2399/how-to-apply-for-a-us-student-visa-f1-in-2025-a-comprehensive-guide)).
3.  **Pay the SEVIS Fee**: Pay the Student and Exchange Visitor Information System (SEVIS) fee ([Pay the SEVIS Fee](https://www.spscanada.com/blog/usa-student-visa-guide-2025-all-you-need-to-know/)).
4.  **Complete the DS-160 Form**: Fill out the Online Nonimmigrant Visa Application (DS-160) ([Fill out the DS-160 form](https://www.spscanada.com/blog/usa-student-visa-guide-2025-all-you-need-to-know/)).
5.  **Schedule a Visa Interview**: Schedule an appointment for your visa interview at the U.S. embassy or consulate in your country ([Visa Interview scheduled at the US Embassy or Consulate.](https://www.spscanada.com/blog/usa-student-visa-guide-2025-all-you-need-to-know/)).
6.  **Attend the Visa Interview**: Attend the visa interview with all required documents ([Attend the Visa Interview](https://www.alonereaders.com/article/details/2399/how-to-apply-for-a-us-student-visa-f1-in-2025-a-comprehensive-guide)).

#### Locations for Application

The application process for a US student visa is primarily online, but it requires in-person attendance for the visa interview. Indian students, for example, need to visit the biometric and US visa interview centers to complete their USA student visa process ([Where to Apply for a US Student Visa?](https://yocket.com/study-in-usa/usa-student-visa)).

#### Required Documents

*   Valid passport ([A valid passport.](https://www.spscanada.com/blog/usa-student-visa-guide-2025-all-you-need-to-know/)).
*   DS-160 confirmation ([DS-160 confirmation.](https://www.spscanada.com/blog/usa-student-visa-guide-2025-all-you-need-to-know/)).
*   SEVIS fee receipt ([SEVIS fee receipt.](https://www.spscanada.com/blog/usa-student-visa-guide-2025-all-you-need-to-know/)).
*   Form I-20 from your university ([Form I-20 from your university.](https://www.spscanada.com/blog/usa-student-visa-guide-2025-all-you-need-to-know/)).
*   Financial documents proving your ability to pay for your studies ([Financial documents Proving your ability to pay for your studies.](https://www.spscanada.com/blog/usa-student-visa-guide-2025-all-you-need-to-know/)).

### Conclusion

Based on the information, the correct answer to the query is: **Online through the DHA website**. The Australian student visa application process is primarily conducted online through the Department of Home Affairs' ImmiAccount portal. While education agents and other resources can assist with the application, the final submission is made online. The process for US student visas involves both online application and in-person interviews at US embassies or consulates.

question_results.question:
Which of the following is never required by DHA for an individual to obtain a student visa:

A valid passport
Providing appropriate information about the financial ability to pay for their study
Providing appropriate information about the English proficiency of the student
Providing appropriate information about the individuals knowledge of the history, language and culture of Australia.

question_results.full_response:
Here's a detailed report addressing the query about the requirements for obtaining an Australian student visa, focusing on the role of knowledge about Australian history, language, and culture:

### Report: Requirements for Obtaining an Australian Student Visa

**Introduction**

The Department of Home Affairs (DHA) in Australia sets specific criteria for international students seeking to study in the country. These requirements are designed to ensure that applicants are genuine students who intend to study and abide by visa conditions. This report aims to identify which of the listed elements is *not* a requirement for obtaining a student visa, based on available documentation. The options include: a valid passport, financial ability, English proficiency, and knowledge of Australian history, language, and culture.

**Core Requirements for an Australian Student Visa**

Based on the provided documents and web sources, the DHA requires several key criteria to be met for a student visa application to be successful. These include:

1.  **Acceptance into Full-Time Study**: The student must be accepted into a registered course of study in Australia ([b7-student-visas-basic-requirements-and-processes.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b7-student-visas-basic-requirements-and-processes/)).

2.  **Genuine Student (GS) Requirement**: As of March 23, 2024, the Genuine Temporary Entrant (GTE) requirement was replaced by the Genuine Student (GS) requirement. This involves answering targeted questions to provide clearer insights into the applicant's intentions and circumstances ([b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md)). Navitas notes that the DHA requires all applicants to complete a Genuine Student form at the visa submission stage ([Navitas Genuine Student Assessment information - Navitas](https://www.navitas.com/study/apply/genuine-student/)).

3.  **Health and Health Insurance**: Applicants must meet health requirements and have Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC) for the duration of their stay ([b7-student-visas-basic-requirements-and-processes.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b7-student-visas-basic-requirements-and-processes/)). Study Australia emphasizes that failure to provide proof of OSHC will result in visa refusal ([How to apply for your visa | Study Australia](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/visa-application-process)).

4.  **Good Character**: Applicants must demonstrate good character and not have any debts to the Australian Government ([b7-student-visas-basic-requirements-and-processes.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b7-student-visas-basic-requirements-and-processes/)).

5.  **Financial Capacity**: Students must prove they have sufficient funds to cover tuition fees, living expenses, and travel costs ([b7-student-visas-basic-requirements-and-processes.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b7-student-visas-basic-requirements-and-processes/)). As of 2024, the minimum funds required are AUD$29,710 for a single student ([b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md)).

6.  **English Language Skills**: Students must demonstrate appropriate English language skills ([b7-student-visas-basic-requirements-and-processes.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b7-student-visas-basic-requirements-and-processes/)).

7.  **Age Requirements**: Students must be of the appropriate age ([b7-student-visas-basic-requirements-and-processes.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b7-student-visas-basic-requirements-and-processes/)).

**Detailed Analysis of Each Requirement**

*   **A Valid Passport**: A valid passport is essential for international travel and serves as proof of identity and nationality. It is a fundamental requirement for visa applications, including the Australian student visa ([b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing/)).

*   **Financial Ability**: The DHA requires evidence of financial capacity to ensure that students can cover their expenses without becoming a burden on the Australian community. Acceptable evidence includes bank statements, government loans, and scholarships ([b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md)). StudyGurus emphasizes the importance of demonstrating a genuine and close connection with the person providing financial support ([How to show Minimum Financial Evidence for your student visa](https://studygurus.com.au/minimum-financial-evidence-for-your-student-visa-in-australia/)).

*   **English Proficiency**: Demonstrating English proficiency is crucial for students to succeed in their studies and integrate into the Australian community. The DHA accepts various English proficiency tests, such as IELTS, TOEFL, and PTE ([b7-student-visas-basic-requirements-and-processes.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b7-student-visas-basic-requirements-and-processes/)). EIA notes that the Australian government is elevating English language proficiency standards for Student and Temporary Graduate visas, with minimum test scores increasing as of March 23, 2024 ([Recent Changes on Australian Migration Strategy and Student Visas Requirements - EIA](https://eia.edu.au/blog/recent-changes-on-australian-migration-strategy-and-student-visas-requirements/)).

*   **Knowledge of Australian History, Language, and Culture**: While the DHA requires students to be genuine and intend to study in Australia, there is no explicit requirement for them to demonstrate knowledge of Australian history, language, and culture. The focus is on their intention to study, financial capacity, and English proficiency.

**Exemptions and Special Cases**

There are specific exemptions to the English language proficiency requirements for certain students, such as those from English-speaking countries or those enrolled in specific courses like ELICOS or postgraduate research ([b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md)). Additionally, secondary exchange students have specific financial evidence and welfare arrangement options ([b8-3-specific-requirements-in-particular-cases.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b8-3-specific-requirements-in-particular-cases/)).

**Integrity Concerns and DHA Scrutiny**

The DHA has increased scrutiny on student visa applications to identify genuine students and address integrity concerns. Examples of integrity concerns include providing false information about English language skills, family background, or financial support ([b8-4-examples-of-integrity-concerns-for-dha.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-4-examples-of-integrity-concerns-for-dha/)). EIA reports that a $19 million investment was placed in the Home Affairs student visa unit to raise the scrutiny for high-risk student visas ([Recent Changes on Australian Migration Strategy and Student Visas Requirements - EIA](https://eia.edu.au/blog/recent-changes-on-australian-migration-strategy-and-student-visas-requirements/)).

**Conclusion**

Based on the information provided, the element that is *not* explicitly required by the DHA for an individual to obtain a student visa is:

*   Providing appropriate information about the individual's knowledge of the history, language, and culture of Australia.

While demonstrating a genuine intention to study is crucial, the DHA does not mandate that applicants possess specific knowledge of Australian history, language, or culture. The focus is primarily on their academic qualifications, financial stability, English proficiency, and genuine intent to study in Australia.

question_results.question:
DHA considers evidentiary requirements for students from different countries on the basis of:

Answer options:
How many friends and relatives a student has who are currently living or studying in Australia.
How much business in trade and exports Australia does with the student’s country.
Statistical evidence of how students from that country comply with their visa conditions based on previous students’ behaviour in the last 12 months.

correct_answers: Statistical evidence of how students from that country comply with their visa conditions based on previous students’ behaviour in the last 12 months.
extracted_answers: Statistical evidence of how students from that country comply with their visa conditions based on previous students’ behaviour in the last 12 months.
question_results.full_response:
## DHA's Consideration of Evidentiary Requirements for Student Visas: A Statistical and Compliance-Based Approach

The Department of Home Affairs (DHA) in Australia employs a risk-based framework to assess student visa applications. This framework aims to streamline the visa process for genuine students while safeguarding the integrity of Australia's immigration system. A key component of this assessment involves considering evidentiary requirements for students from different countries. Based on available information, the DHA primarily determines these requirements based on **statistical evidence of how students from that country comply with their visa conditions based on previous students’ behavior in the last 12 months**. This report will delve into the specifics of this approach, examining the factors considered, the framework employed, and the implications for student visa applicants.

### The Simplified Student Visa Framework (SSVF) and Evidence Levels

The DHA utilizes the Simplified Student Visa Framework (SSVF), implemented on July 1, 2016, to guide the evidentiary requirements for student visa applications ([b2-4-the-migration-act-1958.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b2-australian-international-education-an-overview/topic/b2-4-the-migration-act-1958)). The SSVF operates on a combination of the student's country of citizenship and the rating of the education provider where the student intends to undertake their principal course of study ([b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing)). This combined rating determines whether a student is subject to streamlined (S) or regular (R) evidentiary requirements ([b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing)).

Students subject to regular evidentiary requirements are generally required to provide evidence of their financial capacity and English language proficiency with their visa application ([b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing)). Those eligible for streamlined arrangements may satisfy the DHA of their financial capacity through a declaration and are not generally required to provide evidence of their English language proficiency ([b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing)). However, the DHA retains the discretion to request further evidence from any student, regardless of their eligibility for streamlined arrangements ([b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing)).

### Factors Influencing Evidence Level Ratings

The DHA updates the country and provider ratings every six months based on historical data generated during the previous 12-month period ([b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing)). These ratings are calculated using a weighted average of several indicators related to student immigration outcomes ([b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing)). Key indicators include:

*   **Rate of visa cancellations (25% weighting):** This measures the proportion of student visas cancelled due to non-genuineness, fraud, or breaches of visa condition 8202 (maintaining enrolment, attendance, and course progress) ([b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing)). Breaches of work condition 8105 (working more than 40 hours per fortnight when the course is in session) and other visa conditions are also considered ([b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing)).
*   **Rate of refusals due to a fraud reason (40% weighting):** This represents the proportion of student visas refused at the application stage due to fraud ([b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing)). If a visa is refused due to fraud, this measure applies regardless of any other refusal reason ([b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing)).
*   **Rate of refusals (excluding fraud) where the applicant lodged overseas (10% weighting):** This measures the proportion of student visas refused for reasons other than fraud, such as not meeting the Genuine Temporary Entrant (GTE) (now Genuine Student (GS)), health, or other requirements ([b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing)).
*   **Rate of student visa holders becoming unlawful non-citizens (15% weighting):** This refers to the number of students who have overstayed their student visa for more than 28 days ([b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing)). Students who resolve their immigration status within 28 days are not counted ([b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing)).
*   **Rate of Subsequent Protection Visa applications (10% weighting):** This represents the proportion of students who applied for a Protection Visa (PV) where their last visa was a Student visa ([b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing)).

These indicators provide a comprehensive overview of a country's or provider's compliance with student visa regulations. Higher rates of visa cancellations, fraud, refusals, unlawful non-citizens, and protection visa applications contribute to a higher evidence level rating, potentially leading to more stringent evidentiary requirements for future student visa applicants from that country or provider.

### Evidence Level Ratings and Streamlined Processing

The DHA assigns evidence level ratings to both education providers and countries based on the weighted average of the aforementioned indicators ([b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing)). The ratings are categorized as follows:

*   **Evidence Level One:** Below 1.0 index (weighted average).
*   **Evidence Level Two:** Between 1.0 and 2.70 index.
*   **Evidence Level Three:** Above 2.70 index.

The combination of the student's country rating and the provider rating determines whether the student is eligible for streamlined evidentiary requirements ([b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing)). Generally, students from countries and attending providers with lower evidence levels are more likely to be eligible for streamlined processing, requiring less documentation upfront.

### The Genuine Student (GS) Requirement

The Genuine Temporary Entry (GTE) requirement, previously a key measure in determining visa eligibility, was replaced by the Genuine Student (GS) requirement on March 23, 2024 ([b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements)). This change aimed to streamline the application process and enhance immigration integrity. The GS requirement involves answering targeted questions to provide visa decision-makers with clearer insights into applicants' intentions and circumstances ([b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements)). While the GS requirement focuses on the applicant's genuine intention to study, the evidentiary framework and risk-based assessment based on country and provider ratings remain crucial in determining the level of scrutiny applied to the application.

### Financial Capacity and English Language Proficiency

While evidence of finances and English proficiency is not always required upfront, the DHA retains the right to request this evidence from any student if there is specific intelligence suggesting a potential issue with their financial capacity ([b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements)). This highlights the importance of being prepared to provide this evidence if requested, even if the student is initially assessed as eligible for streamlined processing.

To demonstrate financial capacity, students can provide evidence of:

*   Money deposit with a financial institution (bank).
*   Loan with a financial institution (bank).
*   Government loans.
*   Scholarship ([b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements)).

There are three options to provide financial evidence ([b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements)):

1.  **12 months living expenses:** Evidence of funds for travel costs plus 12 months of living and tuition costs. As of 2024, the minimum funds required are AUD$29,710 for a single student, AUD$10,394 for a spouse or de-facto partner, and AUD$4,449 per dependent child ([b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements)).
2.  **Annual income of parents:** Evidence that the annual income of the student’s parents (combined if necessary) or spouse exceeds AUD$87,856 per year. If one or more members of the applicant’s family unit are seeking to satisfy the secondary criteria, they will need to demonstrate an income of AUD$102,500 per year ([b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements)).
3.  **Secondary exchange students only:** A completed Acceptable Advice for Secondary Exchange Student (AASES) Form ([b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements)).

### Integrity Concerns and Visa Refusals

The DHA identifies several integrity concerns that can lead to student visa refusals ([b8-4-examples-of-integrity-concerns-for-dha.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-4-examples-of-integrity-concerns-for-dha)). These include:

*   **English language skills:** Providing fraudulent English test results or lacking the necessary English proficiency ([b8-4-examples-of-integrity-concerns-for-dha.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-4-examples-of-integrity-concerns-for-dha)).
*   **Genuine student/temporary entrant:** Failing to demonstrate a genuine intention to study and a realistic prospect of returning home after completing studies ([b8-4-examples-of-integrity-concerns-for-dha.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-4-examples-of-integrity-concerns-for-dha)).
*   **Family background and financial support:** Providing false information about family income or lacking sufficient funds to support studies in Australia ([b8-4-examples-of-integrity-concerns-for-dha.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-4-examples-of-integrity-concerns-for-dha)).
*   **Document fraud:** Submitting fraudulent documents to support the visa application ([b8-4-examples-of-integrity-concerns-for-dha.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-4-examples-of-integrity-concerns-for-dha)).

These examples highlight the importance of providing accurate and genuine information in the visa application. The DHA conducts integrity checks and may request interviews to verify the information provided ([b8-4-examples-of-integrity-concerns-for-dha.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-4-examples-of-integrity-concerns-for-dha)).

### Conclusion

In conclusion, the DHA considers evidentiary requirements for students from different countries primarily based on statistical evidence of how students from that country comply with their visa conditions. This risk-based approach, implemented through the SSVF, aims to streamline the visa process for genuine students while mitigating immigration risks. The DHA uses a weighted average of several indicators, including visa cancellations, fraud rates, refusal rates, unlawful non-citizen rates, and protection visa application rates, to determine the evidence level rating for each country and provider. While the GS requirement focuses on the applicant's genuine intention to study, the evidentiary framework remains crucial in determining the level of scrutiny applied to the application. Students should be aware of these requirements and prepared to provide accurate and genuine information to support their visa application.

question_results.question:
A student you recruited to study in Australia is studying a Bachelor of Engineering at university on a Student Visa. The student is finding their study program very difficult and would like to study part- time rather than full-time. The student can:

Answer options:
Study part-time under The National Code as it allows students to study part-time in exceptional circumstances.
Not change to part-time study. Under The National Code students on student visa are not allowed to study part-time.
Study part-time if the Vice-Chancellor of the university approves their study plan.
Not study part-time because the Vice-Chancellor of their university does not allow students to study part-time.
correct_answers: Not change to part-time study. Under The National Code students on student visa are not allowed to study part-time.
extracted_answers: Study part-time if the Vice-Chancellor of the university approves their study plan.
question_results.full_response:
Here's a detailed report addressing the student's query, adhering to the specified guidelines:### Report: International Student's Eligibility for Part-Time Study in Australia

**Introduction**
This report addresses the scenario of an international student enrolled in a Bachelor of Engineering program in Australia on a Student Visa (subclass 500) who wishes to change from full-time to part-time study. It examines the relevant regulations, policies, and potential implications under the National Code of Practice for Providers of Education and Training to Overseas Students 2018 (National Code) and other relevant legislative frameworks.

**Overview of Student Visa Requirements**
To study in Australia, international students typically need to obtain a student visa (subclass 500) ([The University of Western Australia, 2024](https://www.uwa.edu.au/study/international-students/moving-to-perth/student-visas)). This visa has specific conditions that students must adhere to throughout their stay. One of the primary conditions is maintaining enrollment in a full-time registered course ([B9-1-visa-conditions.md](None)).

**Full-Time Study Load Requirements**
A standard full-time study load at Australian universities typically involves enrolling in a specified number of credit points per semester or academic year. For instance, at the University of Western Australia, a full-time load is 24 credit points per semester or 48 credit points per academic year ([The University of Western Australia, 2024](https://www.uwa.edu.au/study/international-students/moving-to-perth/student-visas)). Similarly, at UNSW Sydney, international students are generally required to enroll in 48 units of credit (UOC) per year, with at least 12 UOC per term ([UNSW Sydney, n.d.](https://www.unsw.edu.au/student/managing-your-studies/essentials/visa-requirements/change-your-study-situation/reducing-your-study-load)). At the University of Melbourne, full-time enrollment requires at least 37.5 points (3 standard subjects) per half-year period, though student visa holders are typically required to enroll in 50 points each half-year period ([University of Melbourne, n.d.](https://ask.unimelb.edu.au/faq/1018/)).

**The National Code of Practice 2018**
The National Code of Practice for Providers of Education and Training to Overseas Students 2018 (National Code) sets nationally consistent standards for education providers to deliver quality education and training to overseas students ([Department of Education, Australian Government, n.d.a](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework/national-code-practice-providers-education-and-training-overseas-students-2018)). It is a legislative instrument under the Education Services for Overseas Students Act 2000 (ESOS Act) ([Department of Education, Australian Government, n.d.a](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework/national-code-practice-providers-education-and-training-overseas-students-2018)). Compliance with the National Code is mandatory for education providers to maintain their registration to provide education services to international students ([Department of Education, Australian Government, n.d.a](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework/national-code-practice-providers-education-and-training-overseas-students-2018)).

**Visa Condition 8202: Maintaining Enrolment**
Visa condition 8202 mandates that students must maintain enrollment in a full-time registered course at the same or higher Australian Qualification Framework (AQF) level as the course for which the visa was granted ([B9-1-visa-conditions.md](None)). Transferring to a lower AQF level course or a non-AQF award course is a breach of the student visa condition and may result in visa cancellation ([B1-overview.md](None)).

**Possibility of Reducing Study Load**
While full-time study is generally required, there are specific circumstances under which an international student may be allowed to reduce their study load. Universities may approve a reduced study load if the student can demonstrate specific compassionate or compelling reasons ([The University of Sydney, n.d.](https://www.sydney.edu.au/students/reduced-study-load.html)).

**Compassionate or Compelling Circumstances**
Compassionate or compelling circumstances typically involve situations that are beyond the student's control and have a significant impact on their ability to study full-time. Examples include:
*   Serious illness or injury ([UNSW Sydney, n.d.](https://www.unsw.edu.au/student/managing-your-studies/essentials/visa-requirements/change-your-study-situation/reducing-your-study-load)).
*   Death of a close family member ([UNSW Sydney, n.d.](https://www.unsw.edu.au/student/managing-your-studies/essentials/visa-requirements/change-your-study-situation/reducing-your-study-load)).
*   Political upheaval or natural disaster in the student's home country ([B7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications.md](None)).
*   Significant emotional or psychological difficulties ([UNSW Sydney, n.d.](https://www.unsw.edu.au/student/managing-your-studies/essentials/visa-requirements/change-your-study-situation/reducing-your-study-load)).

**University Approval Process**
To reduce their study load, the student must apply to their university, providing documented evidence of the compassionate or compelling circumstances ([UNSW Sydney, n.d.](https://www.unsw.edu.au/student/managing-your-studies/essentials/visa-requirements/change-your-study-situation/reducing-your-study-load)). The university will assess the application based on its policies and procedures. If approved, the university will notify the Department of Home Affairs (DHA) of the reduced study load ([C3-2-after-arriving-in-australia.md](None)).

**Implications for the Student Visa**
Reducing the study load may have implications for the student visa. The National Code requires international student visa holders to complete their program within the time specified on their Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE) ([UNSW Sydney, n.d.](https://www.unsw.edu.au/student/managing-your-studies/essentials/visa-requirements/change-your-study-situation/reducing-your-study-load)). If reducing the study load lengthens the time it takes to complete the program, the student may need to extend their CoE and student visa ([UNSW Sydney, n.d.](https://www.unsw.edu.au/student/managing-your-studies/essentials/visa-requirements/change-your-study-situation/reducing-your-study-load)). There will be additional costs associated with extending the student visa, such as administration fees, overseas student health cover, and medical assessment ([UNSW Sydney, n.d.](https://www.unsw.edu.au/student/managing-your-studies/essentials/visa-requirements/change-your-study-situation/reducing-your-study-load)).

**Potential Visa Cancellation**
If the student fails to maintain satisfactory course progress or does not comply with their visa conditions, their visa may be cancelled ([B9-1-visa-conditions.md](None)). Breaching visa conditions can also result in a three-year ban (exclusion period) on re-entry to Australia ([B9-1-visa-conditions.md](None)).

**Recent Changes to Student Visa Regulations**
In 2025, Australia has introduced stricter guidelines for student visa applicants to ensure they are genuine students ([VisaVerge.com, 2025](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/)). These changes include:
*   Capping international student enrollments at 270,000 to address resource allocation and housing shortages ([Pandey, 2025](https://www.moneycontrol.com/education/australia-student-visa-2025-all-you-need-to-know-about-new-visa-rules-and-updated-student-policies-article-12908700.html)).
*   Stricter adherence to Confirmation of Enrollment (CoE) requirements to enhance academic integrity and transparency ([Pandey, 2025](https://www.moneycontrol.com/education/australia-student-visa-2025-all-you-need-to-know-about-new-visa-rules-and-updated-student-policies-article-12908700.html)).
*   Revised financial proof requirements to ensure students can cover tuition fees, living costs, and accommodation expenses ([Pandey, 2025](https://www.moneycontrol.com/education/australia-student-visa-2025-all-you-need-to-know-about-new-visa-rules-and-updated-student-policies-article-12908700.html)).
*   Limiting work hours for international students to 48 per fortnight to balance academic focus and financial independence ([Pandey, 2025](https://www.moneycontrol.com/education/australia-student-visa-2025-all-you-need-to-know-about-new-visa-rules-and-updated-student-policies-article-12908700.html)).
*   Restricting onshore applications for student visas from temporary visa holders unless they meet all requirements, including holding a CoE ([VisaVerge.com, 2025](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/)).

**Advice for the Student**
Based on the information available, the student should:
1.  **Consult with the University:** The student should immediately consult with their university's international student support services or academic advisors to discuss their difficulties and explore options for reducing their study load ([UNSW Sydney, n.d.](https://www.unsw.edu.au/student/managing-your-studies/essentials/visa-requirements/change-your-study-situation/reducing-your-study-load)).
2.  **Gather Evidence:** The student should gather documented evidence of the reasons they are finding the program difficult. This may include medical certificates, counseling reports, or other relevant documents ([UNSW Sydney, n.d.](https://www.unsw.edu.au/student/managing-your-studies/essentials/visa-requirements/change-your-study-situation/reducing-your-study-load)).
3.  **Apply for Reduced Study Load:** If the university advises that the student's circumstances meet the criteria for compassionate or compelling reasons, the student should formally apply for a reduced study load, following the university's procedures ([UNSW Sydney, n.d.](https://www.unsw.edu.au/student/managing-your-studies/essentials/visa-requirements/change-your-study-situation/reducing-your-study-load)).
4.  **Understand the Implications:** The student should fully understand the implications of reducing their study load, including the potential need to extend their CoE and student visa, and the associated costs ([UNSW Sydney, n.d.](https://www.unsw.edu.au/student/managing-your-studies/essentials/visa-requirements/change-your-study-situation/reducing-your-study-load)).
5.  **Maintain Compliance:** The student must continue to comply with all other visa conditions, such as maintaining adequate health insurance and informing the university of their current address ([B9-1-visa-conditions.md](None)).

**Conclusion**
While the National Code generally requires international students to study full-time, it does allow for reduced study loads in specific, documented compassionate or compelling circumstances. The decision to approve a reduced study load rests with the university, and the student must follow the university's procedures and provide sufficient evidence to support their request. The student should be aware of the potential implications for their student visa and take steps to maintain compliance with all visa conditions. Therefore, the most accurate answer is that the student may be able to study part-time if the university approves their reduced study load request based on compelling circumstances.**References**

*   B1-overview.md. (n.d.). *Education Agent Training Course*.
*   B7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications.md. (n.d.). *Education Agent Training Course*.
*   B9-1-visa-conditions.md. (n.d.). *Education Agent Training Course*.
*   C3-2-after-arriving-in-australia.md. (n.d.). *Education Agent Training Course*.
*   Department of Education, Australian Government. (n.d.a). *National Code of Practice for Providers of Education and Training to Overseas Students 2018*. [https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework/national-code-practice-providers-education-and-training-overseas-students-2018](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework/national-code-practice-providers-education-and-training-overseas-students-2018)
*   Pandey, R. (2025, January 13). *Australia Student Visa 2025: All you need to know about new visa rules and updated student policies*. Moneycontrol. [https://www.moneycontrol.com/education/australia-student-visa-2025-all-you-need-to-know-about-new-visa-rules-and-updated-student-policies-article-12908700.html](https://www.moneycontrol.com/education/australia-student-visa-2025-all-you-need-to-know-about-new-visa-rules-and-updated-student-policies-article-12908700.html)
*   The University of Sydney. (n.d.). *Reduced study load (student visa holders)*. [https://www.sydney.edu.au/students/reduced-study-load.html](https://www.sydney.edu.au/students/reduced-study-load.html)
*   The University of Western Australia. (2024). *Student visas*. [https://www.uwa.edu.au/study/international-students/moving-to-perth/student-visas](https://www.uwa.edu.au/study/international-students/moving-to-perth/student-visas)
*   UNSW Sydney. (n.d.). *Reducing your study load as an international student*. [https://www.unsw.edu.au/student/managing-your-studies/essentials/visa-requirements/change-your-study-situation/reducing-your-study-load](https://www.unsw.edu.au/student/managing-your-studies/essentials/visa-requirements/change-your-study-situation/reducing-your-study-load)
*   University of Melbourne. (n.d.). *Full Time/Part Time*. [https://ask.unimelb.edu.au/faq/1018/](https://ask.unimelb.edu.au/faq/1018/)

[https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/)

question_results.question:
You recruited a student to study in a Foundation Year Program. The student has not been attending classes. The student is on a student visa and has been absent from class for two weeks now. The Institution should:

Answer options:
Let the student do what they want as they are in Australia and away from their parents.
Send an email to all agents telling them that the student you recruited is a very bad one.
Contact you immediately and ask for help in locating the student.
Report the student without seeking to find out where the student is.
correct_answers: Contact you immediately and ask for help in locating the student.
extracted_answers: Contact you immediately and ask for help in locating the student.
question_results.full_response:
Here's a detailed report addressing the scenario of a student visa holder in a Foundation Year Program with attendance issues, focusing on the institution's responsibilities and actions.

### Report: Institutional Response to Student Visa Holder Attendance Issues

**Introduction**

This report addresses the scenario where an international student, recruited into a Foundation Year Program, exhibits poor attendance. Given the student's status as a student visa holder, the educational institution has specific obligations and procedures to follow. This report will outline the appropriate steps the institution should take, emphasizing compliance with Australian regulations and ethical responsibilities. The analysis considers relevant information from provided documents and external web sources to provide a comprehensive recommendation.

**Scenario Overview**

An education agent has recruited a student to enroll in a Foundation Year Program in Australia. The student is on a student visa but has been absent from classes for two weeks. The central question is: What action should the institution take?

**Analysis of Available Options**

Let's evaluate the options provided:

1.  **Let the student do what they want as they are in Australia and away from their parents:** This option is unacceptable. Educational institutions have a duty of care towards their students, particularly international students on visas. Ignoring attendance issues would violate visa conditions and institutional responsibilities ([b9-1-visa-conditions.md](b9-1-visa-conditions.md)).

2.  **Send an email to all agents telling them that the student you recruited is a very bad one:** This option is unprofessional and potentially defamatory. It does not address the core issue of the student's non-attendance and could damage the institution's relationship with its agents ([d2-2-professional-standards.md](d2-2-professional-standards.md)).

3.  **Contact you immediately and ask for help in locating the student:** While involving the agent might be a part of the process, it should not be the immediate or sole action. The institution has primary responsibility for student welfare and visa compliance ([c4-2-people.md](c4-2-people.md)).

4.  **Report the student without seeking to find out where the student is:** This option is premature. Reporting the student to the Department of Home Affairs (DHA) should be a last resort, taken after reasonable attempts to contact the student and address the attendance issue ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md)).

**Recommended Institutional Response**

Based on the provided information and current regulations, the institution should follow a structured approach:

1.  **Initial Contact and Investigation:**
    *   The institution should attempt to contact the student through all available channels (email, phone, etc.) to inquire about the reason for their absence.
    *   Check the student's provided emergency contact information and attempt to reach out to them to gather more information ([kangarooedu.au](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025/)).
    *   Review the student's attendance record and academic progress to identify any patterns or underlying issues.

2.  **Formal Notification and Counseling:**
    *   If initial contact attempts are unsuccessful or the student's explanation is unsatisfactory, the institution should issue a formal written notification to the student. This notification should:
        *   Clearly state the attendance requirements and the consequences of non-compliance.
        *   Offer the student an opportunity to explain their absence and provide supporting documentation (e.g., medical certificate).
        *   Inform the student of available support services, such as counseling, academic advising, and health services ([c4-2-people.md](c4-2-people.md), [overseasstudentsaustralia.com](https://overseasstudentsaustralia.com/support-services-for-international-students-in-australia/)).
    *   Provide a timeline for the student to respond and rectify the situation.

3.  **Intervention and Support:**
    *   Offer the student a meeting with an international student advisor or counselor to discuss their situation and develop a plan for improvement ([c4-2-people.md](c4-2-people.md)).
    *   Explore potential reasons for the student's absence, such as:
        *   Academic difficulties: Offer tutoring or learning support services ([c4-2-people.md](c4-2-people.md), [overseasstudentsaustralia.com](https://overseasstudentsaustralia.com/support-services-for-international-students-in-australia/)).
        *   Personal or health issues: Refer the student to appropriate counseling or health services ([c4-2-people.md](c4-2-people.md), [overseasstudentsaustralia.com](https://overseasstudentsaustralia.com/support-services-for-international-students-in-australia/)).
        *   Cultural adjustment problems: Provide cultural awareness workshops or peer support programs ([c4-2-people.md](c4-2-people.md), [overseasstudentsaustralia.com](https://overseasstudentsaustralia.com/support-services-for-international-students-in-australia/)).
        *   Financial difficulties: Offer information on financial aid or support services ([c4-2-people.md](c4-2-people.md), [overseasstudentsaustralia.com](https://overseasstudentsaustralia.com/support-services-for-international-students-in-australia/)).

4.  **Compliance with Visa Condition 8202:**
    *   Ensure the student is aware of Visa Condition 8202, which requires them to maintain satisfactory attendance and course progress ([b9-1-visa-conditions.md](b9-1-visa-conditions.md)).
    *   Document all communication and interventions with the student.

5.  **Reporting to DHA (Department of Home Affairs):**
    *   If the student fails to respond to the formal notification, does not provide a satisfactory explanation, or does not improve their attendance after intervention, the institution must consider reporting the student to DHA via PRISMS (Provider Registration and International Student Management System) ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md)).
    *   Before reporting, ensure that the institution has followed its documented policies and procedures for monitoring course progress and attendance ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md)).
    *   Issue a written notification of the intention to report the student to DHA, informing the student of their right to access the provider’s complaints and appeals process within 20 working days ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md)).
    *   Only report the student after the timeframe has lapsed or the appeals process has been finalized in favor of the provider ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md)).

6.  **Agent Involvement (Cautious Approach):**
    *   Once the institution has made reasonable attempts to contact the student and has followed its internal procedures, it may be appropriate to contact the education agent.
    *   The agent may have additional contact information or insights into the student's situation.
    *   However, maintain student privacy and only share information that is necessary and compliant with privacy laws ([b10-2-when-is-privacy-a-concern.md](b10-2-when-is-privacy-a-concern.md)).

**Legal and Regulatory Context**

*   **National Code 2018:** Standard 8 of the National Code emphasizes the need for registered providers to safeguard the integrity of Australia’s migration laws by supporting overseas students to complete their course and fulfill their visa requirements ([b4-1-national-code-standards.md](b4-1-national-code-standards.md)).
*   **ESOS Act:** The Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Act 2000 sets out the legal framework for the regulation of education providers offering courses to overseas students ([d4-extension-emerging-bad-practice.md](d4-extension-emerging-bad-practice.md)).
*   **Visa Condition 8202:** This condition mandates that students maintain enrolment in a registered course, satisfy attendance requirements, and make satisfactory course progress ([b9-1-visa-conditions.md](b9-1-visa-conditions.md)).
*   **PRISMS:** The Provider Registration and International Student Management System (PRISMS) is the database used by education providers to report information about international students to DHA ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md)).

**Impact of 2025 Visa Rule Updates**

Several updates to the student visa rules in 2025 further emphasize the need for institutions to monitor and report student attendance and progress:

*   **Genuine Student Requirement (GS):** Replacing the Genuine Temporary Entrant (GTE) requirement, the GS assesses the applicant’s intention to study in Australia, making it crucial for institutions to ensure students are genuinely engaged in their studies ([kangarooedu.au](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025/)).
*   **Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE):** As of January 1, 2025, a CoE is mandatory for all visa applications, reinforcing the importance of institutions verifying and maintaining accurate enrolment records ([visaverge.com](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/)).
*   **Attendance Monitoring:** Strict attendance monitoring is required, with institutions expected to report attendance every study period and issue warnings at 90% and 85% attendance levels ([kangarooedu.au](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025/)). Visa cancellation may occur if attendance falls below 80%.
*   **Work Rights:** Limited work rights during term time (up to 48 hours per fortnight) emphasize the primary purpose of the student's stay is study, reinforcing the need for institutions to monitor academic engagement ([kangarooedu.au](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025/)).

**Consequences of Non-Compliance**

Failure to comply with reporting requirements can have severe consequences for the institution, including:

*   **Fines:** Institutions may be fined for failing to report student breaches of visa conditions ([cpdimmigration.com](https://cpdimmigration.com/explained-reporting-international-student-no-shows-in-the-big-four/)).
*   **Suspension:** The institution's ability to enroll international students may be suspended ([cpdimmigration.com](https://cpdimmigration.com/explained-reporting-international-student-no-shows-in-the-big-four/)).
*   **Revocation of Registration:** The institution's registration as a provider of education services to overseas students may be revoked ([cpdimmigration.com](https://cpdimmigration.com/explained-reporting-international-student-no-shows-in-the-big-four/)).

**Support Services for International Students**

Institutions should ensure that international students are aware of and have access to a range of support services, including:

*   **Academic Support:** Learning and teaching centers, peer-assisted study sessions, online learning resources, and academic skills advisors ([overseasstudentsaustralia.com](https://overseasstudentsaustralia.com/support-services-for-international-students-in-australia/)).
*   **Counseling and Mental Health Services:** Support for relationships, crisis intervention, mental health, and suicide prevention ([ozstudies.com](https://www.ozstudies.com/studying-in-australia/why-study-in-australia/support-services-for-international-students)).
*   **International Student Advisors:** Providing advice on settling into accommodation, cultural adjustment, academic progress, and visa compliance ([c4-2-people.md](c4-2-people.md)).
*   **Accommodation Officers:** Assisting in securing accommodation for newly arrived students ([c2-4-roles-international-student-support.md](c2-4-roles-international-student-support.md)).

**Conclusion**

In the case of a student visa holder with poor attendance, the institution must act responsibly and in accordance with Australian regulations. The recommended approach involves initial contact and investigation, formal notification and counseling, intervention and support, compliance with visa conditions, and, as a last resort, reporting to DHA. Involving the agent should be done cautiously and with consideration for student privacy. By following these steps, the institution can fulfill its duty of care, maintain its compliance obligations, and support the student in achieving their academic goals.

question_results.full_response:
## Student Visa Requirements for Under-18 Students in Australia: A Comprehensive Report

The Australian Department of Home Affairs (DHA) has specific requirements for international students under the age of 18 who wish to study in Australia. These requirements are in place to ensure the safety and well-being of these students, as they are considered minors under Australian law ([B8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18/)). One of the key aspects of these requirements is related to accommodation and welfare arrangements. This report will analyze the accommodation options available to a 17-year-old student seeking to study in Australia, based on the provided information.

**The Correct Accommodation Option**

Based on the information provided, the correct answer is: Live with a relative over 21, their parent or guardian or in accommodation approved by the education provider.

**Rationale**

The Australian government mandates that international students under 18 years of age must have adequate welfare arrangements in place for the duration of their visa or until they turn 18 ([B8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18/)). These arrangements can take one of the following forms:

1.  **Living with a Parent or Legal Custodian:** The student can live in Australia with a parent or legal custodian who holds a valid visa that allows them to remain in Australia until the student turns 18 ([B8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18/), [Student.unsw.edu.au](https://www.student.unsw.edu.au/parents-or-custodians-under-18-years-students)). The parent or legal custodian may need to apply for a Student Guardian visa (subclass 590) ([B1-overview.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b1-overview/), [B2-4-the-migration-act-1958.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b2-4-the-migration-act-1958/)).

2.  **Living with a Relative:** The student can live with a relative who meets specific criteria. The relative must:

    *   Be a brother, sister, step-brother, step-sister, grandparent, aunt, uncle, niece, nephew, step-grandparent, step-aunt, step-uncle, step-niece, or step-nephew ([B8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18/)).
    *   Be aged over 21 years ([B8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18/), [Insiderguides.com.au](https://insiderguides.com.au/international-students-under-18-australia-accommodation/)).
    *   Have the right to remain in Australia until the visa expires or the student turns 18, whichever happens first ([B8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18/)).
    *   Have a police clearance check ([B8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18/)).

3.  **Education Provider Approved Accommodation:** If the student is not living with a parent, legal custodian, or suitable relative, the education provider must provide for their general welfare and accommodation ([B8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18/)). The provider will issue a Confirmation of Adequate Accommodation and Welfare (CAAW) letter ([B8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18/)).

**Why the Other Options are Incorrect**

*   **Live with a relative over 18, their parent or guardian or in accommodation approved by the education provider:** This is incorrect because relatives must be over 21 years of age to be considered suitable guardians ([B8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18/)).
*   **Live with a person over 21 years of age who has no criminal records or in accommodation approved by the education provider:** This is incorrect because the person must be a relative, parent, or legal custodian. While having no criminal record is a requirement for relatives, it is not sufficient on its own ([B8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18/)).
*   **Live where ever and with whomever they would like as the student is almost 18 and is living away from their home country:** This is incorrect because students under 18 are legally considered minors and require approved welfare arrangements ([Insiderguides.com.au](https://insiderguides.com.au/international-students-under-18-australia-accommodation/)).

**Further Considerations for Under-18 Students**

*   **Form 1229:** The student's parents or custodian must complete Form 1229 – Consent to grant an Australian visa to a child under the age of 18 years ([B8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18/), [Immi.homeaffairs.gov.au](https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-listing/student-500/welfare-arrangements-students-under-18)).
*   **CAAW Letter:** If the education provider is responsible for the student's welfare, the CAAW letter must nominate two dates: when the provider begins taking responsibility and when they cease to take responsibility ([B8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18/)). The minimum period on the CAAW letter must be the same as the Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE) plus 7 days or until the student turns 18 ([Immi.homeaffairs.gov.au](https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-listing/student-500/welfare-arrangements-students-under-18)).
*   **Changing Welfare Arrangements:** Students cannot change their welfare arrangements without written approval from their education provider ([Immi.homeaffairs.gov.au](https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-listing/student-500/welfare-arrangements-students-under-18)).
*   **Temporary Absences:** Students are required to reside at the address of their approved accommodation provider at all times and cannot stay overnight at any other address without prior approval from the University of Sydney ([Sydney.edu.au](https://www.sydney.edu.au/study/applying/apply-for-a-visa/under-18-international-student-visa-holder.html)).
*   **Financial Capacity:** All applicants for a Student Guardian visa must have sufficient funds to support themselves, the nominating student(s), and any secondary applicants for the duration of their intended stay in Australia ([B8-3-specific-requirements-in-particular-cases.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-3-specific-requirements-in-particular-cases/)). Evidence of financial capacity can be provided through evidence of annual income of $70,000 or more, or evidence of sufficient funds to cover travel costs and the first 12 months of living costs ([B8-3-specific-requirements-in-particular-cases.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-3-specific-requirements-in-particular-cases/)).

**Accommodation Options Approved by Education Providers**

If the student's education provider is responsible for their accommodation and welfare, several options are available:

*   **Homestay:** This involves living with an Australian family in their home ([A4-4-entry-points-typical-costs-and-accommodation-options.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/a4-4-entry-points-typical-costs-and-accommodation-options/), [C3-2-after-arriving-in-australia.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/c3-2-after-arriving-in-australia/), [C5-7-accommodation-options.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/c5-7-accommodation-options/), [Studyaustralia.gov.au](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en_in/life-in-australia/accommodation)). Homestay is popular with younger students and those studying short-term English courses ([A4-4-entry-points-typical-costs-and-accommodation-options.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/a4-4-entry-points-typical-costs-and-accommodation-options/), [C5-7-accommodation-options.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/c5-7-accommodation-options/)). Meals are usually included in the cost, and single or shared rooms may be offered ([A4-4-entry-points-typical-costs-and-accommodation-options.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/a4-4-entry-points-typical-costs-and-accommodation-options/)). Education providers must ensure that homestay families are reputable and offer good accommodation ([A4-4-entry-points-typical-costs-and-accommodation-options.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/a4-4-entry-points-typical-costs-and-accommodation-options/), [C5-7-accommodation-options.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/c5-7-accommodation-options/)). Several organizations can assist with homestay arrangements, including Australian Homestay Network, Global Experience, and Homestay Australia ([Neas.org.au](https://neas.org.au/homestay/), [Studyaustralia.gov.au](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en_in/life-in-australia/accommodation)).
*   **Managed Student Accommodation:** These are purpose-built buildings that are well-located and offer various room options, from solo studio apartments to multi-bedroom duplexes ([Insiderguides.com.au](https://insiderguides.com.au/international-students-under-18-australia-accommodation/)).
*   **Boarding Schools:** Many private secondary schools provide accommodation, meals, and laundry services for international students ([C5-7-accommodation-options.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/c5-7-accommodation-options/)).
*   **University Apartments, Colleges, and Halls of Residence:** These options are also available, but the cost can vary ([C5-7-accommodation-options.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/c5-7-accommodation-options/)).

**Obligations of Education Providers**

Registered providers of overseas students aged under 18 must meet legislative or other regulatory requirements relating to child welfare and protection ([B4-1-national-code-standards.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b4-1-national-code-standards/)). They must provide students with emergency contact information and information about how to report actual or alleged abuse ([B4-1-national-code-standards.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b4-1-national-code-standards/)). Where the registered provider has taken on responsibility for the approval of welfare arrangements, they must ensure the arrangements are suitable, ongoing, and appropriately managed until the student turns 18 ([B4-1-national-code-standards.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b4-1-national-code-standards/)).

**Consequences of Non-Compliance**

It is essential that students comply with their visa conditions. If a student does not comply, their visa may be cancelled, and they may need to return home ([B9-1-visa-conditions.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-1-visa-conditions/)). There is also a three-year ban (exclusion period) on re-entry to Australia if a visa is cancelled for breaching visa conditions ([B9-1-visa-conditions.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-1-visa-conditions/)).

**Conclusion**

In conclusion, a 17-year-old student wishing to study in Australia must live with a parent or legal custodian, a relative over 21 who meets the specified criteria, or in accommodation approved by their education provider. The Australian government has strict requirements in place to ensure the safety and well-being of international students under 18, and it is crucial that students and their families understand and comply with these requirements. Failure to do so can result in visa cancellation and a ban on re-entry to Australia.

***

**References**
