question_results.full_response:
## Student Visa Conditions and the AQF: A Comprehensive Report

### Introduction

The Australian student visa program is designed to facilitate international students pursuing education within the country. However, obtaining a visa is only the first step. Maintaining compliance with visa conditions is crucial for the duration of their stay. This report aims to clarify the specific requirements for students who have been granted a student visa under streamlined arrangements, particularly concerning course levels within the Australian Qualifications Framework (AQF). The central question addressed is whether a student who gained a student visa under streamlined arrangements must remain in an AQF course of the same or higher level, or if they may need to apply for a new student visa. This report will delve into the relevant regulations, conditions, and potential implications for international students.

### Overview of Student Visa Requirements

To understand the obligations of students under streamlined arrangements, it is essential to first outline the general requirements for obtaining and maintaining a student visa. The Department of Home Affairs (DHA) mandates several criteria that applicants must meet, including acceptance into a full-time study program, demonstrating genuine temporary entrant status, fulfilling health and health insurance requirements, possessing good character, and having no debts to the Australian Government ([b7-student-visas-basic-requirements-and-processes.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b7-student-visas-basic-requirements-and-processes/)).

In addition to these basic requirements, students must also demonstrate appropriate English language skills and, if under 18, have acceptable arrangements for accommodation and welfare ([b7-student-visas-basic-requirements-and-processes.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b7-student-visas-basic-requirements-and-processes/)). These criteria ensure that students are well-prepared for their studies and can contribute positively to the Australian educational environment.

### Health Insurance Requirements

One of the critical conditions for student visa holders is maintaining adequate health insurance. The DHA requires evidence of Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC) to ensure that students are adequately insured throughout their stay ([b7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications/)). OSHC provides access to medical and hospital services, offering peace of mind and necessary coverage for healthcare needs ([unicreds.com](https://unicreds.com/blog/student-health-insurance-australia/)).

Students (and any accompanying family members) must have OSHC for the entire duration of their student visa, from the date of arrival in Australia to the visa's expiry date ([b7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications/)). Failure to maintain health insurance can result in visa cancellation ([b9-1-visa-conditions.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b9-1-visa-conditions/)).

### The Significance of the Australian Qualifications Framework (AQF)

The Australian Qualifications Framework (AQF) is a national framework that defines educational qualifications across various levels, from Certificate I to Doctoral Degree ([b1-overview.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b1-overview.md)). The AQF ensures consistency and comparability of qualifications across different institutions and sectors. For student visa holders, maintaining enrolment at the same or a higher AQF level is a critical visa condition ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions/)).

### Visa Condition 8202 and Course Level Maintenance

Visa condition 8202 explicitly states that students must maintain enrolment in a full-time registered course that provides a qualification at the same or higher level than the course for which the visa was granted ([b9-1-visa-conditions.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b9-1-visa-conditions/)). This condition is strictly enforced to ensure that students are genuinely pursuing educational goals and not using the student visa as a means to circumvent immigration laws.

Transferring to a lower AQF level course or from an AQF level course to a non-AQF award course is a breach of the student visa condition and might result in visa cancellation ([b1-overview.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b1-overview.md)). The DHA closely monitors students who change their course soon after arrival, make large changes in level (e.g., Bachelor to Certificate III), or switch to very different course types ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions/)).

### Exceptions to the AQF Level Requirement

There is one specific exception to the requirement of maintaining the same or higher AQF level. Students undertaking a doctoral degree (AQF 10) may transfer to a master’s degree (AQF 9) without breaching their visa conditions ([b1-overview.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b1-overview.md)). This exception recognizes the flexibility that doctoral students may need in their academic pursuits.

### Changing Courses and Institutions

If a student wants to change courses within the same institution but at the same AQF level, a new student visa is not required ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions/)). However, if the new course is longer than the original, the student must apply for a further student visa before their current visa expires.

If a student wishes to undertake a shorter course than that for which the visa was granted, they must either depart Australia within 28 days of completing the shorter course or notify DHA and apply for a new student visa if they wish to enrol in a further course of study ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions/)).

### Streamlined Visa Processing (SVP) and its Implications

The Simplified Student Visa Framework (SSVF) came into effect on 1 July 2016, streamlining the application process for international students ([b2-4-the-migration-act-1958.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b2-4-the-migration-act-1958/)). Under SSVF, international students apply for a single Student visa (subclass 500) regardless of their chosen course of study. The evidentiary requirements are determined by a combination of the student’s country of citizenship and the rating of the education provider ([b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing/)).

However, the Streamlined Visa Processing (SVP) regime has also led to some emerging issues. Some students and agents have been found to exploit the system by gaining student visas with no genuine intention of studying at the nominated institution. These students withdraw immediately upon arrival and transfer to cheaper institutions, often in different sectors ([d4-extension-emerging-bad-practice.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/d4-extension-emerging-bad-practice/)).

To combat this, the DHA closely monitors changes in course and institution, particularly those that occur soon after arrival ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions/)).

### Genuine Student (GS) Requirement

As of March 23, 2024, the Genuine Student (GS) requirement replaced the Genuine Temporary Entrant (GTE) requirement for student visas ([kangarooedu.au](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025/), [soledu.net](https://www.soledu.net/au/blog/genuine-student-requirement-explained/)). The GS requirement focuses on demonstrating a true interest and commitment to studying in Australia, rather than just temporary residency ([soledu.net](https://www.soledu.net/au/blog/genuine-student-requirement-explained/)).

The application now asks specific questions about the applicant's background, reasons for choosing Australia and the specific course, and future focus ([soledu.net](https://www.soledu.net/au/blog/genuine-student-requirement-explained/)). This ensures that students are genuinely motivated to pursue their studies and contribute to Australia's educational environment.

### Updated Visa Rules for 2025

Several updates to the student visa rules have been implemented in 2025 to strengthen the integrity of the international education sector ([provinceimmigration.com](https://provinceimmigration.com/blogs/updated-prioritisation-rules-for-australian-student-visas), [visaandimmigrations.com](https://visaandimmigrations.com/australias-new-student-visa-rules-for-2025-key-changes-and-what-you-need-to-know/)). These include requiring a Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE) at the time of application, increased financial requirements, updated English language proficiency standards, and stricter GS criteria ([avie.com.au](https://avie.com.au/student-visa-changes-2025/), [swecvisaconsultant.com](https://swecvisaconsultant.com/understanding-the-australian-student-visa-subclass-500/)).

A cap of 270,000 new international student commencements has also been introduced for 2025 to manage the growing number of international students ([a7-5-international-student-numbers.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/a7-5-international-student-numbers/), [visaandimmigrations.com](https://visaandimmigrations.com/australias-new-student-visa-rules-for-2025-key-changes-and-what-you-need-to-know/)). This cap aims to balance the expansion of Australia’s education sector with infrastructure and economic sustainability.

### Permanent Residency Pathways

While the primary intention of a student visa is to facilitate study, many international students aspire to gain permanent residency (PR) in Australia after completing their studies ([ivc-services.com](https://ivc-services.com/blog/permanent-residency-in-australia-with-student-visa), [visaverge.com](https://www.visaverge.com/questions/applying-for-permanent-residency-in-australia-on-a-student-visa-is-it-possible/)). Several pathways are available, including the Post-Study Work visa, Skilled Migration, Partner Visa, and Employer Nomination Scheme ([visaverge.com](https://www.visaverge.com/questions/applying-for-permanent-residency-in-australia-on-a-student-visa-is-it-possible/)).

The Post-Study Work stream of the Temporary Graduate visa (subclass 485) offers extended options for working in Australia to eligible graduates of a higher education degree ([c5-8-ability-to-work.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/c5-8-ability-to-work/)). Successful applicants are granted a visa of two, three, or four years duration, depending on the highest educational qualification they have obtained ([b9-4-visas-following-study.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/)).

### Conclusion

Based on the information presented, it is evident that a student who gained a student visa under streamlined arrangements **must remain in an AQF course of the same or higher level or they may need to apply for a new student visa**. Visa condition 8202 explicitly requires students to maintain enrolment at the same or higher AQF level, with limited exceptions. Failure to comply with this condition can lead to visa cancellation. The DHA closely monitors changes in course and institution, and the introduction of the Genuine Student (GS) requirement further reinforces the need for students to demonstrate a genuine commitment to their studies. While pathways to permanent residency exist, maintaining compliance with visa conditions is paramount for international students in Australia.

question_results.question:
A prospective student is going to visit some relatives in Australia for 2 months. While she is in Australia she thinks she may study English. Her tourist visa has the condition 8201 on it. You inform the student that this means:

Answer options:
She is not able to undertake any study while in Australia. She will have to change to a student visa to be able to do this.
She is not able to engage in any study or training for more than three months.
She must take a chest x-ray if she intends to study in a classroom environment for more than 4 weeks.
She can study only English studies while she is in Australia and not any other short training or study course.
correct_answers: She is not able to engage in any study or training for more than three months.
extracted_answers: She is not able to engage in any study or training for more than three months.
question_results.full_response:
## Understanding Visa Condition 8201 for Australian Tourist Visas: A Detailed Report

A prospective student planning a two-month visit to relatives in Australia is considering studying English while there. Her tourist visa includes condition 8201. This report aims to clarify the implications of this visa condition, providing a comprehensive understanding of its restrictions and available options.

**The Correct Interpretation of Visa Condition 8201**

Based on the provided information, the correct interpretation of visa condition 8201 is: **She is not able to engage in any study or training for more than three months**. This condition, commonly attached to visitor visas, explicitly limits the duration of study or training an individual can undertake while in Australia ([Korrylink Migration Consultants, n.d.](https://korrylink.com.au/tourist-visas/visitor-visa-conditions-and-waiver/); [Visitor-visa, 2024](https://www.visitor-visa.com.au/australian-tourist-visa-conditions/); [Visa Plan Lawyers, n.d.](https://visaplan.au/visitor-visa/tourist/)).

**In-Depth Analysis of Visa Condition 8201**Visa condition 8201 is a standard clause imposed on visitor visas (subclass 600) granted by the Australian Department of Home Affairs (DHA) ([Visitor-visa, 2024](https://www.visitor-visa.com.au/australian-tourist-visa-conditions/)). It directly addresses the extent to which individuals on tourist visas can participate in educational activities. The primary intention of a tourist visa is for tourism and recreational purposes, with any study undertaken being secondary to this main objective ([Studyau Ikatandinas, n.d.](https://studyau.ikatandinas.com/can-you-study-on-a-tourist-visa-in-australia/)).

**Permissible Study on a Tourist Visa**

The three-month limit allows visitors to engage in short courses or training programs that enhance their travel experience without shifting the visa's fundamental purpose ([Studyau Ikatandinas, n.d.](https://studyau.ikatandinas.com/can-you-study-on-a-tourist-visa-in-australia/)). Examples of permissible activities include:

*   **Short language courses:** A 10-week English Intensive Language Course for Overseas Students (ELICOS) is a common example ([Study Australia, n.d.](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/your-guide-to-visas/other-types-of-visas)).
*   **Recreational courses:** Cooking classes, photography workshops, or other short-term workshops are generally acceptable ([Studyau Ikatandinas, n.d.](https://studyau.ikatandinas.com/can-you-study-on-a-tourist-visa-in-australia/)).

**Restrictions and Limitations**

While some study is allowed, it's crucial to understand the limitations imposed by condition 8201:

*   **Duration:** The total duration of any study or training must not exceed three months ([Korrylink Migration Consultants, n.d.](https://korrylink.com.au/tourist-visas/visitor-visa-conditions-and-waiver/); [Visitor-visa, 2024](https://www.visitor-visa.com.au/australian-tourist-visa-conditions/); [Visa Plan Lawyers, n.d.](https://visaplan.au/visitor-visa/tourist/)).
*   **Purpose:** The primary purpose of the visit must remain tourism. Study should be a secondary activity ([Studyau Ikatandinas, n.d.](https://studyau.ikatandinas.com/can-you-study-on-a-tourist-visa-in-australia/)).
*   **Visa type:** The tourist visa is not intended for long-term study. Individuals planning to pursue a degree or longer course must apply for a student visa (subclass 500) ([Studyau Ikatandinas, n.d.](https://studyau.ikatandinas.com/can-you-study-on-a-tourist-visa-in-australia/)).

**Consequences of Non-Compliance**

Breaching visa conditions, including condition 8201, can have severe consequences:

*   **Visa cancellation:** The DHA can cancel the visa if the holder fails to comply with any of its conditions ([Crystal Migration, 2023](https://crystalmigration.com.au/2023/01/27/visa-conditions-and-cancellations/)).
*   **Deportation:** Individuals with cancelled visas may be required to leave Australia ([Studyau Ikatandinas, n.d.](https://studyau.ikatandinas.com/can-you-study-on-a-tourist-visa-in-australia/)).
*   **Future visa applications:** Breaching visa conditions can negatively impact future visa applications, potentially leading to refusal or exclusion periods ([B9-1-visa-conditions.md](b9-1-visa-conditions.md)).

**Alternative Visa Options for Extended Study**

If the prospective student intends to study English for longer than three months, she must apply for a student visa (subclass 500) ([Studyau Ikatandinas, n.d.](https://studyau.ikatandinas.com/can-you-study-on-a-tourist-visa-in-australia/)). This visa allows full-time study in Australia and offers additional benefits, such as the ability to work part-time ([Studyau Ikatandinas, n.d.](https://studyau.ikatandinas.com/can-you-study-on-a-tourist-visa-in-australia/)).

**Key Requirements for a Student Visa (Subclass 500)**

To obtain a student visa, the applicant must meet several requirements:

*   **Enrollment in a registered course:** The student must enroll in a full-time registered course with a CRICOS-registered provider ([B9-1-visa-conditions.md](b9-1-visa-conditions.md)).
*   **Genuine Temporary Entrant (GTE) requirement:** The applicant must demonstrate a genuine intention to stay in Australia temporarily for the purpose of study ([B7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications.md](b7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications.md)).
*   **English language proficiency:** The student must demonstrate adequate English language skills through approved tests like IELTS, TOEFL, or PTE Academic ([B7-student-visas-basic-requirements-and-processes.md](b7-student-visas-basic-requirements-and-processes.md)). As of July 1, 2024, a minimum score of 6.0 is required for most applicants ([B7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications.md](b7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications.md)).
*   **Financial capacity:** The student must provide evidence of sufficient funds to cover tuition fees, living expenses, and health insurance ([B9-1-visa-conditions.md](b9-1-visa-conditions.md)).
*   **Health insurance:** The student must maintain adequate health insurance (Overseas Student Health Cover - OSHC) during their stay in Australia ([B9-1-visa-conditions.md](b9-1-visa-conditions.md)).
*   **Character requirements:** The student must be of good character and not pose a risk to the Australian community ([B2-4-the-migration-act-1958.md](b2-4-the-migration-act-1958.md)).

**Recent Changes to Student Visa Regulations (2025)**

Several changes to Australian student visa regulations have been implemented in 2025, impacting prospective students:

*   **Certificate of Enrollment (CoE):** Obtaining a CoE from the educational institution is now a critical step in the application process ([VisaVerge, 2025](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/)).
*   **Increased application fee:** As of July 1, 2024, the base application fee for student visas increased to AUD $1,600 ([B7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications.md](b7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications.md); [VisaVerge, 2025](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/)).
*   **Restrictions on onshore applications:** Applying for a student visa from within Australia while holding a temporary visa, such as a visitor visa, has become more restricted. Applicants must meet all requirements, including holding a CoE, to be eligible for an onshore application ([VisaVerge, 2025](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/)).
*   **Cap on international student enrollments:** A National Planning Level (NPL) cap of 270,000 new international student commencements has been enforced for 2025 ([Visaandimmigrations, 2025](https://visaandimmigrations.com/australias-new-student-visa-rules-for-2025-key-changes-and-what-you-need-to-know/)).

**Recommendations for the Prospective Student**

Given the information and the student's intention to potentially study English in Australia, the following recommendations are provided:

1.  **Assess the duration of study:** Determine the length of the English course. If it exceeds three months, a student visa is necessary.
2.  **If study is less than 3 months:** The student can study while on a tourist visa, but the primary purpose of the visit must remain tourism.
3.  **If study is longer than 3 months:** Apply for a student visa (subclass 500) well in advance, considering the new CoE requirement and potential processing times.
4.  **Do not breach visa conditions:** Avoid engaging in unauthorized study, as it can lead to visa cancellation and future immigration issues.
5.  **Seek professional advice:** Consult with a registered migration agent for personalized guidance on visa options and requirements.

**Conclusion**

Visa condition 8201 allows for limited study on a tourist visa, but it's crucial to adhere to the three-month restriction. For extended English studies, a student visa is the appropriate pathway. Understanding the regulations and recent changes is essential for a smooth and compliant educational journey in Australia.

**References**

[B2-4-the-migration-act-1958.md](b2-4-the-migration-act-1958.md)[B7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications.md](b7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications.md)

[B7-student-visas-basic-requirements-and-processes.md](b7-student-visas-basic-requirements-and-processes.md)

[B9-1-visa-conditions.md](b9-1-visa-conditions.md)

Crystal Migration. (2023, January 27). *Visa conditions and cancellations*. [https://crystalmigration.com.au/2023/01/27/visa-conditions-and-cancellations/](https://crystalmigration.com.au/2023/01/27/visa-conditions-and-cancellations/)

Dingoos. (n.d.). *Study english in Australia: all you need to know*. [https://dingoos.com/en/australia-study-english/](https://dingoos.com/en/australia-study-english/)

Korrylink Migration Consultants. (n.d.). *Visitor visa conditions and waiver*. [https://korrylink.com.au/tourist-visas/visitor-visa-conditions-and-waiver/](https://korrylink.com.au/tourist-visas/visitor-visa-conditions-and-waiver/)

Study Australia. (n.d.). *Other types of visas*. [https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/your-guide-to-visas/other-types-of-visas](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/your-guide-to-visas/other-types-of-visas)

Studyau Ikatandinas. (n.d.). *Can you study on a tourist visa in Australia?* [https://studyau.ikatandinas.com/can-you-study-on-a-tourist-visa-in-australia/](https://studyau.ikatandinas.com/can-you-study-on-a-tourist-visa-in-australia/)

Visa Plan Lawyers. (n.d.). *Tourist visitor visa*. [https://visaplan.au/visitor-visa/tourist/](https://visaplan.au/visitor-visa/tourist/)

Visaandimmigrations. (2025, February 14). *Australia’s new student visa rules for 2025: Key changes and what you need to know*. [https://visaandimmigrations.com/australias-new-student-visa-rules-for-2025-key-changes-and-what-you-need-to-know/](https://visaandimmigrations.com/australias-new-student-visa-rules-for-2025-key-changes-and-what-you-need-to-know/)

VisaVerge. (2025, January 29). *Australia updates student visa rules for 2025 to ensure genuine applicants*. [https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/)

question_results.question:
The parents of a student you recruited to study in Australia call you. Their son is very ill and has been taken to hospital. He cannot attend classes and the parents are not sure what to do. You seek advice from your liaison at the student’s school regarding his attendance and then tell his parents:

Answer options:
Not to worry, as attendance is not recorded in Australian institutions.
To make sure their son gets a medical certificate from the doctor or hospital so that he can show this to the institution (and DHA if necessary) to prove he has been sick.
That he has a big problem as he is not allowed to miss any class for any reason.
correct_answers: To make sure their son gets a medical certificate from the doctor or hospital so that he can show this to the institution (and DHA if necessary) to prove he has been sick.
extracted_answers: To make sure their son gets a medical certificate from the doctor or hospital so that he can show this to the institution (and DHA if necessary) to prove he has been sick.
question_results.full_response:
## Report on Student Illness and Visa Compliance in Australia

The following report addresses the scenario of an international student in Australia who has fallen ill and been hospitalized, impacting their ability to attend classes. It provides guidance to an education agent on how to advise the student's parents, considering the student's visa conditions and the policies of Australian educational institutions. The report emphasizes the importance of obtaining medical documentation and communicating with the education provider to ensure compliance with visa requirements.

### Determining the Correct Advice

Based on the provided information, the most appropriate advice to give the parents is:

"To make sure their son gets a medical certificate from the doctor or hospital so that he can show this to the institution (and DHA if necessary) to prove he has been sick."

This advice is grounded in the following facts and considerations:

*   **Attendance Requirements:** Student visa holders are generally required to maintain satisfactory attendance, often at least 80% of scheduled classes ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md), [https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025/](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025/)). While universities may have different attendance policies, a sudden inability to attend classes due to illness needs to be properly documented.
*   **Visa Condition 8202:** This visa condition mandates that students satisfy their provider's requirements for attendance and course progress ([b9-1-visa-conditions.md](b9-1-visa-conditions.md)). Failure to do so can lead to the education provider reporting the student to the Department of Home Affairs (DHA), potentially resulting in visa cancellation.
*   **Compassionate and Compelling Circumstances:** Education providers typically have documented policies and procedures for considering compassionate and compelling circumstances that may affect a student's attendance ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md)). Serious illness definitely falls under this category.
*   **Medical Documentation:** Obtaining a medical certificate from a registered health professional is crucial for demonstrating a valid reason for non-attendance ([b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms.md](b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms.md)).
*   **Transparency with the Education Provider:** The student must keep the education provider informed of their current address and any changes in their circumstances ([b9-1-visa-conditions.md](b9-1-visa-conditions.md), [b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md)). This includes informing them of the illness and providing the medical certificate.
*   **Health Requirements:** The Australian Department of Home Affairs mandates a health check for international students applying for a visa to ensure public health safety within Australia ([https://ivc-services.com/blog/australia-student-visa-health-check](https://ivc-services.com/blog/australia-student-visa-health-check)).

### Why the Other Options Are Incorrect

*   **"Not to worry, as attendance is not recorded in Australian institutions."** This is incorrect and potentially damaging advice. Attendance is generally monitored, especially for courses with mandatory attendance requirements ([https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025/](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025/)).
*   **"That he has a big problem as he is not allowed to miss any class for any reason."** This is an overstatement. While attendance is important, institutions recognize that students may have legitimate reasons for missing classes, such as illness, and have procedures for addressing these situations ([https://policies.mq.edu.au/document/view.php?id=279](https://policies.mq.edu.au/document/view.php?id=279)).

### Detailed Explanation and Actionable Steps

1.  **Immediate Action:** The parents should focus on their son's health and ensure he receives the best possible medical care.

2.  **Medical Certificate:** Obtain a medical certificate from the treating doctor or hospital. The certificate should clearly state:

    *   The student's name and date of birth.
    *   The dates of hospitalization or the period during which the student is unable to attend classes.
    *   The nature of the illness (if possible, without breaching patient confidentiality).
    *   A statement that the illness prevents the student from attending classes.
    *   The doctor's name, registration number, and contact details.

3.  **Notify the Education Provider:** The student (or the parents, if the student is unable to) should immediately notify the education provider about the illness. This can be done by contacting the student support services, the course coordinator, or the international student advisor. The notification should include:

    *   The student's name and student ID number.
    *   The course in which the student is enrolled.
    *   The reason for absence (illness and hospitalization).
    *   The expected duration of absence.
    *   A copy of the medical certificate (or advise when it will be provided).
    *   Contact information for the student and/or parents.

4.  **Understand the Education Provider's Policy:** The education agent should contact their liaison at the student's school to understand the institution's specific policy on attendance and absences due to illness. This will help determine what documentation is required and what steps the student needs to take to ensure compliance.

5.  **Leave of Absence or Suspension of Studies:** Depending on the severity and expected duration of the illness, the student may need to apply for a leave of absence or a suspension of studies. Many universities have specific procedures for international students seeking to suspend their studies due to compassionate or compelling circumstances ([https://policies.mq.edu.au/document/view.php?id=279](https://policies.mq.edu.au/document/view.php?id=279)). The education provider can advise on the appropriate process.

6.  **Impact on Visa:** The education provider is obligated to report any significant changes in the student's enrolment status or attendance to the DHA ([b4-1-national-code-standards.md](b4-1-national-code-standards.md)). If the student's absence is prolonged and affects their ability to meet course requirements, the DHA may be notified. However, if the student has provided adequate documentation and is taking steps to address the situation, the impact on their visa should be minimal.

7.  **Health Insurance:** Ensure the student has adequate health insurance (Overseas Student Health Cover - OSHC) ([b7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications.md](b7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications.md)). The parents should confirm that the OSHC covers the student's medical expenses.

8.  **Agent's Role:** The education agent should:

    *   Provide accurate information and support to the student and their parents.
    *   Liaise with the education provider to understand their policies and procedures.
    *   Advise the student on their options and the potential impact on their visa.
    *   Respect the student's privacy and confidentiality ([b10-2-when-is-privacy-a-concern.md](b10-2-when-is-privacy-a-concern.md)).

### Potential Complications and Solutions

*   **Prolonged Illness:** If the student's illness is prolonged and they are unable to resume their studies within a reasonable timeframe, they may need to consider withdrawing from their course and returning home for treatment. In this case, they should seek advice from the education provider and the DHA regarding their visa options.
*   **Visa Cancellation:** If the DHA is not satisfied with the student's explanation for their absence, they may consider cancelling the visa. In this case, the student has the right to appeal the decision. The education agent can assist the student in finding legal representation if necessary.
*   **Financial Difficulties:** If the student's illness leads to financial difficulties, the education agent can refer them to student support services or other organizations that provide financial assistance.

### Changes to Student Visa Rules in 2025

It's important to be aware of the changes to student visa rules in 2025, which aim to ensure genuine applicants and improve the integrity of the visa system ([https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/)). These changes include:

*   **Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE):** A CoE is now mandatory for all student visa applications ([https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/)).
*   **Genuine Student Requirement (GS):** The Genuine Temporary Entrant (GTE) requirement has been replaced by the Genuine Student (GS) requirement, which assesses the applicant's intention to study in Australia ([https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025/](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025/)).
*   **Increased Financial Costs:** Students need to demonstrate sufficient financial resources to cover their tuition fees, living expenses, and travel costs ([https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025/](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025/)).

### Conclusion

In conclusion, when advising the parents of a student who is ill and unable to attend classes, the education agent should emphasize the importance of obtaining medical documentation, notifying the education provider, and understanding the institution's policies on attendance and absences. By taking these steps, the student can minimize the potential impact on their visa and focus on their recovery. The agent should also be aware of the changes to student visa rules in 2025 and provide accurate information to the student and their parents.

question_results.question:
One of the other counsellors in your office comes to ask your advice on the following situation:
A student will study in an ELICOS program for 6 months and then enter into a Masters of Biotechnology course. The student has paid her tuition fees and the Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC) for the ELICOS course. She wants to pay her tuition fees for the Masters course but the university is asking her to also pay OSHC. The counsellor is unsure about what the student should do about their OSHC for the Masters course.
You advise the counsellor that the student:

Answer options:
needs to take out OSHC for the Masters course too before applying for a student visa as it is compulsory for international students to have health insurance for all courses in a package of offers while studying in Australia.
should take out OSHC covering the Masters course too because it is always a better option to be covered just in case of an accident.
does not need to pay OSHC to cover the length of the other course. This is just another expense in an already expensive process.
correct_answers: needs to take out OSHC for the Masters course too before applying for a student visa as it is compulsory for international students to have health insurance for all courses in a package of offers while studying in Australia.
extracted_answers: needs to take out OSHC for the Masters course too before applying for a student visa as it is compulsory for international students to have health insurance for all courses in a package of offers while studying in Australia.
question_results.full_response:
## Report on Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC) Requirements for Packaged Courses**Introduction**

This report addresses the query regarding a student undertaking a packaged course comprising an English Language Intensive Course for Overseas Students (ELICOS) program followed by a Masters of Biotechnology course, and the necessity of Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC) for the latter. The report will analyze the relevant regulations and guidelines to provide a well-supported recommendation.

**Background**

The student in question is enrolled in a packaged course, beginning with a 6-month ELICOS program and progressing to a Masters of Biotechnology. She has already paid tuition fees and OSHC for the ELICOS program. The university is now requesting OSHC payment for the Masters course as well. The counsellor seeks advice on whether this additional OSHC payment is required.

**Analysis of OSHC Requirements**

Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC) is a mandatory requirement for international students holding a student visa (subclass 500) in Australia ([Edufirst Visa Consultancy](https://www.edufirstvisa.com/blog/everything-you-need-about-overseas-student-health-cover-oshc-in-australia)). It ensures that students have access to medical care during their stay in Australia without facing financial hardship ([Study in Australia](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/overseas-student-health-cover-oshc)). The Department of Home Affairs mandates that students maintain continuous OSHC for the duration of their visa ([Study in Australia](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/overseas-student-health-cover-oshc)). Failure to maintain valid OSHC can lead to visa cancellation ([Swinburne](https://www.swinburne.edu.au/courses/visas/overseas-student-health-cover/)).

**Specific Requirements for Packaged Courses**

For students undertaking packaged courses, the visa duration typically covers the length of all courses included in the package, plus some additional time ([Immigration News Australia](https://immigrationnewsaustralia.com/australian-student-visa-500-a-2025-guide-for-international-students/)). This implies that OSHC should also cover the entire visa duration, encompassing all courses within the package ([Kangaroo Edu](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025)).

**Relevant Information from Local Documents**

The local documents provide further clarity on this matter:

*   **b7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications.md**: This document explicitly states that a student (and any accompanying family members) must have OSHC for the proposed duration of their student visa. This includes the entire period from the date of arrival in Australia on the student visa to the expiry date of the visa. If the cost of health insurance is not included in enrolment fees, the student will need to obtain OSHC insurance and provide OSHC policy details in the application.

*   **b9-student-visas-visa-conditions-and-student-responsibilities.md**: This document highlights the requirements of OSHC as a visa condition.

*   **b9-1-visa-conditions.md**: This document lists condition 8501, which mandates that the student must maintain adequate health insurance during their time in Australia.

**Exceptions to OSHC Requirements**

There are limited exceptions to the OSHC requirement. Students from Norway, Belgium, or Sweden may be exempt if they have acceptable health cover from their home country ([Kangaroo Edu](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025); [This is Australia](https://www.thisisaustralia.com/student-visas-and-courses/oshc-information/); [Swinburne](https://www.swinburne.edu.au/courses/visas/overseas-student-health-cover/)). However, this does not apply to the student in question.

**Consequences of Non-Compliance**

Failure to maintain adequate OSHC coverage can have severe consequences, including visa cancellation and a potential ban on re-entry to Australia ([B9-1-visa-conditions.md](b9-1-visa-conditions.md)).

**Recommendation**

Based on the analysis of regulations, guidelines, and local documents, the student **needs to take out OSHC for the Masters course too before applying for a student visa as it is compulsory for international students to have health insurance for all courses in a package of offers while studying in Australia.**

**Rationale**

1.  **Visa Requirement:** OSHC is a mandatory visa condition, and students must maintain it for the entire duration of their student visa ([B9-1-visa-conditions.md](b9-1-visa-conditions.md)).
2.  **Packaged Courses:** The student is undertaking a packaged course, and the visa duration will likely cover both the ELICOS program and the Masters course. Therefore, OSHC must cover the entire period ([B7-4-packaging-arrangements-and-visa-duration.md](b7-4-packaging-arrangements-and-visa-duration.md)).
3.  **Continuous Coverage:** The student must have continuous OSHC coverage from the date of arrival in Australia until the expiry date of their student visa ([B7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications.md](b7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications.md)).
4.  **Compliance:** To comply with visa condition 8501, the student must have adequate health insurance for the entire duration of their stay in Australia ([B9-1-visa-conditions.md](b9-1-visa-conditions.md)).
5.  **Financial Protection:** OSHC provides access to medical care without financial hardship, covering doctor visits, hospital treatments, ambulance services, and limited pharmaceuticals ([Study in Australia](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/overseas-student-health-cover-oshc); [Edith Cowan College](https://www.edithcowancollege.edu.au/how-apply/international/health-cover/)).

**Additional Considerations**

*   **Choice of Provider:** International students have the right to choose their OSHC provider, although education providers may make specific recommendations ([B7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications.md](b7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications.md)).
*   **Policy Details:** Students need to provide details of their OSHC policy in their visa application ([B7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications.md](b7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications.md)).
*   **Renewals:** If the student extends their visa, they must renew their OSHC to cover the extended period ([Studies in Australia](https://www.studiesinaustralia.com/studying-in-australia/how-to-study-in-australia/student-visas/overseas-student-health-cover)).
*   **Transferring Providers:** Students can transfer to a different OSHC provider at any time, but some providers may charge a refund processing fee ([Studies in Australia](https://www.studiesinaustralia.com/studying-in-australia/how-to-study-in-australia/student-visas/overseas-student-health-cover)).

**Conclusion**

In conclusion, the student must obtain OSHC coverage for the Masters of Biotechnology course to comply with visa requirements and ensure continuous health insurance coverage throughout their stay in Australia. This is essential for maintaining their student visa status and accessing necessary medical care.

**References**

Edith Cowan College. (n.d.). *Overseas Student Health Cover - Edith Cowan College*. [https://www.edithcowancollege.edu.au/how-apply/international/health-cover/](https://www.edithcowancollege.edu.au/how-apply/international/health-cover/)

Edufirst Visa Consultancy. (n.d.). *Everything You Need About Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC) in Australia*. [https://www.edufirstvisa.com/blog/everything-you-need-about-overseas-student-health-cover-oshc-in-australia](https://www.edufirstvisa.com/blog/everything-you-need-about-overseas-student-health-cover-oshc-in-australia)

Immigration News Australia. (2024). *Australian Student Visa 500 - A 2025 Guide for International Students*. [https://immigrationnewsaustralia.com/australian-student-visa-500-a-2025-guide-for-international-students/](https://immigrationnewsaustralia.com/australian-student-visa-500-a-2025-guide-for-international-students/)

Kangaroo Edu. (2024). *Navigating Australian Student Visa Requirements in 2025: A Beginner’s Guide*. [https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025)

Study in Australia. (n.d.). *Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC)*. [https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/overseas-student-health-cover-oshc](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/overseas-student-health-cover-oshc)

Studies in Australia. (n.d.). *Overseas Student Health Cover | Study in Australia*. [https://www.studiesinaustralia.com/studying-in-australia/how-to-study-in-australia/student-visas/overseas-student-health-cover](https://www.studiesinaustralia.com/studying-in-australia/how-to-study-in-australia/student-visas/overseas-student-health-cover)

Swinburne. (n.d.). *Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC) in Australia*. [https://www.swinburne.edu.au/courses/visas/overseas-student-health-cover/](https://www.swinburne.edu.au/courses/visas/overseas-student-health-cover/)

This is Australia. (n.d.). *OSHC Information | This Is Australia*. [https://www.thisisaustralia.com/student-visas-and-courses/oshc-information/](https://www.thisisaustralia.com/student-visas-and-courses/oshc-information/)

**Local Documents**

*   b7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications.md
*   b7-4-packaging-arrangements-and-visa-duration.md
*   b9-1-visa-conditions.md
*   b9-student-visas-visa-conditions-and-student-responsibilities.md

question_results.question:
The parents of a 21-year-old student ask you to contact the institution their daughter is studying in to obtain her results. You contact the institution and ask if you can have a copy of her academic results. The institution should:

Answer options:
Give the information to the parents as they have paid for the student to be in the program.
Only give the results to the parents through you after asking the student for permission to do this and obtaining this permission in writing as privacy laws require.
Not give the information to the parents as required by migration laws.
Not give the information to the parents unless they pay the institution a fee.
correct_answers: Only give the results to the parents through you after asking the student for permission to do this and obtaining this permission in writing as privacy laws require.
extracted_answers: Only give the results to the parents through you after asking the student for permission to do this and obtaining this permission in writing as privacy laws require.
question_results.full_response:
## Report on the Disclosure of Student Academic Records Under Privacy Laws

### Executive Summary

This report addresses the scenario where parents of a 21-year-old student request an education agent to obtain their daughter's academic results from her institution. Based on an analysis of relevant Australian privacy laws, particularly the Privacy Act 1988, and international student privacy regulations, this report concludes that the institution should only release the student's academic results to the parents through the agent if the student provides explicit written consent. This conclusion is grounded in the legal principle that students over 18 years of age are considered adults with the right to control their personal information, including academic records.

### Introduction

The scenario presented raises critical questions about the balance between parental expectations, student privacy rights, and the legal obligations of educational institutions and agents. In Australia, the Privacy Act 1988 governs the handling of personal information, including student records. This legislation aims to protect the confidentiality of individuals' data and sets strict guidelines for its collection, use, and disclosure ([b2-5-the-privacy-act-1988.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b2-5-the-privacy-act-1988/)).

### Legal Framework: Privacy Act 1988 and Student Privacy

The Privacy Act 1988 is a cornerstone of Australian privacy law, establishing a framework for how personal information is handled by government agencies and private sector organizations with an annual turnover of more than $3 million AUD. The Act includes 13 Australian Privacy Principles (APPs) that govern the collection, use, disclosure, and storage of personal information ([b10-1-what-should-an-agent-know-about-privacy.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b10-1-what-should-an-agent-know-about-privacy/)).

For international students, these principles are particularly relevant. Educational institutions must only collect information necessary for their normal function and must inform students about the collection of their data. The use of this information is restricted to the purpose for which it was collected, unless the student agrees otherwise. Furthermore, institutions are obligated to protect student information from loss or misuse, and students have the right to access their information upon request ([b10-1-what-should-an-agent-know-about-privacy.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b10-1-what-should-an-agent-know-about-privacy/)).

### Privacy Concerns and Students Aged 18 or Over

A key consideration in this scenario is the student's age. As the student is 21 years old, they are legally considered an adult under Australian law. This means that the right to control their personal information rests solely with them. Educational institutions are generally prohibited from disclosing a student’s educational record to a parent without the student’s written consent ([policies.northeastern.edu](https://policies.northeastern.edu/policy106/)).

The Privacy Act 1988 recognizes that once a student turns 18, the rights previously held by their parents regarding access to their educational records transfer to the student ([cdc.gov](https://www.cdc.gov/phlp/php/resources/family-educational-rights-and-privacy-act-ferpa.html); [studentprivacy.ed.gov](http://studentprivacy.ed.gov/resources/parent-guide-family-educational-rights-and-privacy-act-ferpa)). This principle is echoed in other countries with similar privacy laws, such as the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA) in the United States, which also transfers rights to the student upon reaching 18 years of age ([zengrc.com](https://www.zengrc.com/blog/student-data-privacy-laws-by-state/)).

### Academic Progress and Results: Consent Requirement

In the context of academic progress and results, the institution cannot provide information to the parents or the agent without specific written instruction from the student ([b10-2-when-is-privacy-a-concern.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b10-2-when-is-privacy-a-concern/)). The institution is obligated to protect the student's privacy, even if the parents have paid for the student's education ([weber.edu](https://www.weber.edu/registrar/Parent_Info.html)).

The agent's role is to facilitate communication between the student and the institution, ensuring that the student is fully informed of their rights and options. The agent should explain to the parents that they cannot obtain the student's academic results without the student's explicit consent ([b10-2-when-is-privacy-a-concern.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b10-2-when-is-privacy-a-concern/)).

### Medical Situations and Privacy

While the scenario focuses on academic results, it is important to briefly address medical situations. In cases where a student has medical problems, parents may expect the agent to investigate the issue. However, medical authorities may not agree to communicate with an agent or the education provider without the student's consent. In situations where a student is unable to communicate, medical authorities will typically communicate with the student's parents, spouse, or husband, unless the student has expressed a wish for them not to ([b10-2-when-is-privacy-a-concern.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b10-2-when-is-privacy-a-concern/)).

### Student Complaints and Appeals

International students have the right to complain if they believe they have not received acceptable services. They also have the right to appeal adverse decisions, such as failing a subject or not meeting attendance requirements. Education providers must have a complaints and appeals process that students can follow ([b10-3-student-complaints-and-appeals.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b10-3-student-complaints-and-appeals/)).

### Implications for Education Agents

Education agents working in Australia are subject to privacy laws and must understand how information about individuals can be used ([b10-1-what-should-an-agent-know-about-privacy.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b10-1-what-should-an-agent-know-about-privacy/)). Agents working outside of Australia need to be aware that certain institutions, such as hospitals, cannot provide information without the student's written permission. This can be confusing if it differs from the practices in the student's home country ([b10-1-what-should-an-agent-know-about-privacy.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b10-1-what-should-an-agent-know-about-privacy/)).

### The National Code 2018

Standard 3.3.6 of The National Code 2018 requires that written agreements with students outline the circumstances in which personal information may be disclosed by the registered provider, the Commonwealth, or state or territory agencies, in accordance with the Privacy Act 1988 ([b10-1-what-should-an-agent-know-about-privacy.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b10-1-what-should-an-agent-know-about-privacy/)).

### Best Practices for Handling Student Information

To ensure compliance with privacy laws and ethical standards, education agents should adhere to the following best practices:

1.  **Obtain Consent:** Always obtain written consent from the student before collecting, using, or disclosing their personal information.
2.  **Inform Students:** Clearly explain to students how their information will be used and who it will be shared with.
3.  **Protect Information:** Implement security measures to protect student information from loss, misuse, or unauthorized access.
4.  **Provide Access:** Allow students to access their information upon request and correct any inaccuracies.
5.  **Respect Student Autonomy:** Recognize that students over 18 have the right to control their personal information.

### Conclusion

In the scenario presented, the institution should not provide the student's academic results to the parents or the agent without the student's explicit written consent. This is because the student is 21 years old and has the right to control their personal information under the Privacy Act 1988. The agent should work with the student to obtain the necessary consent, ensuring that the student is fully informed of their rights and options.

### Recommendations

1.  The education agent should explain to the parents that they cannot obtain the student's academic results without the student's written consent.
2.  The education agent should contact the student and request written permission to obtain and share their academic results with their parents.
3.  The institution should only release the student's academic results to the parents through the agent after receiving written consent from the student.
4.  Educational institutions should regularly train staff on privacy laws and best practices for handling student information.
5.  Education agents should stay informed about changes to privacy laws and regulations to ensure compliance.

### Reference List

question_results.question:
When a student has been reported to DHA by the education provider, DHA will send a letter to the student asking them to explain their circumstances to DHA. How long does the student have to contact DHA and make an appointment?

Answer options:
20 days
5 days
35 days
28 days
correct_answers: 28 days
extracted_answers: 28 days
question_results.full_response:
## Report on the Timeframe for Student Contacting DHA After Notification of Visa Breach

**Introduction**

This report addresses the query regarding the timeframe a student has to contact the Department of Home Affairs (DHA) and make an appointment after being reported by their education provider for breaching visa conditions. The report will analyze provided documentation and external web sources to determine the correct timeframe and provide a comprehensive understanding of the process. The information is crucial for education agents and international students to navigate visa regulations effectively.

**Analysis of Provided Information**

Several sources within the provided documentation shed light on the procedures following a report of non-compliance by an education provider.

*   **Education Provider Responsibilities:** The education provider must have documented policies and procedures for monitoring course progress and determining when a student has failed to make satisfactory course progress ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md)).

*   **Notification of Intent to Report:** The provider must issue the student a written notification of their intention to report them to DHA. The letter must inform the student they have 20 working days to access the provider’s complaints and appeals process ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md)).

*   **Reporting to DHA via PRISMS:** Once the timeframe for appeal has lapsed, or the appeals process has been finalized in favor of the provider, the provider reports the visa breach using the Provider Registration and International Student Management System (PRISMS) ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md)).

*   **DHA Notification to Student:** After the provider reports the breach, the student receives a notice informing them that they must attend an Immigration office within 28 days, with a warning that failure to do so may result in visa cancellation ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md)).

*   **Consequences of Non-Compliance:** If the student fails to provide the institution with a current postal address, the formal letter might not reach them. However, the student visa can still be canceled, as it is the student’s responsibility to ensure the provider has their current postal address ([b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms.md](b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms.md)).

*   **Valid Reasons for Non-Compliance:** A student may have a valid reason for non-compliance, such as illness, which needs to be supported by medical certificates. DHA may decide not to cancel the visa after an interview with the student ([b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms.md](b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms.md)).

**Analysis of External Web Sources**

External web sources corroborate and expand upon the information found in the provided documents.

*   **Notice of Intention to Consider Cancellation (NOICC):** The Department of Home Affairs (DHA) may send a NOICC if there are concerns regarding a visa status. Common reasons include non-compliance with visa conditions, use of bogus documents, or provision of incorrect information ([Migration Agents Perth, 2023](https://migrationagentsperth.com.au/notice-of-intention-to-consider-cancellation-noicc/)).

*   **Time Limits for Responding to NOICC:** Generally, a student has 28 days from the date of the Notice to answer the question of whether their visa should be cancelled. There is a 14-day response time for answering whether they pass the character test ([Migration Agents Perth, 2023](https://migrationagentsperth.com.au/notice-of-intention-to-consider-cancellation-noicc/)).

*   **Calculating the Time Limit:** To calculate the time limit to respond to a Notice of Intention to Consider Cancellation, look at the date on the last page of the Notice letter and add 7 working days if it was posted. Then add another 28 days (including weekends). If the Notice was faxed or emailed, add 28 days (including weekends) from the date on the letter ([Visa Envoy](https://visaenvoy.com/notice-of-intention-to-consider-cancellation/)).

*   **Actions After Receiving the Notice:** It’s crucial to write to DHA explaining why the visa shouldn’t be canceled. The DHA prepares an Issues Paper for a decision-maker after collecting relevant information ([Migration Agents Perth, 2023](https://migrationagentsperth.com.au/notice-of-intention-to-consider-cancellation-noicc/)).

*   **Factors Considered by DHA:** DHA considers factors such as the protection of the Australian community, the student’s age when they arrived in Australia, the duration of their stay, and Australia’s human rights obligations. Secondary considerations include family ties to Australia, age and health, links to the country of origin, potential hardship, and education level ([Migration Agents Perth, 2023](https://migrationagentsperth.com.au/notice-of-intention-to-consider-cancellation-noicc/)).

*   **Extending Student Visas:** The Department of Home Affairs (DHA) expects students to complete their studies within the timeframe of their student visa; however, extensions are possible in certain circumstances. You can only apply to extend your student visa within 90 days of your current visa expiry date ([MyMurdoch Answers, 2025](https://myanswers.custhelp.com/app/answers/detail/a_id/691/~/extending-student-visas---renewing-coe)).

**Synthesis and Opinion**

Based on the analysis of the provided documents and external web sources, the timeframe a student has to contact DHA and make an appointment after being reported by their education provider is **28 days**.

The education provider first issues a written notification of their intention to report the student to DHA, allowing the student 20 working days to access the provider’s complaints and appeals process. Once this period has lapsed or the appeal is decided in favor of the provider, the provider reports the breach to DHA via PRISMS. Following this report, DHA sends a formal letter to the student, requiring them to attend an Immigration office within 28 days. Failure to comply may result in visa cancellation ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md)).

It is important to note that the 28-day period starts from the date of the DHA notification letter. If the letter is sent via mail, additional time may be added to account for postal delays ([Visa Envoy](https://visaenvoy.com/notice-of-intention-to-consider-cancellation/)).

**Recommendations**

Given the strict timeframes and potential consequences, the following recommendations are crucial:

1.  **Maintain Accurate Contact Information:** Students must keep their education provider informed of their current address in Australia. This ensures all formal notices are received promptly ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md)).

2.  **Act Promptly Upon Receiving Notification:** Upon receiving a notification from DHA, students should immediately seek advice from a registered migration agent or legal professional to understand their rights and obligations ([Migration Agents Perth, 2023](https://migrationagentsperth.com.au/notice-of-intention-to-consider-cancellation-noicc/)).

3.  **Gather Supporting Documentation:** Students should gather all relevant documentation to support their case, including medical certificates, letters of support, and any other evidence that explains their circumstances ([b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms.md](b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms.md)).

4.  **Respond to DHA Within the Timeframe:** Students must respond to DHA within the 28-day timeframe, providing a detailed explanation of their circumstances and why their visa should not be canceled ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md)).

5.  **Utilize Appeals Process:** If the student disagrees with the education provider’s decision, they should utilize the internal and external appeals processes available to them ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md)).

6.  **Stay Informed:** Students should stay informed about their visa conditions and any changes to immigration regulations by regularly checking the DHA website and consulting with education agents or legal professionals ([MyMurdoch Answers, 2025](https://myanswers.custhelp.com/app/answers/detail/a_id/691/~/extending-student-visas---renewing-coe)).

**Conclusion**

The correct answer to the query is **28 days**. After an education provider reports a student to DHA for non-compliance with visa conditions, DHA sends a letter to the student requiring them to attend an Immigration office within 28 days. Adhering to this timeframe is critical to avoid visa cancellation and potential exclusion periods. Students must maintain accurate contact information, act promptly upon receiving notification, gather supporting documentation, and respond to DHA within the given timeframe to protect their visa status.

**References**

*   b6-2-what-is-a-coe.md
*   b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms.md
*   b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing.md
*   b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md
*   b7-4-packaging-arrangements-and-visa-duration.md
*   b8-student-visas-application-processes-specific-requirements-and-integrity-concerns.md
*   b8-4-examples-of-integrity-concerns-for-dha.md
*   b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md
*   b9-3-work-rights-for-students.md
*   c3-2-after-arriving-in-australia.md
*   Migration Agents Perth. (2023, October 28). *Notice of Intention to Consider Cancellation (NOICC) |*. [https://migrationagentsperth.com.au/notice-of-intention-to-consider-cancellation-noicc/](https://migrationagentsperth.com.au/notice-of-intention-to-consider-cancellation-noicc/)
*   MyMurdoch Answers. (2025, February 18). *Extending Student Visas - Renewing CoE*. [https://myanswers.custhelp.com/app/answers/detail/a_id/691/~/extending-student-visas---renewing-coe](https://myanswers.custhelp.com/app/answers/detail/a_id/691/~/extending-student-visas---renewing-coe)
*   Visa Envoy. *Notice of Intention to Consider Cancellation*. [https://visaenvoy.com/notice-of-intention-to-consider-cancellation/](https://visaenvoy.com/notice-of-intention-to-consider-cancellation/)

A student visa in Australia:
