question_results.question:
A student who has studied a Bachelor’s degree in Australia for 3 years:

Answer options:
will be able to apply for a Temporary Graduate Visa to work in Australia for up to 2 years following their Graduation
will be unable to work in Australia following their Graduation and must return home
will be able to migrate to Australia permanently after Graduation
will only be able to work in Australia after Graduation because their degree is from an Australian institution
correct_answers: will be able to apply for a Temporary Graduate Visa to work in Australia for up to 2 years following their Graduation
extracted_answers: will be able to apply for a Temporary Graduate Visa to work in Australia for up to 2 years following their Graduation
question_results.full_response:
## Temporary Graduate Visa Options for Bachelor's Degree Graduates in Australia

### IntroductionThis report addresses the options available to a student who has completed a three-year Bachelor's degree in Australia regarding their ability to work in Australia post-graduation. Specifically, it examines whether the student will be able to apply for a Temporary Graduate visa to work in Australia for up to two years following their graduation. The report will consider relevant visa streams, eligibility criteria, recent changes to visa regulations, and other factors that may influence the student's prospects.

### Temporary Graduate Visa (Subclass 485)
The Temporary Graduate visa (subclass 485) is designed to allow international students who have recently graduated from an Australian educational institution to remain in Australia temporarily to gain work experience ([b9-4-visas-following-study.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/)). This visa has two primary streams: the Graduate Work stream and the Post-Study Work stream ([b9-4-visas-following-study.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/)).

### Post-Study Work Stream
The Post-Study Work stream is available to eligible graduates of a higher education degree, offering extended options for working in Australia ([b9-4-visas-following-study.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/)). Successful applicants under this stream may be granted a visa for two, three, or four years, depending on their highest educational qualification ([b9-4-visas-following-study.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/)). For a Bachelor degree, the visa is typically granted for two years ([b9-4-visas-following-study.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/)).

### Eligibility Criteria for the Post-Study Work Stream
To be eligible for the Post-Study Work stream, applicants must meet several criteria, including:
1.  **Age Limit:** As of March 23, 2024, the age limit for applicants has been reduced from 50 years to 35 years ([b9-4-visas-following-study.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/)).
2.  **English Language Proficiency:** The English language proficiency requirement has been increased for applications lodged on or after March 23, 2024 ([b9-4-visas-following-study.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/)). The minimum score required increases from IELTS 6.0 to 6.5 (or equivalent) with a minimum score of 5.5 for each component of the test (reading, writing, speaking and listening) ([visaenvoy.com](https://visaenvoy.com/graduate-temporary-485-visa/)).
3.  **Australian Study Requirement:** All subclass 485 visa applicants must meet the Australian study requirement in the six months immediately prior to making their application, regardless of the stream that they are assessed under ([b9-4-visas-following-study.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/)). This includes:
    *   Attaining either a single qualification requiring at least two academic years of study or multiple qualifications resulting in a total period of at least two academic years of study ([b9-4-visas-following-study.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/)).
    *   Undertaking this study in no less than 16 months ([b9-4-visas-following-study.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/)).
    *   Lodging their application within six months of completing their course (when they received their results, not the Graduation ceremony) ([b9-4-visas-following-study.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/)).
4.  **Course Requirements:** The course/courses must also:
    *   Be on CRICOS ([b9-4-visas-following-study.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/)).
    *   Have been successfully completed ([b9-4-visas-following-study.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/)).
    *   Have resulted in an eligible qualification ([b9-4-visas-following-study.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/)).
    *   Have had all instruction in English ([b9-4-visas-following-study.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/)).
    *   Have been completed while physically in Australia ([b9-4-visas-following-study.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/)).
    *   Have been completed while holding a visa allowing study in Australia ([b9-4-visas-following-study.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/)).
    *   Be counted only once towards the Australian study requirement ([b9-4-visas-following-study.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/)).
    *   Not be an English language proficiency course or enabling program ([b9-4-visas-following-study.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/)).

### Analysis of the Student's Eligibility
Given that the student has studied a Bachelor’s degree in Australia for three years, the following points can be made:
1.  **Qualification Level:** A Bachelor's degree is an eligible qualification for the Post-Study Work stream ([b9-4-visas-following-study.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/)).
2.  **Duration of Study:** The Australian study requirement mandates at least two academic years (92 weeks) of study ([b9-4-visas-following-study.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/)). Since the student has studied for three years, they meet this requirement, provided that the course is registered by CRICOS ([b9-4-visas-following-study.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/)).
3.  **Age:** Assuming the student is under 35 years of age at the time of application, they meet the age requirement ([b9-4-visas-following-study.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/)).
4.  **Other Requirements:** The student must also meet the English language proficiency requirement and other general criteria such as health and character requirements ([visahome.com.au](https://visahome.com.au/temporary-graduate-visa-in-australia-everything-you-should-know/)).

### Graduate Work Stream
The Graduate Work stream is relevant to international students with an eligible qualification who graduate with skills and qualifications that relate to an occupation on Australia’s Skilled Occupation List (SOL) ([b9-4-visas-following-study.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/)). A visa in this stream is granted for 18 months ([b9-4-visas-following-study.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/)). If the student's qualification and skills align with an occupation on the SOL, they may also consider this stream.

### Changes to Eligible Qualifications
It is important to note that changes to eligible qualifications for the Post-Higher Education Work Stream commenced from December 14, 2024 ([studyaustralia.gov.au](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/your-guide-to-visas/temporary-graduate-visa-subclass-485)). These changes may impact the student's eligibility, and it is crucial to refer to the latest information from the Department of Home Affairs (DHA) ([b9-4-visas-following-study.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/)).

### Conclusion
Based on the information available, a student who has studied a Bachelor’s degree in Australia for three years **will likely be able to apply for a Temporary Graduate Visa to work in Australia for up to two years following their Graduation**, provided they meet all the eligibility criteria for the Post-Study Work stream. These criteria include being under 35 years of age, meeting the English language proficiency requirement, fulfilling the Australian study requirement, and satisfying health and character requirements. The student should also ensure that their course is CRICOS-registered and that they apply within six months of completing their course.

### Recommendations
1.  **Consult the DHA Website:** The student should consult the DHA website for the most up-to-date information on visa requirements and eligibility criteria ([b9-4-visas-following-study.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/)).
2.  **Verify CRICOS Registration:** The student should verify that their course is registered on CRICOS ([b9-4-visas-following-study.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/)).
3.  **Prepare for English Language Test:** The student should prepare for and undertake an English language test to meet the required proficiency level ([b9-4-visas-following-study.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/)).
4.  **Gather Necessary Documents:** The student should gather all necessary documents, including academic transcripts, passport, and evidence of health insurance ([visahome.com.au](https://visahome.com.au/temporary-graduate-visa-in-australia-everything-you-should-know/)).
5.  **Consider Graduate Work Stream:** If the student's skills and qualifications align with an occupation on the SOL, they should also consider the Graduate Work stream ([b9-4-visas-following-study.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/)).

### References

b9-4-visas-following-study.md. (n.d.). ICEF. [https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-4-visas-following-study/)

studyaustralia.gov.au. (n.d.). Temporary Graduate visa (subclass 485) | Study Australia. [https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/your-guide-to-visas/temporary-graduate-visa-subclass-485](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/your-guide-to-visas/temporary-graduate-visa-subclass-485)

visaenvoy.com. (n.d.). Graduate Temporary 485 Visa - Visa Envoy. [https://visaenvoy.com/graduate-temporary-485-visa/](https://visaenvoy.com/graduate-temporary-485-visa/)

visahome.com.au. (n.d.). Temporary Graduate Visa in Australia: Everything You Should Know - visahome.com.au. [https://visahome.com.au/temporary-graduate-visa-in-australia-everything-you-should-know/](https://visahome.com.au/temporary-graduate-visa-in-australia-everything-you-should-know/)

question_results.question:
You recruited an 18 year old student to study in a Foundation program in Australia. She has recently moved out of her homestay and into an apartment with some friends. Whose responsibility is it to ensure that the education provider has her current address?

Answer options:
The student is responsible for informing her education provider of her change of address.
The education provider is responsible for contacting the student and asking her to change her address.
DHA is responsible for contacting the student and asking her to change her address.
AEI is responsible for contacting the student and asking her to change her address.
correct_answers: The student is responsible for informing her education provider of her change of address.
extracted_answers: The student is responsible for informing her education provider of her change of address.
question_results.full_response:
## Report on Responsibility for Updating Student Address Information

**Introduction**

This report addresses the query regarding the responsibility for ensuring an education provider has the current address of an 18-year-old student who has moved out of her homestay and into an apartment. The student is enrolled in a Foundation program in Australia. The report will analyze relevant regulations, policies, and guidelines to determine the responsible party. The analysis will be based on information from local documents and web sources, prioritizing relevance, reliability, and significance.

**Analysis**

Based on the provided information, the primary responsibility for ensuring the education provider has the current address of the student lies with the student. Several sources explicitly state this obligation.

**Student's Responsibility**

*   **Local Documents:** The document "b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md" clearly states, "The student must keep the education provider informed of their current address in Australia. This is because all formal notices are sent to this address. If the address changes, the student must inform the education provider within 7 days."
*   **Visa Condition 8533:** Document "b9-1-visa-conditions.md" mentions visa condition 8533, which likely mandates that students keep their education institution informed of their current address in Australia and notify them of any changes within 7 days.
*   **University Policies:** Several university websites confirm this requirement. For example, La Trobe University states that international students must "Notify the University of your Australian residential address within 7 days of your initial onshore arrival and every time you change your address" ([La Trobe University](https://latrobe-current.custhelp.com/app/answers/detail/a_id/3242/~/study-requirements-for-international-students-on-student-visas)). Similarly, Murdoch University requires students to notify them of their residential address and any changes within seven days ([Murdoch University](https://myanswers.custhelp.com/app/answers/detail/a_id/697/~/notifying-department-of-home-affairs-of-changes-to-my-address)).

**Education Provider's Role**

While the primary responsibility rests with the student, the education provider also has a role in ensuring they have accurate contact information.

*   **ESOS Framework:** The Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) framework places obligations on registered providers to collect and report relevant information relating to student visas ([Department of Education, Australian Government](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework)).
*   **Record Keeping:** Providers must keep records of each accepted student, including their current residential address, mobile phone number, and email address. Every six months, the provider must confirm with the student in writing that these details are still correct and update the records accordingly ([Department of Education, Australian Government](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/international-providers-tps)).
*   **Communication:** The education provider uses the student's address to send formal notices. This underscores the importance of having accurate address information ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md)).

**Department of Home Affairs (DHA) Role**

The DHA is responsible for maintaining Australia’s visa requirements and ensuring compliance with visa conditions ([c2-6-government-peak-bodies-and-other-organisations.md](c2-6-government-peak-bodies-and-other-organisations.md)). While the DHA does not directly contact students to update their address, they rely on the education provider to report any breaches of visa conditions, including failure to maintain accurate contact information.

**AEI Role**

There is no mention of AEI being responsible for contacting the student and asking her to change her address.

**Consequences of Non-Compliance**

Failure to keep the education provider informed of a current address can have serious consequences for the student.

*   **Visa Cancellation:** Breaching visa conditions, such as failing to provide an updated address, can risk visa cancellation ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md)).
*   **Missed Communication:** If the education provider does not have the student's current address, the student may miss important notices and communications, potentially leading to further complications ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md)).

**Changes to Student Visa Requirements in 2025**

It is important to note that Australia is implementing stricter student visa requirements in 2025 ([Balasubramanian](https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/navigating-australias-stricter-student-visa-2025-balasubramanian-3jpnf/)). While the provided documents do not specify whether these changes directly impact the address update requirement, it is likely that compliance with all visa conditions, including maintaining accurate contact information, will be more closely monitored.

One significant change is the mandatory Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE) for all student visa applications from January 1, 2025 ([Sharma](https://imminews.com.au/major-change-to-australia-student-visa-requirements), [VisaVerge](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants), [Admission Ac Blog](https://blog.admission.ac/2025/01/05/australia-changes-rules-for-student-visas-check-new-requirement-for-a-student-visa-application/)). This change aims to ensure visa integrity and attract genuine international students. While the CoE itself may not directly relate to address updates, it signifies a broader effort to tighten visa requirements and ensure students are actively engaged in their studies.

**Specific Considerations for Under 18 Students**

Although the student in question is 18 years old, it is worth noting the specific requirements for students under 18. According to document "b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md", an under 18 student must have the approval of their education provider to move to another address if they are not living with a parent, guardian, or relative. Since the student is now 18, this specific requirement no longer applies, but it highlights the additional level of oversight for younger students.

**Conclusion**

The student is responsible for informing her education provider of her change of address. The student is obligated to notify the education provider within 7 days of any change of address. While the education provider has a responsibility to maintain accurate records and the DHA oversees visa compliance, the onus is on the student to provide the correct information. Failure to do so can result in breaches of visa conditions and potential visa cancellation.

**Recommendations**

*   Education agents should clearly inform students of their responsibility to update their address with the education provider upon arrival and whenever they change their address.
*   Education providers should have clear and accessible procedures for students to update their address information.
*   Education providers should regularly remind students of their obligation to maintain accurate contact information and the consequences of non-compliance.

question_results.question:
When a student applies for a student visa which of the following general requirements will a student NOT need to provide with the application?

Answer options:
Overseas Student Health Insurance
Knowledge of Australian culture
Arrangements for students under 18
Confirmation of Enrolment
correct_answers: Knowledge of Australian culture
extracted_answers: Knowledge of Australian culture
question_results.full_response:
## Student Visa Requirements for Australia: A Detailed Analysis

The Australian Department of Home Affairs (DHA) has specific criteria that international students must meet to obtain a student visa. These requirements ensure that students are genuine, have the financial capacity to support themselves, and will comply with visa conditions. This report aims to determine which of the listed general requirements—Overseas Student Health Insurance (OSHC), knowledge of Australian culture, arrangements for students under 18, and Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE)—is NOT a standard requirement for a student visa application. Based on a comprehensive review of recent updates and regulations, this report concludes that while OSHC, arrangements for students under 18, and CoE are essential, knowledge of Australian culture is not a documented requirement for student visa applications.

### Core Requirements for Australian Student Visas

Several sources confirm the core requirements for obtaining an Australian student visa. These include:

1.  **Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE):** As of January 1, 2025, a CoE is mandatory for all student visa applications, replacing the previous acceptance of Letters of Offer ([VisaVerge, 2025](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/)). The CoE confirms the student's acceptance into a registered course, details the course specifics, tuition fees, and program duration ([ImmiNews, 2025](https://imminews.com.au/australia-introduces-new-rules-for-student-visa-applications-in-2025-australia-immigration-news)).

2.  **Genuine Student (GS) Requirement:** The Genuine Temporary Entrant (GTE) requirement has been replaced by the Genuine Student (GS) requirement, effective from March 23, 2024 ([Kangaroo Edu, 2025](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025/)). This assesses the applicant’s intention to study in Australia through targeted questions about their studies, plans, and circumstances.

3.  **English Language Proficiency:** Applicants must demonstrate appropriate English language skills, often through standardized tests like IELTS or TOEFL ([VisaVerge, 2025](https://www.visaverge.com/questions/visa-requirements-for-minors-studying-in-australia/)). The minimum score required is 6.0 for most applicants ([ICEF, n.d.a](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications/)).

4.  **Financial Capacity:** Students must prove they have sufficient funds to cover tuition fees, living expenses, and travel costs ([VisaVerge, 2025](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/)). As of 2024, the minimum funds required are AUD$29,710 for a single student, AUD$10,394 for a spouse, and AUD$4,449 per dependent child ([ICEF, n.d.b](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements/)).

5.  **Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC):** Adequate health insurance is mandatory for most international students to cover medical and hospital care ([VisaVerge, 2025](https://www.visaverge.com/questions/australian-visa-health-insurance-requirements-for-international-students/)). OSHC must cover the entire duration of the student visa, from arrival to expiry ([VisaVerge, 2025](https://www.visaverge.com/questions/australian-visa-health-insurance-requirements-for-international-students/)).

6.  **Good Character:** Applicants must declare that they have not been involved in criminal activity or previously deported ([ICEF, n.d.c](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications/)).

7.  **Arrangements for Students Under 18:** Students under 18 must provide evidence of adequate welfare arrangements for the duration of their visa or until they turn 18 ([ICEF, n.d.d](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18/)). This can include living with a parent or legal custodian, a relative with a Student Guardian visa, or arrangements approved by the education provider ([ICEF, n.d.d](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18/)).

### Absence of Knowledge of Australian Culture as a Visa Requirement

While cultural awareness is beneficial for international students adjusting to life in Australia, it is not a formal requirement for obtaining a student visa. The DHA focuses on ensuring that students are genuine, have the means to support themselves, and will adhere to visa conditions.

#### Cultural Awareness and Adaptation

Although not a visa requirement, cultural awareness is crucial for international students to integrate successfully into Australian society. Education agents play a vital role in preparing students for cross-cultural challenges, including understanding differences in teaching and learning environments ([ICEF, n.d.e](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/c4-4-cross-cultural-awareness/)).

#### Teaching and Learning Environment

Australian classrooms encourage initiative and questioning, which may differ from educational norms in other cultures ([ICEF, n.d.e](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/c4-4-cross-cultural-awareness/)). Australian educators emphasize problem-solving and group projects, requiring students to collaborate and overcome interpersonal difficulties ([ICEF, n.d.e](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/c4-4-cross-cultural-awareness/)).

#### Language and Communication

Australians often use informal language, which can be confusing for international students accustomed to American or British English ([ICEF, n.d.e](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/c4-4-cross-cultural-awareness/)). Understanding these nuances can help students communicate more effectively and feel more comfortable in their new environment.

### Specific Requirements for Minors

For students under 18, additional welfare arrangements are mandatory. These arrangements ensure the safety and well-being of younger students while they are in Australia ([VisaVerge, 2025](https://www.visaverge.com/questions/age-requirements-for-australian-student-visa-applying-and-eligibility/)).

#### Welfare Arrangements

Minors must have adequate welfare arrangements in place for the duration of their stay, which can include:

*   Living with a parent or legal custodian ([ICEF, n.d.d](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18/)).
*   Living with a relative who holds a Student Guardian visa (subclass 590) ([ICEF, n.d.d](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18/)).
*   Having their education provider provide for their general welfare and accommodation ([ICEF, n.d.d](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18/)).

#### Confirmation of Appropriate Accommodation and Welfare (CAAW)If a minor is not living with a parent or suitable relative, the education provider must issue a CAAW letter approving the student’s welfare and accommodation arrangements ([ICEF, n.d.d](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18/)). The provider must specify the dates when they will take responsibility for the student’s welfare ([ICEF, n.d.d](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18/)).

### Financial Requirements

Demonstrating sufficient financial capacity is a critical requirement for obtaining an Australian student visa. Applicants must show they have access to funds to cover tuition fees, living expenses, and travel costs ([VisaVerge, 2025](https://www.visaverge.com/questions/visa-requirements-for-minors-studying-in-australia/)).

#### Evidence of Financial Capacity

Acceptable sources of financial evidence include:

*   Money deposit with a financial institution ([ICEF, n.d.b](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements/)).
*   Loan with a financial institution ([ICEF, n.d.b](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements/)).
*   Government loans ([ICEF, n.d.b](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements/)).
*   Scholarship ([ICEF, n.d.b](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements/)).

#### Minimum Funds Required

As of 2024, the minimum funds required are:

*   AUD$29,710 for a single student ([ICEF, n.d.b](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements/)).
*   AUD$10,394 for a spouse or de-facto partner ([ICEF, n.d.b](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements/)).
*   AUD$4,449 per dependent child ([ICEF, n.d.b](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements/)).
*   AUD$13,502 per child for annual school costs ([ICEF, n.d.b](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements/)).

### Health Insurance Requirements

Adequate health insurance is a mandatory visa condition. The DHA requires evidence of Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC) to demonstrate that the student is adequately insured ([VisaVerge, 2025](https://www.visaverge.com/questions/australian-visa-health-insurance-requirements-for-international-students/)).

#### OSHC Coverage

OSHC typically covers visits to the doctor, some hospital treatment, ambulance cover, and limited pharmaceuticals ([VisaVerge, 2025](https://www.visaverge.com/questions/australian-visa-health-insurance-requirements-for-international-students/)). The coverage must last for the entire duration of the student visa, from the date of arrival in Australia to the expiry date of the visa ([VisaVerge, 2025](https://www.visaverge.com/questions/australian-visa-health-insurance-requirements-for-international-students/)).

#### Exemptions

Some students may be exempt from the OSHC requirement if they are from countries with reciprocal health care agreements with Australia ([VisaVerge, 2025](https://www.visaverge.com/questions/australian-visa-health-insurance-requirements-for-international-students/)).

### Conclusion

Based on the analysis of current regulations and guidelines, it is evident that Overseas Student Health Insurance, arrangements for students under 18, and Confirmation of Enrolment are all essential requirements for obtaining an Australian student visa. While knowledge of Australian culture is beneficial for students to adapt and integrate into Australian society, it is not a documented requirement for the visa application process. The DHA prioritizes ensuring that students are genuine, have sufficient financial capacity, and will comply with visa conditions, with specific measures in place to protect the welfare of students under 18.

### References

ICEF. (n.d.a). *B7.1 Criteria Applied to all Student Applications*. ICEF Academy. [https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications/](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications/)

ICEF. (n.d.b). *B7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements*. ICEF Academy. [https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements/](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements/)ICEF. (n.d.c). *B7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications*. ICEF Academy. [https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications/](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications/)

ICEF. (n.d.d). *B8.2 Requirements for Students Under 18*. ICEF Academy. [https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18/](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-2-requirements-for-students-under-18/)

ICEF. (n.d.e). *C4.4 Cross-Cultural Awareness*. ICEF Academy. [https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/c4-4-cross-cultural-awareness/](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/c4-4-cross-cultural-awareness/)

ImmiNews. (2025). *Australia Introduces New Rules for Student Visa Applications in 2025*. [https://imminews.com.au/australia-introduces-new-rules-for-student-visa-applications-in-2025-australia-immigration-news](https://imminews.com.au/australia-introduces-new-rules-for-student-visa-applications-in-2025-australia-immigration-news)

question_results.question:
A student you recruited to study in Australia is studying a three-year Bachelor of Arts program. In her last semester the student was admitted to hospital and missed 4 weeks. She feels that she is not able to finish her program and she would like to extend her studies by one more semester. You inform the student that she:

Answer options:
Can apply for a tourist visa.
Cannot apply for an extension to her student visa.
Cannot apply for an extension to her student visa as extensions are only granted for international students studying part time.
Can apply for an extension to her student visa. The student should make an appointment with DHA to discuss the issue and bring documents with her such as her passport and a copy of her hospital records.
correct_answers: Can apply for an extension to her student visa. The student should make an appointment with DHA to discuss the issue and bring documents with her such as her passport and a copy of her hospital records.
extracted_answers: Can apply for an extension to her student visa. The student should make an appointment with DHA to discuss the issue and bring documents with her such as her passport and a copy of her hospital records.
question_results.full_response:
## Student Visa Extension Options for Students Unable to Complete Studies: A Detailed Report

The scenario presented involves an international student enrolled in a three-year Bachelor of Arts program in Australia who experienced a significant health issue during her final semester, leading to concerns about completing her studies within the original visa timeframe. This report aims to provide a comprehensive analysis of the student's options, focusing on the possibility of extending her student visa. Based on the provided information, the most appropriate course of action is that the student **can apply for an extension to her student visa**. The student should gather relevant documents, including her passport and hospital records, and consult with the Department of Home Affairs (DHA) to discuss her situation.

### Visa Extension Eligibility and Requirements

Several sources confirm that international students may be eligible to extend their student visas under certain circumstances ([Victory Group, 2024](https://www.victorygroup.au/2024/12/22/student-visa-extension-australia-essential-steps-and-updates-for-2025/); [ACU International, n.d.](https://www.acu.edu.au/international-students/arriving-and-living-in-australia/applying-for-your-student-visa/extend-your-student-visa)). The key is whether the student can demonstrate "compassionate or compelling circumstances" that have impacted their ability to complete their studies on time ([Canberra University, n.d.a](https://www.canberra.edu.au/current-students/international-students/current-international-students/accordions/intermissions); [Student.ask.adelaide.edu.au, n.d.](https://student.ask.adelaide.edu.au/app/answers/detail/a_id/1606/~/as-an-international-student,-what-happens-if-i-will-not-complete-my-degree-by)).

#### Compassionate and Compelling Circumstances

According to the University of Canberra and Charter Australia, compassionate or compelling circumstances are generally defined as events beyond the student's control that significantly affect their course progress or wellbeing ([Canberra University, n.d.a](https://www.canberra.edu.au/current-students/international-students/current-international-students/accordions/intermissions); [Charter Australia, n.d.a](https://charter.edu.au/policies/deferment-suspension-and-cancellation-international-students)). These circumstances can include:

*   **Serious illness or injury:** A medical certificate is required to verify that the student was unable to attend classes due to their condition ([Canberra University, n.d.a](https://www.canberra.edu.au/current-students/international-students/current-international-students/accordions/intermissions); [Charter Australia, n.d.a](https://charter.edu.au/policies/deferment-suspension-and-cancellation-international-students)).
*   **Bereavement of close family members:** A death certificate should be provided if possible ([Canberra University, n.d.a](https://www.canberra.edu.au/current-students/international-students/current-international-students/accordions/intermissions); [Charter Australia, n.d.a](https://charter.edu.au/policies/deferment-suspension-and-cancellation-international-students)).
*   **Major political upheaval or natural disaster in the home country:** Emergency travel may be required, impacting the student's studies ([Canberra University, n.d.a](https://www.canberra.edu.au/current-students/international-students/current-international-students/accordions/intermissions); [Charter Australia, n.d.a](https://charter.edu.au/policies/deferment-suspension-and-cancellation-international-students)).
*   **Traumatic experience:** Involvement in or witnessing a serious accident or crime can significantly impact a student's wellbeing ([Canberra University, n.d.a](https://www.canberra.edu.au/current-students/international-students/current-international-students/accordions/intermissions); [Charter Australia, n.d.a](https://charter.edu.au/policies/deferment-suspension-and-cancellation-international-students)). Police or psychologist reports may be required.

In the student's case, being admitted to the hospital for four weeks due to illness clearly falls under the category of "serious illness or injury," which constitutes a compassionate or compelling circumstance. This provides a strong basis for applying for a student visa extension.

#### Required Documentation

To support her application, the student should gather the following documents:

*   **Valid passport:** Essential for any visa-related process ([VisaVerge, n.d.a](https://www.visaverge.com/questions/guide-to-extending-your-student-visa-in-australia-step-by-step-process-for-australian-student-visa-extension)).
*   **Medical certificate/hospital records:** Documentation from the hospital confirming her admission and the duration of her stay ([Canberra University, n.d.a](https://www.canberra.edu.au/current-students/international-students/current-international-students/accordions/intermissions); [Charter Australia, n.d.a](https://charter.edu.au/policies/deferment-suspension-and-cancellation-international-students)).
*   **Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE):** A new CoE from the university indicating the extended duration of her studies ([VisaVerge, n.d.a](https://www.visaverge.com/questions/guide-to-extending-your-student-visa-in-australia-step-by-step-process-for-australian-student-visa-extension); [ACU International, n.d.](https://www.acu.edu.au/international-students/arriving-and-living-in-australia/applying-for-your-student-visa/extend-your-student-visa)).
*   **Evidence of sufficient funds:** Demonstrating the ability to cover tuition fees and living expenses for the additional semester ([VisaVerge, n.d.a](https://www.visaverge.com/questions/guide-to-extending-your-student-visa-in-australia-step-by-step-process-for-australian-student-visa-extension); [Victory Group, 2024](https://www.victorygroup.au/2024/12/22/student-visa-extension-australia-essential-steps-and-updates-for-2025/)). As of May 10, 2024, students must demonstrate access to at least AUD 29,710 to cover living expenses ([Victory Group, 2024](https://www.victorygroup.au/2024/12/22/student-visa-extension-australia-essential-steps-and-updates-for-2025/)).
*   **Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC):** Valid health insurance for the extended duration of her stay ([VisaVerge, n.d.a](https://www.visaverge.com/questions/guide-to-extending-your-student-visa-in-australia-step-by-step-process-for-australian-student-visa-extension); [ACU International, n.d.](https://www.acu.edu.au/international-students/arriving-and-living-in-australia/applying-for-your-student-visa/extend-your-student-visa)).
*   **Genuine Temporary Entrant (GTE) statement:** A statement explaining her reasons for needing the extension and her intention to return to her home country after completing her studies ([Victory Group, 2024](https://www.victorygroup.au/2024/12/22/student-visa-extension-australia-essential-steps-and-updates-for-2025/)).

#### Application Process

The student should follow these steps to apply for a student visa extension:

1.  **Extend OSHC:** Ensure her health cover aligns with her intended visa period ([Victory Group, 2024](https://www.victorygroup.au/2024/12/22/student-visa-extension-australia-essential-steps-and-updates-for-2025/)).
2.  **Obtain a new CoE:** Request this from her institution promptly ([Victory Group, 2024](https://www.victorygroup.au/2024/12/22/student-visa-extension-australia-essential-steps-and-updates-for-2025/)).
3.  **Prepare necessary documents:** Gather all the required documents mentioned above ([VisaVerge, n.d.a](https://www.visaverge.com/questions/guide-to-extending-your-student-visa-in-australia-step-by-step-process-for-australian-student-visa-extension); [Victory Group, 2024](https://www.victorygroup.au/2024/12/22/student-visa-extension-australia-essential-steps-and-updates-for-2025/)).
4.  **Submit the application via ImmiAccount:** Complete the online application through the Department of Home Affairs portal ([Victory Group, 2024](https://www.victorygroup.au/2024/12/22/student-visa-extension-australia-essential-steps-and-updates-for-2025/)).
5.  **Pay the application fee:** As of July 1, 2024, the fee is AUD 1,600 ([Victory Group, 2024](https://www.victorygroup.au/2024/12/22/student-visa-extension-australia-essential-steps-and-updates-for-2025/)).
6.  **Undergo health examinations:** If required, attend any medical checks promptly to avoid delays ([VisaFast, n.d.](https://www.visafast.com.au/blog/student-visa-7/student-visa-extension-australia-23); [Victory Group, 2024](https://www.victorygroup.au/2024/12/22/student-visa-extension-australia-essential-steps-and-updates-for-2025/)).

#### Potential Challenges and Mitigation

*   **Document delays:** Start gathering necessary documents early to avoid last-minute issues ([Victory Group, 2024](https://www.victorygroup.au/2024/12/22/student-visa-extension-australia-essential-steps-and-updates-for-2025/)).
*   **Financial proof:** Ensure bank statements or financial affidavits clearly demonstrate the required funds ([Victory Group, 2024](https://www.victorygroup.au/2024/12/22/student-visa-extension-australia-essential-steps-and-updates-for-2025/)).
*   **Application accuracy:** Double-check all information to prevent processing delays ([Victory Group, 2024](https://www.victorygroup.au/2024/12/22/student-visa-extension-australia-essential-steps-and-updates-for-2025/)).#### Bridging Visa

Processing times for visa extensions can vary, typically ranging from 4 to 6 weeks ([Victory Group, 2024](https://www.victorygroup.au/2024/12/22/student-visa-extension-australia-essential-steps-and-updates-for-2025/)). If the student's current visa expires before a decision is made, a Bridging Visa A (BVA) will allow her to remain in Australia lawfully during the processing period ([Victory Group, 2024](https://www.victorygroup.au/2024/12/22/student-visa-extension-australia-essential-steps-and-updates-for-2025/); [Isamigrations, n.d.a](https://www.isamigrations.com/blog/student-visa-extension-in-australia/)).

### Alternatives to Student Visa Extension

While a student visa extension is the most likely option, it's important to consider alternatives:

*   **Temporary Graduate Visa (Subclass 485):** If the student has completed at least two academic years of study in Australia, she may be eligible for a Temporary Graduate Visa, which allows her to stay and work in Australia for a period of time ([This Is Australia, 2025a](https://www.thisisaustralia.com/news/why-the-15th-march-student-visa-deadline-is-critical/); [Vision Consultants, n.d.](https://visionaus.com.au/march-15-the-expiry-date-for-many-australian-student-visas-what-you-need-to-know/)). However, given that she needs only one more semester to complete her degree, this option may not be the most suitable.
*   **Tourist Visa:** Applying for a tourist visa is not a viable option, as it only allows for a maximum of three months of study ([B2-4-the-migration-act-1958.md](b2-4-the-migration-act-1958.md); [B3-3-visitor-working-holiday-and-work-holiday-visas-and-study.md](b3-3-visitor-working-holiday-and-work-holiday-visas-and-study.md)). This is insufficient for completing a full semester of study.

### Conclusion

Based on the information available, the student **can apply for an extension to her student visa**. Her hospital admission constitutes a compassionate and compelling circumstance, making her eligible for an extension. She should gather all the necessary documents, including medical records, a new CoE, evidence of financial capacity, and OSHC, and submit her application through ImmiAccount. It is also advisable to contact the DHA to discuss her situation and seek guidance on the application process.

[https://www.canberra.edu.au/current-students/international-students/current-international-students/accordions/intermissions](https://www.canberra.edu.au/current-students/international-students/current-international-students/accordions/intermissions)

Charter Australia. (n.d.a). *Policy - Deferment, Suspension and Cancellation (International Students)*. [https://charter.edu.au/policies/deferment-suspension-and-cancellation-international-students](https://charter.edu.au/policies/deferment-suspension-and-cancellation-international-students)

question_results.question:
Which of the following statements is TRUE about student complaints?

Answer options:
A student must access the institution’s internal complaint process before they contact the OSO or State Ombudsman.
Students cannot complain about their agent to the OSO or State Ombudsman.
If a student contacts the OSO, the police will never investigate the complaint.
Students only the have the right to complain in certain, specified circumstances.
correct_answers: A student must access the institution’s internal complaint process before they contact the OSO or State Ombudsman.
extracted_answers: A student must access the institution’s internal complaint process before they contact the OSO or State Ombudsman.
question_results.full_response:
Here's a detailed report addressing the query about student complaints, incorporating the provided documents and adhering to the specified guidelines.

### Report on Student Complaint Processes and Regulations

**Introduction**

The landscape of higher education is increasingly focused on student rights and consumer protection. Ensuring that students have avenues to voice concerns and seek resolutions is paramount for maintaining institutional integrity and student satisfaction. This report examines the veracity of several statements regarding student complaints, drawing upon provided documentation and external web sources to provide a comprehensive analysis. The goal is to clarify the processes, rights, and limitations surrounding student complaints in educational settings.

**Analysis of Statements**

**Statement 1: A student must access the institution’s internal complaint process before they contact the OSO or State Ombudsman.**

This statement appears to be **TRUE**, based on the information available. Several documents emphasize the importance of exhausting internal institutional processes before seeking external intervention.

*   **Internal Complaint Procedures:** Wilkes University explicitly states that students "should first address any issues by contacting their instructor, if course-related, the program director or supervisor of the involved party" ([Student Complaint Process | Wilkes University](https://www.wilkes.edu/about-wilkes/accreditation-and-rankings/student-complaint-process.aspx)). If resolution cannot be achieved, students should follow the institutional process outlined in the Internal Complaint Procedure. Similarly, for distance education students, an additional process is afforded, but only after exhausting all institutional options ([Student Complaint Process | Wilkes University](https://www.wilkes.edu/about-wilkes/accreditation-and-rankings/student-complaint-process.aspx)).

*   **Federal Requirements:** WCET (the WICHE Cooperative for Educational Technologies) notes that institutions should "specifically indicate that the student must complete the institution’s own complaint process before seeking external resolution of the issue" ([Federal Student Complaint Requirements – Is Your Institution in Compliance Today? - WCET](https://wcet.wiche.edu/frontiers/2017/08/15/federal-student-complaint-requirement/)). This aligns with federal regulations requiring institutions to have a clear complaint process.

*   **Overseas Student Ombudsman (OSO):** The document "b10-3-student-complaints-and-appeals.md" states that the OSO may decide not to investigate a complaint if "the student has not complained to the education provider first" ([b10-3-student-complaints-and-appeals.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b10-3-student-complaints-and-appeals/)).

This requirement ensures that institutions have the first opportunity to address and rectify issues, promoting internal accountability and resolution mechanisms.

**Statement 2: Students cannot complain about their agent to the OSO or State Ombudsman.**

This statement is **FALSE**. The provided document "b10-3-student-complaints-and-appeals.md" explicitly mentions that students do complain about their agents. Common complaints include:

*   Giving false or misleading advice about a course or provider.
*   Enrolling a student with one provider while telling the student they had been enrolled with a different provider.
*   Accepting tuition fees before the student signed the written agreement.
*   Failing to pass on tuition fees to the provider.
*   Failing to give the student a copy of the written agreement, with the refund policy, so the student is unaware of their rights.
*   Receiving a refund on behalf of a student when not authorized to do so in the student’s written agreement with the provider.
*   Receiving a refund on behalf of a student when authorized to do so but then failing to give the refund to the student ([b10-3-student-complaints-and-appeals.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b10-3-student-complaints-and-appeals/)).

These complaints highlight the potential for agents to act unethically or provide misleading information, necessitating avenues for students to seek redress.

**Statement 3: If a student contacts the OSO, the police will never investigate the complaint.**

This statement is **FALSE**. The OSO process and police investigations are not mutually exclusive. The document "b10-3-student-complaints-and-appeals.md" indicates that the Ombudsman may decide not to investigate a complaint if "another organization is better able to deal with the complaint (e.g. the police if it is a criminal matter)" ([b10-3-student-complaints-and-appeals.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b10-3-student-complaints-and-appeals/)).

Additionally, document "c8-extension-useful-information.md" mentions that police units may be specifically set up to handle crime and serious issues relating to international students, such as violence, extortion, and kidnapping ([c8-extension-useful-information.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/c8-extension-useful-information/)).

If a complaint involves criminal activity, it is appropriate and necessary for the police to investigate, regardless of whether the student has also contacted the OSO. The OSO focuses on resolving disputes related to education services, while the police address criminal violations.

**Statement 4: Students only have the right to complain in certain, specified circumstances.**

This statement is **FALSE**. While there are common categories of complaints, students have the right to complain if they believe the education provider has not followed the rules correctly or treated them fairly ([b10-3-student-complaints-and-appeals.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b10-3-student-complaints-and-appeals/)). The common complaints according to the OSO are:

1.  Refund & fee disputes (28%)
2.  Transfer/release letter external appeals (16%)
3.  Unsatisfactory attendance external appeals (11%)
4.  Unsatisfactory course progress external appeals (9%) ([b10-3-student-complaints-and-appeals.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b10-3-student-complaints-and-appeals/)).

Complaints might also be about:

*   Being refused admission to a course
*   Course fees and due dates
*   Graduation/completion certificates/academic transcripts
*   Cancellation of enrolment
*   Accommodation or work arranged by a provider
*   Incorrect advice given by a provider’s agent
*   Inaction or delay, for example, failure by a provider to issue student results within the normal timeframes, or failure to provide services that were included in the student’s written agreement with the education provider ([b10-3-student-complaints-and-appeals.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b10-3-student-complaints-and-appeals/)).

Moreover, institutions like American Public University System (APUS) are committed to an environment where open, honest communications are the expectation, not the exception ([University General Grievance Procedure | Student Handbook American Public University | American Public University](https://www.apu.apus.edu/student-handbook/university-policies-and-code-of-conduct/apus-consumer-information/university-general-grievance-procedure/)). They encourage students to approach University faculty and staff in instances where it is believed violations of policies or standards have occurred.

The right to complain extends to any situation where a student reasonably believes they have been treated unfairly or that the provider has not met its obligations.

**Additional Considerations**

*   **Time Limitations:** The OSO does not investigate complaints where a student took more than 12 months to complain ([b10-3-student-complaints-and-appeals.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b10-3-student-complaints-and-appeals/)). This highlights the importance of addressing issues promptly.

*   **Ombudsman Role:** A student loan ombudsman is an independent and confidential resource that helps with student loans and sometimes federal financial aid concerns ([How To Work With A Student Loan Ombudsman – Forbes Advisor](https://www.forbes.com/advisor/student-loans/work-with-a-student-loan-ombudsman/)). The ombudsman can help resolve disputes, review collections, and explain repayment options.

*   **Complaint Resolution:** At the end of an investigation, the Ombudsman may conclude that the provider has not acted unreasonably, or may recommend that a provider remedy the problem by apologising, reconsidering a decision, providing a refund, providing clearer information, or changing a policy or procedure ([b10-3-student-complaints-and-appeals.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b10-3-student-complaints-and-appeals/)).

**Conclusion**

In summary, the analysis reveals that:

*   Students are generally required to exhaust internal complaint processes before seeking external resolution.
*   Students can indeed complain about their agents to the OSO or State Ombudsman.
*   Contacting the OSO does not preclude police investigation if criminal activity is suspected.
*   Students have broad rights to complain about unfair treatment or breaches of obligation, not limited to specified circumstances.

Understanding these aspects of the student complaint landscape is crucial for educational institutions, agents, and students alike. By adhering to established processes and respecting student rights, institutions can foster a fair and supportive learning environment.

**References***   b10-1-what-should-an-agent-know-about-privacy.md ([b10-1-what-should-an-agent-know-about-privacy.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b10-1-what-should-an-agent-know-about-privacy/))
*   b10-2-when-is-privacy-a-concern.md ([b10-2-when-is-privacy-a-concern.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b10-2-when-is-privacy-a-concern/))
*   b10-3-student-complaints-and-appeals.md ([b10-3-student-complaints-and-appeals.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b10-3-student-complaints-and-appeals/))
*   b10-privacy-student-complaints-and-appeals.md ([b10-privacy-student-complaints-and-appeals.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b10-privacy-student-complaints-and-appeals/))
*   b11-extension-agency-agreements-and-commission.md ([b11-extension-agency-agreements-and-commission.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b11-extension-agency-agreements-and-commission/))
*   b2-1-the-esos-act.md ([b2-1-the-esos-act.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b2-1-the-esos-act/))
*   b3-2-protection-for-international-students.md ([b3-2-protection-for-international-students.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b3-2-protection-for-international-students/))
*   b4-1-national-code-standards.md ([b4-1-national-code-standards.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b4-1-national-code-standards/))
*   b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions/))
*   c2-4-roles-international-student-support.md ([c2-4-roles-international-student-support.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/c2-4-roles-international-student-support/))
*   c4-2-people.md ([c4-2-people.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/c4-2-people/))
*   c8-extension-useful-information.md ([c8-extension-useful-information.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/c8-extension-useful-information/))
*   d3-6-student-management.md ([d3-6-student-management.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/d3-6-student-management/))
*   Student Complaint Process | Wilkes University ([Student Complaint Process | Wilkes University](https://www.wilkes.edu/about-wilkes/accreditation-and-rankings/student-complaint-process.aspx))
*   Federal Student Complaint Requirements – Is Your Institution in Compliance Today? - WCET ([Federal Student Complaint Requirements – Is Your Institution in Compliance Today? - WCET](https://wcet.wiche.edu/frontiers/2017/08/15/federal-student-complaint-requirement/))
*   How To Work With A Student Loan Ombudsman – Forbes Advisor ([How To Work With A Student Loan Ombudsman – Forbes Advisor](https://www.forbes.com/advisor/student-loans/work-with-a-student-loan-ombudsman/))
*   Department of Education Complaints - Student Loan Borrowers Assistance ([Department of Education Complaints - Student Loan Borrowers Assistance](https://studentloanborrowerassistance.org/for-borrowers/find-help/file-complaints/department-of-education-complaints/))
*   File Complaints - Student Loan Borrowers Assistance ([File Complaints - Student Loan Borrowers Assistance](https://studentloanborrowerassistance.org/for-borrowers/find-help/file-complaints/))
*   Complaint : Student Conduct ([Complaint : Student Conduct](https://studentconduct.osu.edu/complaint))
*   Student Consumer Complaint Process - Student Right to Know Act - Santa Clara University ([Student Consumer Complaint Process - Student Right to Know Act - Santa Clara University](https://www.scu.edu/student-right-to-know-act/student-consumer-complaint-process/))
*   University General Grievance Procedure | Student Handbook American Public University | American Public University ([University General Grievance Procedure | Student Handbook American Public University | American Public University](https://www.apu.apus.edu/student-handbook/university-policies-and-code-of-conduct/apus-consumer-information/university-general-grievance-procedure/))
*   How to Deal with Student Complaints: The Gap Between Stimulus and Response - Higher Ed Professor ([How to Deal with Student Complaints: The Gap Between Stimulus and Response - Higher Ed Professor](https://higheredprofessor.com/2015/03/26/how-to-deal-with-student-complaints/))

question_results.question:
Which of the following proposed course changes might require a student to obtain a new visa?

Answer options:
The student is studying in a Foundation program and wishes to change to a Bachelor of Business.
The student is studying in a Bachelor of Business and wishes to change to a Certificate IV of Business.
The student wishes to change from one undergraduate program to another undergraduate program.
The student is studying in an ELICOS program and wishes to change to Diploma in Business.
correct_answers: The student is studying in a Bachelor of Business and wishes to change to a Certificate IV of Business.
extracted_answers: The student is studying in a Bachelor of Business and wishes to change to a Certificate IV of Business.
question_results.full_response:
## Report on Student Visa Requirements for Course Changes in Australia

**Introduction**

This report addresses the question of which proposed course changes might require an international student in Australia to obtain a new visa. The information is based on Australian student visa regulations, particularly those related to the Australian Qualifications Framework (AQF) and visa conditions. Recent updates and changes to visa policies, especially those implemented in 2024 and 2025, are also considered to provide a comprehensive overview. The report aims to provide clarity on the circumstances under which a student visa holder needs to apply for a new visa due to changes in their course of study.

**Overview of Student Visa Regulations**

Australia's student visa program is governed by specific regulations designed to ensure that international students are genuine and maintain appropriate enrollment levels. The primary visa for international students is the Student visa (subclass 500) ([b1-overview.md](b1-overview.md)). A key condition for this visa is that students must maintain enrollment at the same or a higher AQF level for which their visa was granted ([b1-overview.md](b1-overview.md), [b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md)).

The AQF is a national system of learning pathways that provides a clear structure for the level of each qualification ([a3-2-the-australian-qualifications-framework-aqf.md](a3-2-the-australian-qualifications-framework-aqf.md)). It allows students to progress from lower to higher levels and ensures that educational institutions understand the level of qualifications awarded by others ([a3-2-the-australian-qualifications-framework-aqf.md](a3-2-the-australian-qualifications-framework-aqf.md)).

**Analysis of Course Change Scenarios**

To determine which course changes necessitate a new visa, each scenario provided will be analyzed based on AQF levels and visa regulations.

1.  **Foundation Program to Bachelor of Business:**

    *   Foundation programs are generally considered non-AQF courses ([a3-2-the-australian-qualifications-framework-aqf.md](a3-2-the-australian-qualifications-framework-aqf.md)).
    *   A Bachelor of Business is an AQF level 7 qualification.
    *   Changing from a non-AQF course to an AQF course is generally acceptable and does not typically require a new visa ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md)).
    *   Therefore, a student moving from a Foundation program to a Bachelor of Business would likely **not** need a new visa, provided they meet the entry requirements for the Bachelor program and the visa remains valid.

2.  **Bachelor of Business to Certificate IV of Business:**

    *   A Bachelor of Business is an AQF level 7 qualification.
    *   A Certificate IV is an AQF level 4 qualification.
    *   Changing to a lower AQF level course is a breach of the student visa condition and may result in visa cancellation ([b1-overview.md](b1-overview.md), [b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md)).
    *   Therefore, a student changing from a Bachelor of Business to a Certificate IV of Business **would** need to apply for a new Student visa ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md)).

3.  **Undergraduate Program to Another Undergraduate Program:**

    *   Both programs are at the same AQF level (typically AQF level 7 for Bachelor degrees).
    *   If a student wants to stay at the same institution but wants to change courses with the same AQF level they will not require a new student visa ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md)).
    *   If the new course is longer than the original course, the student should apply for a further Student visa before their visa expires ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md)).
    *   Therefore, a student changing from one undergraduate program to another **may not** need a new visa, unless the duration of the new course extends beyond the current visa's validity.

4.  **ELICOS Program to Diploma in Business:**

    *   ELICOS (English Language Intensive Courses for Overseas Students) programs are generally considered non-AQF courses ([a3-2-the-australian-qualifications-framework-aqf.md](a3-2-the-australian-qualifications-framework-aqf.md)).
    *   A Diploma in Business is an AQF level 5 qualification.
    *   Changing from a non-AQF course to an AQF course is generally acceptable and does not typically require a new visa ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md)).
    *   Therefore, a student moving from an ELICOS program to a Diploma in Business would likely **not** need a new visa, provided they meet the entry requirements for the Diploma program and the visa remains valid.

**Additional Considerations**

*   **Visa Duration:** If the new course is longer than the original course, the student should apply for a further Student visa before their visa expires ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md)).
*   **Six-Month Rule:** If a student has not completed six months of their principal course and wants to change education provider, they typically need permission from their current provider ([b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md](b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md)).
*   **Genuine Student (GS) Requirement:** As of March 23, 2024, the Genuine Temporary Entrant (GTE) requirement has been replaced by a new Genuine Student (GS) requirement ([b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md](b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md)). This involves answering targeted questions to assess the applicant's intentions and circumstances.
*   **Financial Capacity and English Proficiency:** While evidence of finance and English is not always required with the visa application, the Department of Home Affairs (DHA) retains the right to ask for financial evidence from any student if there is specific intelligence that suggests there may be a problem with the financial capacity of the student ([b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md](b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md)).
*   **English Language Proficiency:** The minimum English language proficiency requirement for student visas has increased, with a minimum IELTS score of 6.0 now required for most applicants ([b7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications.md](b7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications.md)).
*   **Visa Subclass 500:** International students apply for a single Student visa (subclass 500) regardless of their chosen course of study ([b1-overview.md](b1-overview.md)).

**Recent Changes and Updates**

Several changes have been implemented in recent years that affect student visa requirements:

*   **Increased English Language Requirements:** As of March 23, 2024, the minimum IELTS score for student visas increased from 5.5 to 6.0 ([migrationalliance.com.au](https://migrationalliance.com.au/immigration-daily-news/entry/2024-03-update-on-changes-esos-act-and-english-language-requirements.html), [blueskyconsultancy.com](https://blueskyconsultancy.com/australia-raises-the-bar-new-english-requirements-for-student-visa-and-temporary-graduate-visas/)). For packaged ELICOS courses, the requirement increased from 4.5 to 5.0 ([migrationalliance.com.au](https://migrationalliance.com.au/immigration-daily-news/entry/2024-03-update-on-changes-esos-act-and-english-language-requirements.html)).
*   **Genuine Student Requirement:** The GTE requirement has been replaced by the GS requirement, focusing on targeted questions to assess the genuineness of the student's intentions ([b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md](b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md)).
*   **Visa Application Fee:** As of July 1, 2024, the base application fee for student visas increased to AUD $1,600 ([b7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications.md](b7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications.md)).
*   **Limitations on Onshore Applications:** The updated policy restricts onshore applications for those on temporary visas unless they meet all requirements, including holding a Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE) ([visaverge.com](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/)).

**Conclusion**

Based on the analysis, the course change that would most likely require a student to obtain a new visa is:

*   **The student is studying in a Bachelor of Business and wishes to change to a Certificate IV of Business.**

This is because changing to a lower AQF level course is a breach of the student visa condition and may result in visa cancellation. The other scenarios, such as moving from a Foundation program to a Bachelor of Business, changing between undergraduate programs, or moving from an ELICOS program to a Diploma, generally do not require a new visa, provided the student meets the entry requirements for the new course and their visa remains valid.

It is crucial for international students to stay informed about the latest visa regulations and seek advice from registered migration agents or education providers to ensure compliance with visa conditions.

**References**
