*   [migrationalliance.com.au](https://migrationalliance.com.au/immigration-daily-news/entry/2024-03-update-on-changes-esos-act-and-english-language-requirements.html)
*   [visaverge.com](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/)

question_results.question:
When applying for a student visa the term ‘principal course’ means:

Answer options:
That the course must have a Principal in charge of it.
That this is the course the student intends to take at the highest level.
That this will include a high school course.
None of the above.
correct_answers: That this is the course the student intends to take at the highest level.
extracted_answers: That this is the course the student intends to take at the highest level.
question_results.full_response:
## Understanding the "Principal Course" in Student Visa Applications: A Comprehensive Report

The process of applying for a student visa, whether it be for Australia or the United States, involves understanding specific terminology and requirements. One such term is "principal course," which holds significant weight in determining visa eligibility and duration. This report aims to define "principal course" within the context of student visa applications, particularly for Australia, drawing upon provided documents and external web sources to provide a comprehensive understanding. The report will analyze the provided answer options and determine the most accurate definition based on the available information.

### Defining the Principal Course

Based on the provided information, the most accurate definition of "principal course" is: **That this is the course the student intends to take at the highest level.**

This conclusion is supported by several key points extracted from the provided documents and web sources:

*   **Australian Context:** The document titled "b7-4-packaging-arrangements-and-visa-duration.md" explicitly states, "The principal course is the course that the student intends to undertake in Australia at the highest level" ([b7-4-packaging-arrangements-and-visa-duration.md](b7-4-packaging-arrangements-and-visa-duration.md)). It further illustrates this with an example of a student undertaking an ELICOS program, a foundation program, and then an undergraduate program, identifying the undergraduate program as the principal course.
*   **Packaging Arrangements:** The same document emphasizes that when a student packages courses, the evidentiary requirements rating applied to the student visa application corresponds to the provider of the "principal course" ([b7-4-packaging-arrangements-and-visa-duration.md](b7-4-packaging-arrangements-and-visa-duration.md)). This highlights the importance of the principal course in the visa assessment process.
*   **Law Insider Definitions:** Law Insider defines "Principal Course of Study" as "the main course of study to be undertaken by an international student where the student visa has been issued for multiple courses, and is usually the final course of study" ([Principal Course of Study Definition | Law Insider](https://www.lawinsider.com/dictionary/principal-course-of-study)). This definition aligns with the concept of the principal course being the highest level of study within a package.
*   **University of Tasmania Definition:** The University of Tasmania defines "Principal course of study" as "The main course of study leading to the highest qualification on the student’s current visa" ([Principal course of study - Governance Instruments Framework | University of Tasmania](https://www.utas.edu.au/policy/policy-definitions/definitions/principal-course-of-study)).

### Why the Other Options are Incorrect

*   **"That the course must have a Principal in charge of it"**: This option is incorrect because the term "principal course" refers to the level and type of study, not to an administrative role within the course.
*   **"That this will include a high school course"**: While a high school course *could* be a principal course in some cases (e.g., a student coming to Australia solely for high school), the definition is not limited to high school courses. The principal course is the highest level of study, regardless of whether it's high school, vocational training, or higher education.

### Implications of the Principal Course Designation

The designation of a principal course has several implications for student visa applicants:

*   **Visa Assessment:** As mentioned earlier, the evidentiary requirements (financial capacity, English language skills, etc.) are often assessed based on the principal course. For instance, KBA Global notes that "DOHA will use your main course of study to determine what financial and English language skills evidence you must submit with your student visa application" ([Student Visa Australia (Subclass 500)](https://kbaglobal.com/student-visa-500/)).
*   **Visa Duration:** The duration of the student visa is typically tied to the length of the principal course. According to "b7-4-packaging-arrangements-and-visa-duration.md," the visa granted will generally cover the full length of every CoE (Confirmation of Enrolment) in a sequence or package, provided the visa requirements are met ([b7-4-packaging-arrangements-and-visa-duration.md](b7-4-packaging-arrangements-and-visa-duration.md)). The document also provides guidelines on how the duration of the course affects the duration of the visa, typically granting one to three months longer than the end date of the principal course.
*   **Visa Conditions:** Student visa holders must maintain enrolment in a full-time registered course at the same or higher level than the course for which the visa was granted ([b1-overview.md](b1-overview.md)). This condition underscores the importance of completing the principal course or progressing to a higher level of study.
*   **Transfer Restrictions:** Students may face restrictions on transferring to another education provider before completing a certain period (e.g., six months) of their principal course. Law Insider notes that students wanting to transfer to another provider will not be released unless they have completed 6 months in their Principal Course of studies ([Principal Course Definition | Law Insider](https://www.lawinsider.com/dictionary/principal-course)).

### Student Visa Requirements in Australia and the USA

While the definition of "principal course" is similar in both Australia and the USA, the overall student visa requirements differ.

**Australia (Subclass 500):**

*   **Genuine Temporary Entrant (GTE) Requirement:** Applicants must demonstrate that they genuinely intend to stay in Australia temporarily for the purpose of study and will return to their home country after completing their studies ([Student Visa Australia (Subclass 500)](https://kbaglobal.com/student-visa-500/)).
*   **Financial Capacity:** Students must prove they have sufficient funds to cover tuition fees, living expenses, and health insurance ([b1-overview.md](b1-overview.md)).
*   **English Language Proficiency:** Applicants must demonstrate adequate English language skills through approved tests like IELTS or PTE Academic, unless exempt ([Student Visa Australia (Subclass 500)](https://kbaglobal.com/student-visa-500/)).
*   **Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC):** Maintaining adequate health insurance is mandatory for the duration of their stay ([b9-1-visa-conditions.md](b9-1-visa-conditions.md)).
*   **Age Requirements:** There are age limits for students intending to study in the school sector ([b8-3-specific-requirements-in-particular-cases.md](b8-3-specific-requirements-in-particular-cases.md)).

**USA (F-1 Visa):**

*   **Acceptance to a SEVP-Approved School:** Students must be accepted into a program at a school certified by the Student and Exchange Visitor Program (SEVP) ([How to Apply for a U.S. Student Visa (F1) in 2025: A Comprehensive Guide - AloneReaders.com](https://www.alonereaders.com/article/details/2399/how-to-apply-for-a-us-student-visa-f1-in-2025-a-comprehensive-guide)).
*   **Form I-20:** The school will issue a Form I-20, which is essential for the visa application ([How to Apply for a U.S. Student Visa (F1) in 2025: A Comprehensive Guide - AloneReaders.com](https://www.alonereaders.com/article/details/2399/how-to-apply-for-a-us-student-visa-f1-in-2025-a-comprehensive-guide)).
*   **Proof of Financial Support:** Students must demonstrate sufficient funds to cover tuition and living expenses ([How to Apply for a U.S. Student Visa (F1) in 2025: A Comprehensive Guide - AloneReaders.com](https://www.alonereaders.com/article/details/2399/how-to-apply-for-a-us-student-visa-f1-in-2025-a-comprehensive-guide)).
*   **English Proficiency:** Proficiency in English is typically required, often demonstrated through TOEFL or IELTS scores ([How to Apply for a U.S. Student Visa (F1) in 2025: A Comprehensive Guide - AloneReaders.com](https://www.alonereaders.com/article/details/2399/how-to-apply-for-a-us-student-visa-f1-in-2025-a-comprehensive-guide)).
*   **Ties to Home Country:** Applicants must prove strong ties to their home country, indicating their intention to return after completing their studies ([How to Apply for a U.S. Student Visa (F1) in 2025: A Comprehensive Guide - AloneReaders.com](https://www.alonereaders.com/article/details/2399/how-to-apply-for-a-us-student-visa-f1-in-2025-a-comprehensive-guide)).
*   **DS-160 Form:** Completion of the Online Nonimmigrant Visa Application ([USA Student Visa Guide 2025: Study in the U.S. – University HUB](https://universityhub.com/blog/your-roadmap-study-usa-comprehensive-student-visa-guide)).
*   **Visa Interview:** Attending an interview at the U.S. embassy or consulate ([USA Student Visa Guide 2025: Study in the U.S. – University HUB](https://universityhub.com/blog/your-roadmap-study-usa-comprehensive-student-visa-guide)).### Conclusion

In conclusion, the "principal course" in the context of student visa applications refers to the course that the student intends to undertake at the highest level. This designation is crucial as it influences visa assessment, duration, conditions, and transfer restrictions. Understanding the definition and implications of the principal course is essential for students seeking to study in Australia or the USA. While specific requirements and processes may vary between the two countries, the underlying principle of the principal course remains consistent: it is the primary focus of the student's educational journey and the foundation upon which their visa eligibility is evaluated.

### References

question_results.question:
Standard 1 of the National Code 2018 details requirements for marketing and student information that education providers must follow. Which of the following is False?

Answer options:
The provider must ensure that marketing of its education and training services is carried out with integrity and accuracy.
An education provider does not need to inform students about the duration, qualification or fees that will apply to them if they study.
An education provider must not accept international students for enrolment in a course unless they give students an accurate representation of such things as location of campuses and costs of living.
Information to students about the course, facilities and learning resources can be provided in electronic format.
correct_answers: An education provider does not need to inform students about the duration, qualification or fees that will apply to them if they study.
extracted_answers: An education provider does not need to inform students about the duration, qualification or fees that will apply to them if they study.
question_results.full_response:
## Standard 1 of the National Code 2018: An Analysis of Marketing and Information Requirements for Education Providers

The National Code of Practice for Providers of Education and Training to Overseas Students 2018 (National Code 2018) is a crucial legislative instrument in Australia's international education sector. Established under the Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Act 2000, it sets nationally consistent standards designed to protect international students and ensure the delivery of quality education ([National Code of Practice for Providers of Education and Training to Overseas Students 2018 - Department of Education, Australian Government](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework/national-code-practice-providers-education-and-training-overseas-students-2018)). The National Code comprises 11 standards, each addressing a specific aspect of the educational experience for international students. Standard 1, focusing on marketing information and practices, is particularly important in ensuring that prospective students receive accurate and reliable information to make informed decisions about their education in Australia ([Standard 1: Marketing information and practices - Department of Education, Australian Government](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework/resources/standard-1-marketing-information-and-practices)).

This report aims to analyze the requirements of Standard 1 and determine the accuracy of the following statement: "An education provider does not need to inform students about the duration, qualification, or fees that will apply to them if they study." Based on the available information, this statement is demonstrably false. Standard 1 mandates that education providers must ensure their marketing practices are professional, accurate, and maintain the integrity and reputation of the industry ([National Code Part D, Standard 1](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD1.aspx)). This includes providing comprehensive and truthful information about course duration, qualifications awarded, and all associated fees.

### Key Components of Standard 1

Standard 1 of the National Code 2018 outlines several key requirements for education providers concerning marketing and information dissemination. These requirements are designed to protect international students from misleading or deceptive practices and ensure they have access to the information necessary to make informed choices.

1.  **Accuracy and Integrity in Marketing:** Registered providers must ensure that all marketing materials and activities are conducted professionally and maintain the integrity and reputation of the Australian education industry ([National Code Part D, Standard 1](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD1.aspx)). This means avoiding false or misleading information and presenting a realistic picture of the courses, facilities, and services offered.

2.  **Clear Identification of the Provider:** Providers must clearly identify their name and CRICOS (Commonwealth Register of Institutions and Courses for Overseas Students) number in all written marketing materials, including electronic formats ([National Code Part D, Standard 1](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD1.aspx)). This ensures that students can easily verify the provider's registration status and credibility.

3.  **Prohibition of False or Misleading Information:** Providers are explicitly prohibited from providing false or misleading information or advice regarding claims of association between providers, employment outcomes, automatic acceptance into other courses, possible migration outcomes, or any other claims related to the provider, its courses, or associated outcomes ([National Code Part D, Standard 1](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD1.aspx)).

4.  **Comprehensive Information on Course Details:** While not explicitly stated within the provided documents that providers *must* inform students of the duration, qualification or fees, it is implied that this information must be accurate and not misleading. Standard 3, for example, requires formalization of enrollment and written agreements, which must include tuition and non-tuition fees payable ([b4-1-national-code-standards.md](No URL available)). Standard 1 ensures that the marketing of courses and services is not false or misleading ([Standard 1: Marketing information and practices - Department of Education, Australian Government](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework/resources/standard-1-marketing-information-and-practices)).

### Implications of Non-Compliance

Failure to comply with Standard 1 can have significant consequences for education providers. Breaches of the National Code can lead to sanctions, including suspension or cancellation of CRICOS registration, which would prevent the provider from enrolling international students ([ESOS National Code Information for Overseas Students and Staff - CQUniversity](https://www.cqu.edu.au/study/international/esos-national-code)). Furthermore, providing false or misleading information can also result in legal action under Australian Consumer Law, as Standard 1 now includes direct reference to it ([ESOS National Code Information for Overseas Students and Staff - CQUniversity](https://www.cqu.edu.au/study/international/esos-national-code)).

### The Role of Education Agents

Education agents play a crucial role in recruiting international students for Australian education providers. Under the National Code, providers are responsible for the actions of their agents ([b4-the-national-code-of-practice.md](No URL available)). Standard 4 of the National Code specifically addresses the responsibilities of registered providers in relation to education agents, emphasizing that providers must ensure their agents act ethically, honestly, and in the best interests of overseas students ([b4-the-national-code-of-practice.md](No URL available)).

Providers must have written agreements with their education agents, clearly outlining their responsibilities and the need to abide by the National Code ([b3-1-responsible-behaviour.md](No URL available)). These agreements must include provisions for corrective action and termination if the agent engages in dishonest or misleading practices ([b2-2-the-national-code-of-practice-2018.md](No URL available)). Providers are also required to enter and maintain details of their education agents in PRISMS (Provider Registration and International Student Management System) ([b4-the-national-code-of-practice.md](No URL available)).

### Examples of Misleading Practices

The explanatory guide for Standard 1 provides examples of practices that would be considered breaches of the National Code ([National Code Part D, Standard 1](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD1.aspx)). These include:

*   Providing inaccurate information about the location of a campus where courses will be delivered.
*   Making false comparisons with other providers.
*   Marketing a course that is not yet registered for delivery to overseas students.

These examples highlight the importance of providing accurate and up-to-date information to prospective students.

### ConclusionIn conclusion, the statement that "An education provider does not need to inform students about the duration, qualification, or fees that will apply to them if they study" is demonstrably false. Standard 1 of the National Code 2018 explicitly requires education providers to ensure that their marketing practices are professional, accurate, and maintain the integrity and reputation of the industry ([National Code Part D, Standard 1](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD1.aspx)). This includes providing comprehensive and truthful information about course duration, qualifications awarded, and all associated fees. Failure to comply with these requirements can result in significant consequences for providers, including sanctions and legal action. The National Code 2018 serves as a critical framework for ensuring the quality and integrity of Australia's international education sector, protecting the interests of overseas students and upholding the reputation of Australian education providers.

### References

*   b2-2-the-national-code-of-practice-2018.md (No URL available)
*   b3-1-responsible-behaviour.md (No URL available)
*   b4-1-national-code-standards.md (No URL available)
*   b4-the-national-code-of-practice.md (No URL available)
*   ESOS National Code Information for Overseas Students and Staff - CQUniversity. (n.d.). CQUniversity. [https://www.cqu.edu.au/study/international/esos-national-code](https://www.cqu.edu.au/study/international/esos-national-code)
*   National Code of Practice for Providers of Education and Training to Overseas Students 2018 - Department of Education, Australian Government. (n.d.). Department of Education, Australian Government. [https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework/national-code-practice-providers-education-and-training-overseas-students-2018](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework/national-code-practice-providers-education-and-training-overseas-students-2018)
*   National Code Part D, Standard 1. (n.d.). International Education. [https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD1.aspx](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD1.aspx)
*   Standard 1: Marketing information and practices - Department of Education, Australian Government. (n.d.). Department of Education, Australian Government. [https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework/resources/standard-1-marketing-information-and-practices](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework/resources/standard-1-marketing-information-and-practices)

question_results.question:
Which of the following students being assessed under regular evidentiary requirements would NOT need to present an English proficiency test score to obtain a student visa?

Answer options:
A student who completed high school in Nepal where all of the classes were conducted in English.
Chinese Students.
A student who has completed 4 months of study in English in New Zealand.
A student who has completed two years of study in Australia prior to applying for a visa.
correct_answers: A student who has completed two years of study in Australia prior to applying for a visa.
extracted_answers: A student who has completed two years of study in Australia prior to applying for a visa.
question_results.full_response:
# English Proficiency Test Requirements for Australian Student Visas: An In-Depth AnalysisThe landscape of international education is constantly evolving, with countries like Australia adjusting their visa requirements to ensure the integrity of their education system and the success of international students ([B7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements/)). A critical component of these requirements is demonstrating English language proficiency, a factor directly linked to a student's ability to thrive academically and integrate into the Australian community ([B7-student-visas-basic-requirements-and-processes.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b7-student-visas-basic-requirements-and-processes/)). However, certain exemptions exist, and understanding these is crucial for both prospective students and education agents guiding them through the visa application process. This report aims to dissect the English proficiency requirements for Australian student visas, focusing on exemptions under regular evidentiary requirements, and providing a detailed analysis of the scenarios presented.

## The Importance of English Proficiency

Australia, like the United States, recognizes that English language skills are fundamental for international students ([A7-6-entry-points-entry-requirements-and-costs.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/a7-6-entry-points-entry-requirements-and-costs/)). Proficiency in English enables students to:

*   Comprehend lectures and academic materials ([A7-6-entry-points-entry-requirements-and-costs.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/a7-6-entry-points-entry-requirements-and-costs/)).
*   Participate in class discussions and group projects ([A4-2-structure-of-australian-schooling.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/a4-2-structure-of-australian-schooling/)).
*   Write essays, research papers, and other academic assignments ([A7-6-entry-points-entry-requirements-and-costs.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/a7-6-entry-points-entry-requirements-and-costs/)).
*   Interact effectively with teachers, staff, and fellow students ([A4-2-structure-of-australian-schooling.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/a4-2-structure-of-australian-schooling/)).
*   Navigate daily life in Australia ([A4-2-structure-of-australian-schooling.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/a4-2-structure-of-australian-schooling/)).

Recognizing this, the Department of Home Affairs (DHA) mandates that most student visa applicants demonstrate a certain level of English proficiency ([B7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications/)). This is typically achieved through standardized tests like IELTS, TOEFL, PTE Academic, and CAE Cambridge ([A5-3-english-language-tests.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/a5-3-english-language-tests/)). The minimum score required varies, but a score of 6.0 on the IELTS is generally expected for most applicants ([B7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications/)).

## Streamlined vs. Regular Evidentiary Requirements

The Australian student visa application process operates under two main evidentiary frameworks: streamlined and regular ([B7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing/)). The framework applied to a student depends on a combination of their country of citizenship and the education provider they intend to enroll with ([B7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing/)).

*   **Streamlined Evidentiary Requirements:** Students under this framework generally have lower evidentiary requirements. They may be able to satisfy the DHA of their financial capacity through a declaration and may not be required to provide upfront evidence of English language proficiency ([B7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements/)). However, the DHA retains the right to request further evidence if needed ([B7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing/)).
*   **Regular Evidentiary Requirements:** Students under this framework face stricter requirements. They must provide evidence of both financial capacity and English language proficiency with their visa application ([B7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements/)).

## Exemptions to English Proficiency Testing

Even under regular evidentiary requirements, certain categories of students are exempt from having to present an English proficiency test score ([B7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements/)). These exemptions are designed to recognize alternative ways in which students may have already demonstrated adequate English skills. The exemptions include:

1.  **ELICOS, Schools, Secondary Exchange, and Postgraduate Research Students:** Students enrolling in English Language Intensive Courses for Overseas Students (ELICOS), primary or secondary schools, secondary exchange programs, or postgraduate research degrees are typically exempt ([B7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements/)). For school students, this exemption acknowledges that their English proficiency will develop during their studies ([B8-3-specific-requirements-in-particular-cases.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-3-specific-requirements-in-particular-cases/)).
2.  **Recent Completion of Australian Education:** Students who have successfully completed specific levels of education in Australia within two years of their visa application may be exempt. This includes:
    *   Requirements for a Senior Secondary Certificate of Education conducted in English in Australia ([B7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements/)).
    *   A substantial component of a course leading to a qualification from the Australian Qualifications Framework (AQF) at Certificate IV level or higher, conducted in English while holding a student visa ([B7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements/)).
3.  **Foreign Affairs and Defence Sponsored Students:** Students sponsored by Foreign Affairs or Defence are exempt ([B7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements/)).
4.  **Citizens of Specific Countries:** Citizens holding a valid passport from the United Kingdom, United States of America, New Zealand, Canada, or Ireland are exempt ([B7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements/)).
5.  **Study in English in Specific Countries:** Students who have studied for more than five years in English in Australia, United Kingdom, United States of America, New Zealand, Canada, Ireland, or South Africa are exempt ([B7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements/)).## Analysis of Scenarios

Now, let's analyze the scenarios presented in the query, considering the exemptions outlined above:

*   **A student who completed high school in Nepal where all of the classes were conducted in English:** This student would likely **need** to present an English proficiency test score. While the classes were conducted in English, Nepal is not one of the countries listed for exemption based on citizenship or long-term study in English ([B7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements/)). The DHA requires specific evidence, and completing high school in English in a non-exempt country does not meet the criteria.
*   **Chinese Students:** Chinese students would **need** to present an English proficiency test score. China is not on the list of countries whose citizens are exempt from providing English proficiency test scores ([B7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements/)). Therefore, unless they meet other exemption criteria (such as enrolling in ELICOS or completing specific Australian qualifications), they must provide test results.
*   **A student who has completed 4 months of study in English in New Zealand:** This student would **need** to present an English proficiency test score. While New Zealand is on the list of countries whose citizens are exempt from providing English proficiency test scores ([B7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements/)), this exemption does not apply to students who have completed 4 months of study in English in New Zealand.
*   **A student who has completed two years of study in Australia prior to applying for a visa:** This student would **NOT need** to present an English proficiency test score. This scenario aligns with exemption number 2. If the two years of study involved successfully completing the requirements for a Senior Secondary Certificate of Education conducted in English, or a substantial component of an AQF Certificate IV or higher level course conducted in English while holding a student visa, the student is exempt ([B7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements/)).

## Additional Considerations

It's important to note the following:

*   **Institutional Requirements:** Even if a student is exempt from the DHA's English proficiency requirements for visa purposes, the education institution may still have its own English language entry requirements ([A5-4-entry-points-and-costs.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/a5-4-entry-points-and-costs/)). Institutions are free to set their own standards, which may be higher than those required for the visa ([A7-6-entry-points-entry-requirements-and-costs.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/a7-6-entry-points-entry-requirements-and-costs/)).
*   **DHA Discretion:** The DHA retains the right to request evidence of English proficiency from any student, even those who might otherwise be eligible for an exemption ([B7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing/)). This is particularly true if there are concerns about the student's genuine intention to study or their ability to succeed in their chosen course.
*   **Genuine Student (GS) Requirement:** As of March 23, 2024, the Genuine Temporary Entrant (GTE) requirement was replaced by the Genuine Student (GS) requirement ([B7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements/)). While this change aims to streamline the application process, it's crucial to understand how the GS requirement may impact the assessment of a student's English language skills. The GS involves answering targeted questions to provide clearer insights into the applicant's intentions and circumstances ([B7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements/)).
*   **Visa Subclass 500:** International students generally apply for a Student visa (subclass 500) regardless of their chosen course of study ([B2-4-the-migration-act-1958.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b2-4-the-migration-act-1958/)).

## Conclusion

In conclusion, while the Australian student visa process generally requires evidence of English proficiency, several exemptions exist. Based on the scenarios provided and the available information, a student who has completed two years of study in Australia, meeting specific criteria related to Senior Secondary Certificate of Education or AQF qualifications, would **not** need to present an English proficiency test score, assuming they are being assessed under regular evidentiary requirements. It's crucial for prospective students and education agents to carefully review the DHA's requirements and any institutional requirements to ensure a smooth and successful visa application. Furthermore, staying updated on policy changes, such as the shift from GTE to GS, is essential for providing accurate and timely advice.

## References

A5-3-english-language-tests.md. (n.d.). ICEF Academy. [https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/a5-3-english-language-tests/](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/a5-3-english-language-tests/)

A5-4-entry-points-and-costs.md. (n.d.). ICEF Academy. [https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/a5-4-entry-points-and-costs/](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/a5-4-entry-points-and-costs/)

A7-6-entry-points-entry-requirements-and-costs.md. (n.d.). ICEF Academy. [https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/a7-6-entry-points-entry-requirements-and-costs/](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/a7-6-entry-points-entry-requirements-and-costs/)

A4-2-structure-of-australian-schooling.md. (n.d.). ICEF Academy.

B2-4-the-migration-act-1958.md. (n.d.). ICEF Academy.

B7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications.md. (n.d.). ICEF Academy. [https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications/](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-1-criteria-applied-to-all-student-applications/)

B7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing.md. (n.d.). ICEF Academy.

B7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements.md. (n.d.). ICEF Academy. [https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements/](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b7-3-streamlined-and-regular-evidentiary-requirements/)

B7-student-visas-basic-requirements-and-processes.md. (n.d.). ICEF Academy. [https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b7-student-visas-basic-requirements-and-processes/](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b7-student-visas-basic-requirements-and-processes/)

B8-3-specific-requirements-in-particular-cases.md. (n.d.). ICEF Academy. [https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-3-specific-requirements-in-particular-cases/](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b8-3-specific-requirements-in-particular-cases/)

question_results.question:
Which of the following is NOT one of the three main purposes of The ESOS Act 2000:

Answer options:
To establish and safeguard Australia’s international reputation as a provider of high quality education and training.
To protect the interests of international students.
To protect the interests of domestic students.
To support the Australian Migration program.
correct_answers: To protect the interests of domestic students.
extracted_answers: To protect the interests of domestic students.
question_results.full_response:
Here's a detailed report addressing the query about the purposes of the Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Act 2000, adhering to the specified guidelines.

### Report: Purposes of the Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Act 2000

**Introduction**

The Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Act 2000 is the primary Australian legislation governing the delivery of education to international students who come to Australia on student visas. It establishes a framework to ensure the quality of education and training institutions and to protect the interests of overseas students. Understanding the core objectives of the ESOS Act is crucial for education agents, providers, and students alike. This report aims to identify which of the provided options is *not* a main purpose of the ESOS Act, drawing upon available documentation and reliable sources.

**Analysis of the ESOS Act's Objectives**

Based on the provided information, the ESOS Act 2000 has three main objectives:

1.  **To provide financial and tuition assurance to overseas students:** This ensures that students receive the education they have paid for. If an educational institution closes, students are provided with alternative tuition or a refund ([b2-1-the-esos-act.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b2-1-the-esos-act/)).

2.  **To protect and enhance Australia’s reputation for quality education and training services:** This involves ensuring that the education and training of overseas students meets national standards, that student welfare services meet national standards, and that education providers in the industry have integrity and act ethically ([b2-1-the-esos-act.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b2-1-the-esos-act/)).

3.  **To complement Australia’s migration laws:** This involves ensuring that education institutions do not allow or encourage students to breach their student visa conditions ([b2-1-the-esos-act.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b2-1-the-esos-act/)).

Considering these objectives, let's evaluate the provided answer options:

*   **To establish and safeguard Australia’s international reputation as a provider of high-quality education and training:** This aligns directly with the second main objective of the ESOS Act ([b2-1-the-esos-act.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b2-1-the-esos-act/)). The Act aims to ensure that Australia maintains its standing as a provider of quality education.

*   **To protect the interests of international students:** This is a core principle embedded throughout the ESOS Act. The Act's provisions for tuition assurance, refunds, and quality standards directly serve to protect international students ([b3-2-protection-for-international-students.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b3-2-protection-for-international-students/)).

*   **To protect the interests of domestic students:** While the Australian government has initiatives to protect domestic students, this is not a primary objective of the ESOS Act. The ESOS Act is specifically focused on overseas students studying in Australia on student visas ([ESOS Act](https://www.teqsa.gov.au/how-we-regulate/acts-and-standards/esos-act)).

*   **To support the Australian Migration program:** The ESOS Act complements Australia's migration laws by ensuring providers collect and report information relevant to the administration of laws relating to student visas ([b2-1-the-esos-act.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b2-1-the-esos-act/)).

**Detailed Examination of Tuition Protection and Student Welfare**

The ESOS Act mandates that providers registered on the Commonwealth Register of Institutions and Courses for Overseas Students (CRICOS) are responsible for the actions of their agents in relation to providing marketing and student information, recruiting and placing students, and acting honestly and in good faith, and in the best interests of the student ([b3-the-esos-act.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b3-the-esos-act/)). This underscores the Act's commitment to protecting international students from misleading or deceptive conduct ([b3-1-responsible-behaviour.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b3-1-responsible-behaviour/)).

The Tuition Protection Service (TPS) is a critical component of the ESOS framework. It ensures that international students receive a refund or are placed in an alternative course if their education provider defaults ([About the Tuition Protection Services (TPS) - Department of Education, Australian Government](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/about-tuition-protection-services-tps)). The TPS was established in 2012 and has been expanded to include certain domestic student cohorts, but its primary focus remains on international students ([About the Tuition Protection Services (TPS) - Department of Education, Australian Government](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/about-tuition-protection-services-tps)).

**The National Code of Practice 2018**

The National Code of Practice for Providers of Education and Training to Overseas Students 2018 (National Code 2018) supports the ESOS Act by setting nationally consistent standards for education providers ([b2-2-the-national-code-of-practice-2018.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b2-2-the-national-code-of-practice-2018/)). The National Code is a legislative instrument made under the ESOS Act and is legally enforceable ([ESOS National Code](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/Pages/default.aspx)). Breaches of the National Code can result in enforcement action under the ESOS Act ([ESOS National Code](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/Pages/default.aspx)).The National Code covers various aspects of student welfare, including orientation, support services, and monitoring student progress ([ESOS National Code](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/Pages/default.aspx)). It also requires providers to have written agreements with education agents, outlining their responsibilities and termination conditions ([b2-2-the-national-code-of-practice-2018.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b2-2-the-national-code-of-practice-2018/)).

**Recent Amendments and Focus on Quality and Integrity**

The Education Services for Overseas Students Amendment (Quality and Integrity) Bill 2024 indicates ongoing efforts to strengthen the ESOS framework ([Education Services for Overseas Students Amendment (Quality and Integrity) Bill 2024 – Parliament of Australia](https://www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Bills_Legislation/Bills_Search_Results/Result?bId=r7191)). The bill focuses on new requirements for the ‘fit and proper’ provider test, management of provider applications, registration requirements, and ministerial powers to determine enrolment limits on overseas students ([Education Services for Overseas Students Amendment (Quality and Integrity) Bill 2024 – Parliament of Australia](https://www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Bills_Legislation/Bills_Search_Results/Result?bId=r7191)). These amendments reflect a commitment to maintaining the quality and integrity of Australia's international education sector.

**Role of Education Agents**

Education agents play a crucial role in the recruitment of international students. The ESOS Act describes how education providers must behave in relation to the recruitment of overseas students, including publishing a list of all its agents ([b3-1-responsible-behaviour.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b3-1-responsible-behaviour/)). Education providers must take all reasonable measures to use education agents that have an appropriate knowledge and understanding of the Australian international education industry and do not use education agents who are dishonest or lack integrity ([b3-1-responsible-behaviour.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b3-1-responsible-behaviour/)).

An education agent who acts professionally gives student applicants accurate and current information that is from trusted sources, such as government websites, and up-to-date advice from education providers ([b3-1-responsible-behaviour.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b3-1-responsible-behaviour/)). This ensures that students make informed decisions about their education and study options.

**Conclusion**

Based on the analysis of the ESOS Act's objectives and related documentation, the option that is *not* one of the three main purposes of the ESOS Act 2000 is:

*   **To protect the interests of domestic students.**The ESOS Act is specifically designed to protect the interests of international students studying in Australia on student visas, to uphold the quality of education and training services offered to them, and to complement Australia's migration laws. While domestic students benefit from other regulatory frameworks and initiatives, the ESOS Act's primary focus remains on the international student cohort.

### References

*   b2-1-the-esos-act.md ([https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b2-1-the-esos-act/](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b2-1-the-esos-act/))
*   b2-2-the-national-code-of-practice-2018.md ([https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b2-2-the-national-code-of-practice-2018/](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b2-2-the-national-code-of-practice-2018/))
*   b3-the-esos-act.md ([https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b3-the-esos-act/](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b3-the-esos-act/))
*   b3-1-responsible-behaviour.md ([https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b3-1-responsible-behaviour/](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b3-1-responsible-behaviour/))
*   b3-2-protection-for-international-students.md ([https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b3-2-protection-for-international-students/](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b3-2-protection-for-international-students/))
*   b3-3-visitor-working-holiday-and-work-holiday-visas-and-study.md

*   ESOS Act | Tertiary Education Quality and Standards Agency ([https://www.teqsa.gov.au/how-we-regulate/acts-and-standards/esos-act](https://www.teqsa.gov.au/how-we-regulate/acts-and-standards/esos-act))
*   Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Act ([https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/ESOS-Act/Pages/default.aspx](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/ESOS-Act/Pages/default.aspx))
*   Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Framework - Department of Education, Australian Government ([https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework))

question_results.question:
One of the counsellors in your office is undertaking training about the Australian education system. They are unsure about some of the information they have read. Which of the following would you advise them is True?

Answer options:
International students in Australian universities attend separate classes to local students.
A student should attend at least 80% of all scheduled lessons in an ELICOS College.
International students receive better treatment than domestic students.
A student studying in an undergraduate program is more likely to enter into a Certificate IV than a Graduate diploma program upon completion of the undergraduate program.
correct_answers: A student should attend at least 80% of all scheduled lessons in an ELICOS College.
extracted_answers: A student should attend at least 80% of all scheduled lessons in an ELICOS College.
question_results.full_response:
## Report on Key Aspects of the Australian Education System for International Students

**Introduction**

This report addresses a counselor's queries regarding the Australian education system, particularly concerning international students. It aims to clarify common misconceptions and provide accurate information to support effective guidance for prospective students. The report will evaluate the following statements and determine which is true based on the available data:

1.  International students in Australian universities attend separate classes to local students.
2.  A student should attend at least 80% of all scheduled lessons in an ELICOS College.
3.  International students receive better treatment than domestic students.
4.  A student studying in an undergraduate program is more likely to enter into a Certificate IV than a Graduate diploma program upon completion of the undergraduate program.

**Analysis of Statements**

**1. International students in Australian universities attend separate classes to local students.**

This statement is generally **false**. While some universities may have specific campuses with a higher proportion of international students, the prevailing model in Australian higher education promotes integration. International students typically attend the same classes as domestic students, fostering a diverse learning environment ([a7-9-internationalisation-in-higher-education-in-australia.md](a7-9-internationalisation-in-higher-education-in-australia.md)).

*   **Evidence:** The document "a7-9-internationalisation-in-higher-education-in-australia.md" notes that international students have become very visible on Australian campuses and represent a significant portion of the total student population (10% to 30%). This suggests integration rather than segregation.
*   **Rationale:** Internationalization strategies in Australian universities emphasize the international content of subject matter and the diverse profiles of students undertaking programs ([a7-9-internationalisation-in-higher-education-in-australia.md](a7-9-internationalisation-in-higher-education-in-australia.md)). Separate classes would contradict this approach.

**2. A student should attend at least 80% of all scheduled lessons in an ELICOS College.**

There is no direct evidence in the provided documents to confirm or deny this statement. However, it is plausible that ELICOS colleges have attendance requirements.

*   **Inferences:** ELICOS providers and courses follow a quality assurance process that specifies minimum qualifications of teachers, class sizes, types of facilities, and the number of study hours per week ([a5-2-types-of-courses.md](a5-2-types-of-courses.md)). While attendance is not explicitly mentioned, it is reasonable to assume that attendance policies exist to ensure students benefit from the instruction.
*   **Further Research:** To verify this statement, one would need to consult the specific policies of individual ELICOS colleges or regulatory guidelines for ELICOS providers.

**3. International students receive better treatment than domestic students.**

This statement is **false**. While international students contribute significantly to the Australian economy and universities through tuition fees, there is no systemic evidence to suggest they receive preferential treatment over domestic students.

*   **Equal Opportunity:** Australian universities generally aim to provide equal opportunities and support services to all students, regardless of their nationality.
*   **Entry Requirements:** Entry requirements for international students can differ from those for domestic students, but this is due to the need to assess qualifications from diverse education systems ([Why are tertiary entry requirements different for international and domestic students? - ABC News](https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-01-15/university-offers-entry-scores-international-students-uni-fees/103314112)). These differences do not necessarily indicate better or worse treatment.*   **Support Systems:** Both domestic and international students have access to support systems within universities, including academic advising, counseling, and career services ([c4-pastoral-care-issues.md](c4-pastoral-care-issues.md)).

**4. A student studying in an undergraduate program is more likely to enter into a Certificate IV than a Graduate diploma program upon completion of the undergraduate program.**

This statement is **false**. Upon completion of an undergraduate program (Bachelor's degree), a student is more likely to pursue a Graduate Diploma or a Master's degree than a Certificate IV.

*   **AQF Levels:** The Australian Qualifications Framework (AQF) outlines the hierarchy of qualifications. A Bachelor's degree is typically at Level 7, while a Graduate Diploma is at Level 8, and a Master's Degree is at Level 9 ([The difference between Certificates, Diplomas and Degrees](https://www.upskilled.edu.au/faq/qualifications/difference-between-certificates-diplomas-degrees)). A Certificate IV, on the other hand, is at Level 4 ([Diploma vs. Certificate IV: Which Is Best for Your Career? | Swinburne Open Education](https://www.swinburneopen.edu.au/explored/careers/diploma-vs-certificate-iv-which-is-best-for-your-career)).
*   **Career Progression:** Students pursue Graduate Diplomas or Master's degrees to gain further specialized knowledge and enhance their career prospects ([a7-4-courses-and-qualifications.md](a7-4-courses-and-qualifications.md)). A Certificate IV is typically pursued for entry-level vocational skills or career changes, which are less common after completing a Bachelor's degree.
*   **Purpose of Qualifications:** Graduate Certificates and Diplomas are designed to broaden skills gained in an undergraduate program or develop vocational knowledge in a new professional area ([a7-4-courses-and-qualifications.md](a7-4-courses-and-qualifications.md)).

**Conclusion**

Based on the available information, none of the statements are definitively true. However, the statement that is closest to the truth is:

*   A student should attend at least 80% of all scheduled lessons in an ELICOS College.

While there is no explicit evidence to confirm this, it is a reasonable assumption based on the quality assurance processes and the need for students to benefit from instruction.

**Recommendations**

To provide accurate guidance to international students, counselors should:

*   Consult official university websites and publications for information on admission requirements, support services, and campus life.
*   Refer to the Australian Government's Department of Education website for up-to-date statistics and policy information.
*   Encourage students to attend orientation programs and seek advice from international student advisors.
*   Stay informed about changes in visa regulations and education policies.

[https://www.swinburneopen.edu.au/explored/careers/diploma-vs-certificate-iv-which-is-best-for-your-career](https://www.swinburneopen.edu.au/explored/careers/diploma-vs-certificate-iv-which-is-best-for-your-career)

question_results.question:
Unsatisfactory academic performance means:

Answer options:
That a student has not attended class to the 80% required.
That a student has not achieved the required English levels necessary to enter an undergraduate program.
That a student has failed the majority of their subjects and would be unable to continue studying in their current course.
correct_answers: That a student has failed the majority of their subjects and would be unable to continue studying in their current course.
extracted_answers: That a student has failed the majority of their subjects and would be unable to continue studying in their current course.
question_results.full_response:
## Report on Unsatisfactory Academic Performance in the Context of Student Visas

**Introduction**

The query at hand seeks to define "unsatisfactory academic performance" within the context of student visas, particularly in Australia. Understanding this definition is crucial for education providers, international students, and education agents, as it directly impacts a student's ability to maintain their visa and continue their studies. This report will analyze the provided information, including local documents and web sources, to determine a concrete and valid definition of unsatisfactory academic performance. It will also explore the consequences of such performance and the processes involved in reporting and addressing it.

**Defining Unsatisfactory Academic Performance**

Based on the provided information, "unsatisfactory academic performance" is best defined as: **That a student has failed the majority of their subjects and would be unable to continue studying in their current course.**

This conclusion is supported by several key pieces of evidence:

1.  **Local Documents:**
    *   Document `b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md` states that a student must achieve satisfactory academic results. It also mentions that institutions often cannot immediately exclude a student for failure, but the student needs to follow the relevant appeal process. If the appeal is unsuccessful, further action is taken.
    *   Document `b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms.md` explicitly lists "unsatisfactory academic performance" as one of the two reasons why an educational provider uses PRISMS (Provider Registration and International Student Management System) to report students to DHA (Department of Home Affairs) for non-compliance with student visa conditions.
    *   Document `b7-2-evidentiary-framework-and-student-visa-processing.md` mentions "breaches of visa condition 8202 (i.e. maintaining enrolment, attendance and course progress)" as a factor considered in visa cancellations. Unsatisfactory academic performance directly contributes to a breach of this condition.

2.  **Web Sources:**
    *   Law Insider defines "unsatisfactory academic performance" as failing more than 50% of units in two consecutive study periods ([Law Insider](https://www.lawinsider.com/dictionary/unsatisfactory-academic-performance)). This aligns with the concept of failing the majority of subjects.
    *   Several universities' academic policies, such as those of College of San Mateo and Santa Monica College, define academic probation and dismissal based on GPA (Grade Point Average) falling below a certain threshold (typically 2.0) or failing to maintain satisfactory progress (completing less than 50% of enrolled units) ([College of San Mateo](https://collegeofsanmateo.edu/academicpolicies/probation.asp), [Santa Monica College](https://catalog.smc.edu/25-26/academic-policies/progress-probation-dismissal-policies.php)).
    *   Colorado School of Mines defines unsatisfactory academic progress as failing to maintain a cumulative GPA of 3.0 or greater, receiving an Unsatisfactory Progress grade for research, or receiving an Unsatisfactory Progress recommendation from the department ([Colorado School of Mines](https://facultyhandbook.mines.edu/graduate/generalregulations/academicperformance/)).

**Why the Other Options Are Less Accurate**

*   **"That a student has not attended class to the 80% required"**: While attendance is a crucial aspect of student visa conditions, as highlighted in document `b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md`, it is a separate and distinct reason for reporting a student to DHA. Non-attendance and unsatisfactory academic performance are treated as two independent breaches of visa conditions.
*   **"That a student has not achieved the required English levels necessary to enter an undergraduate program"**: This refers to the initial English language proficiency requirements for admission to a course, as mentioned in document `a7-6-entry-points-entry-requirements-and-costs.md`. While a student's English language skills can indirectly impact their academic performance, failing to meet initial English proficiency is a barrier to entry, not a definition of unsatisfactory performance during the course of study.

**Consequences of Unsatisfactory Academic Performance**

The consequences of unsatisfactory academic performance for international students holding student visas are significant and can ultimately lead to visa cancellation. The process typically involves the following steps:

1.  **Monitoring and Notification:** Education providers are required to have documented policies and procedures for monitoring course progress and determining when a student has failed to make satisfactory progress, as stated in document `b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md`.
2.  **Written Notification:** If a student is deemed to be performing unsatisfactorily, the provider must issue a written notification of their intention to report the student to DHA. This letter must inform the student that they have 20 working days to access the provider's complaints and appeals process, as per document `b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md`.
3.  **Appeals Process:** The student has the opportunity to appeal the provider's decision.
4.  **Reporting to DHA:** Once the timeframe for appeal has lapsed, or the appeals process has been finalized in favor of the provider, the provider reports the visa breach using PRISMS, as mentioned in document `b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md`.
5.  **DHA Notification:** After the provider reports the student, PRISMS generates a formal letter that is sent to the student, asking them to explain their circumstances to DHA, as stated in document `b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms.md`.
6.  **Immigration Office Attendance:** The student will then receive a notice informing them that they must attend an Immigration office within 28 days. Failure to do so may result in visa cancellation, according to document `b9-2-meeting-student-visa-conditions.md`.
7.  **Visa Cancellation:** If the student does not provide a valid reason for their non-compliance, or if DHA is not satisfied with their explanation, their visa may be cancelled, as indicated in document `b6-4-reporting-students-using-prisms.md`.

**Addressing Unsatisfactory Academic Performance**

While the consequences are severe, universities and other educational institutions have a responsibility to help students who are struggling academically. Some strategies include:

*   **Early Intervention:** Implementing systems to identify students at risk of failing early in the semester.
*   **Academic Support Services:** Providing access to tutoring, study skills workshops, and academic advising.
*   **Clear Expectations:** Ensuring students understand the course requirements and assessment criteria.
*   **Flexible Assessment:** Offering alternative assessment methods to accommodate different learning styles.*   **Addressing Underlying Issues:** Recognizing that factors such as financial strain, health problems, and family responsibilities can contribute to poor academic performance, and providing support services to address these issues ([The Conversation](https://theconversation.com/failing-a-subject-isnt-just-the-students-fault-universities-can-and-should-help-126195)).
*   **Open Communication:** Creating a culture where students feel comfortable seeking help without shame or embarrassment ([The Conversation](https://theconversation.com/failing-a-subject-isnt-just-the-students-fault-universities-can-and-should-help-126195)).

**Conclusion**

Unsatisfactory academic performance, in the context of student visas, primarily refers to a student's failure to meet the academic standards required to progress in their course of study. This is typically manifested as failing the majority of their subjects, leading to academic probation or dismissal. Education providers have a responsibility to monitor student progress, provide support, and report non-compliance to DHA. Students, in turn, must maintain satisfactory academic performance to uphold their visa conditions. Understanding the definition, consequences, and processes related to unsatisfactory academic performance is crucial for all stakeholders in the international education sector.

**References**

*   b10-2-when-is-privacy-a-concern.md
*   b10-3-student-complaints-and-appeals.md
