*   "Failing a subject isn’t just the student’s fault. Universities can and should help." *The Conversation*, [https://theconversation.com/failing-a-subject-isnt-just-the-students-fault-universities-can-and-should-help-126195](https://theconversation.com/failing-a-subject-isnt-just-the-students-fault-universities-can-and-should-help-126195)
*   "Guidelines for Academic Standing for Matriculated Undergraduate Students." *Farmingdale State College*, [https://www.farmingdale.edu/policies/?pid=214129](https://www.farmingdale.edu/policies/?pid=214129)
*   "Section V - Probation and Dismissal for Failure to Meet Academic Requirements - My Law School | University of South Carolina." *University of South Carolina School of Law*, [https://sc.edu/study/colleges_schools/law/internal/current_students/handbook/section_005.php](https://sc.edu/study/colleges_schools/law/internal/current_students/handbook/section_005.php)
*   "Section 9: Consequences of Failure | Academic Manual - UCL – University College London." *University College London*, [https://www.ucl.ac.uk/academic-manual/chapters/chapter-4-assessment-framework-taught-programmes/section-9-consequences-failure](https://www.ucl.ac.uk/academic-manual/chapters/chapter-4-assessment-framework-taught-programmes/section-9-consequences-failure)
*   "Unsatisfactory Academic Performance." *Colorado School of Mines Faculty Handbook*, [https://facultyhandbook.mines.edu/graduate/generalregulations/academicperformance/](https://facultyhandbook.mines.edu/graduate/generalregulations/academicperformance/)
*   "Unsatisfactory academic performance Definition | Law Insider." *Law Insider*, [https://www.lawinsider.com/dictionary/unsatisfactory-academic-performance](https://www.lawinsider.com/dictionary/unsatisfactory-academic-performance)

question_results.question:
Which of the following statements about student visas is True?

Answer options:
The process an individual goes through in order to obtain a student visa is the same for everyone regardless of nationality or institution they will study with.
Students under 18 enrolling in a High School program do not need a student visa as they are not considered adults.
When the visa application states that an individual must be of good character, this means that they must have no criminal record or poor previous visa compliance record.
There is no fee payable to apply for a student visa.
correct_answers: When the visa application states that an individual must be of good character, this means that they must have no criminal record or poor previous visa compliance record.
extracted_answers: When the visa application states that an individual must be of good character, this means that they must have no criminal record or poor previous visa compliance record.
question_results.full_response:
Here is a detailed report on student visas, focusing on the accuracy of the provided statements, written in markdown syntax and APA format:

### Student Visa Requirements and Application Process: An In-Depth Analysis

Student visas are essential for foreign nationals intending to pursue education in countries like the United States, the United Kingdom, Australia, and Canada. These visas are non-immigrant documents that allow individuals to temporarily reside in a foreign country for educational purposes ([Credenc](https://www.credenc.com/blog/student-visa-type)). Understanding the nuances of student visa applications is crucial for prospective international students. This report evaluates the accuracy of several statements regarding student visas, providing a comprehensive overview of the application process, eligibility, and associated requirements.

#### Evaluating the Statements

Let's analyze the accuracy of the provided statements based on the available information:

1.  **"The process an individual goes through in order to obtain a student visa is the same for everyone regardless of nationality or institution they will study with."**

    This statement is **false**. The student visa application process varies based on nationality and the specific requirements of the country and educational institution. For instance, Indian students applying for a Canadian study permit can utilize the Student Direct Stream (SDS) for faster processing ([Credenc](https://www.credenc.com/blog/student-visa-type)). Additionally, Australia has specific requirements such as the Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE) replacing Letters of Offer starting January 1, 2025, which impacts the application process ([VisaVerge](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants)). The type of institution (e.g., university, high school, vocational school) also dictates the specific visa type required, such as F-1, J-1, or M-1 visas for the USA ([EducationUSA](https://educationusa.state.gov/foreign-institutions-and-governments/understanding-us-higher-education/international-student)).

2.  **"Students under 18 enrolling in a High School program do not need a student visa as they are not considered adults."**

    This statement is **false**. Students under 18 enrolling in a high school program generally require a student visa. In the USA, minor children can obtain an F-1 student visa to attend private kindergarten through high school institutions, provided the school is SEVP-certified ([Leverage Edu](https://leverageedu.com/learn/student-visa-for-high-school-in-usa/)). While students 13 and younger may not be required to attend a visa interview, they still need a visa to study in the USA ([Leverage Edu](https://leverageedu.com/learn/student-visa-for-high-school-in-usa/)). The UK also offers a Tier 4 (Child) Student Visa for children aged 4 to 15 attending primary education ([Credenc](https://www.credenc.com/blog/student-visa-type)).3.  **"When the visa application states that an individual must be of good character, this means that they must have no criminal record or poor previous visa compliance record."**

    This statement is **true**. The "good character" requirement in visa applications typically refers to the applicant's criminal history and compliance with previous visa regulations. For instance, Australia's Section 57 character requirement assesses criminal history, visa compliance, and behavioral risks ([Education ONE](https://www.educationone.net.au/blog/s57-character-requirement-student-visa-australia/)). A criminal record, especially involving crimes against children, drug trafficking, or violence, can significantly impact visa approval ([Education ONE](https://www.educationone.net.au/blog/s57-character-requirement-student-visa-australia/)). Similarly, previous visa breaches, such as overstaying or providing false information, are considered serious offenses ([Education ONE](https://www.educationone.net.au/blog/s57-character-requirement-student-visa-australia/)). New Zealand also requires applicants for temporary visas to be of good character, considering criminal history and previous false information provided in visa applications ([Immigration NZ](https://www.immigration.govt.nz/new-zealand-visas/preparing-a-visa-application/character-and-identity/good-character)).

4.  **"There is no fee payable to apply for a student visa."**

    This statement is **false**. Applying for a student visa involves several fees. In the USA, these include the SEVIS fee (ranging from $220 to $350 depending on the visa type) and the visa application fee ($160) ([Yocket](https://yocket.com/study-in-usa/usa-student-visa)). Australia's student visa fee is AUD 1,600 as of July 1, 2024, and is non-refundable ([Insider Guides](https://insiderguides.com.au/australias-2025-visa-changes-what-international-students-need-to-know/)). These fees are essential for processing the visa application.

#### Key Requirements for Student Visas

To provide a more detailed understanding, here are some key requirements for obtaining a student visa, particularly for the USA, UK, Australia, and Canada:

*   **Valid Passport**: A valid passport is a fundamental requirement for all student visa applications ([Credenc](https://www.credenc.com/blog/student-visa-type), [USCIS Guide](https://www.uscisguide.com/visa/nonimmigrant-visas/study-and-exchange/u-s-student-visa-document-checklist/)).
*   **Acceptance Letter/Confirmation of Enrolment**: A letter of acceptance from a designated educational institution is crucial. In Australia, a Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE) is now required instead of a Letter of Offer ([VisaVerge](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants)).
*   **Financial Clarity**: Applicants must demonstrate they have sufficient funds to cover tuition, living expenses, and other costs ([Credenc](https://www.credenc.com/blog/student-visa-type)).
*   **Language Proficiency**: Proof of language proficiency, such as IELTS or TOEFL scores, is often required ([Credenc](https://www.credenc.com/blog/student-visa-type)).
*   **Medical Requirements**: Some countries, like the USA, have specific medical requirements, including documentation showing freedom from communicable diseases ([USCIS Guide](https://www.uscisguide.com/visa/nonimmigrant-visas/study-and-exchange/u-s-student-visa-document-checklist/)).
*   **Good Character**: As discussed, applicants must demonstrate good character, with no significant criminal history or previous visa violations ([Education ONE](https://www.educationone.net.au/blog/s57-character-requirement-student-visa-australia/)).

#### Types of Student Visas (USA)

In the USA, there are three primary types of student visas ([EducationUSA](https://educationusa.state.gov/foreign-institutions-and-governments/understanding-us-higher-education/international-student), [Edwise International](https://www.edwiseinternational.com/blogs/usa-study-visa-for-international-students.html)):

*   **F-1 Visa**: For students pursuing academic studies at a U.S. university, college, or school ([EducationUSA](https://educationusa.state.gov/foreign-institutions-and-governments/understanding-us-higher-education/international-student)).
*   **J-1 Visa**: For students participating in exchange programs, including scholars and researchers ([EducationUSA](https://educationusa.state.gov/foreign-institutions-and-governments/understanding-us-higher-education/international-student)).
*   **M-1 Visa**: For students in non-academic or vocational studies ([EducationUSA](https://educationusa.state.gov/foreign-institutions-and-governments/understanding-us-higher-education/international-student)).

#### Application Process for a US Student Visa

The application process for a US student visa generally involves the following steps ([StudyAbroad Careers360](https://studyabroad.careers360.com/articles/how-apply-for-us-student-visa-in-2025), [Yocket](https://yocket.com/study-in-usa/usa-student-visa)):

1.  **Receive the I-20 Form**: Obtain the Certificate of Eligibility for Nonimmigrant Student Status (Form I-20) from the university or college ([StudyAbroad Careers360](https://studyabroad.careers360.com/articles/how-apply-for-us-student-visa-in-2025)).
2.  **Pay the SEVIS Fee**: Pay the Student and Exchange Visitor Information System (SEVIS) fee ([Yocket](https://yocket.com/study-in-usa/usa-student-visa)).
3.  **Complete the DS-160 Form**: Fill out the online Nonimmigrant Visa Application (Form DS-160) ([Yocket](https://yocket.com/study-in-usa/usa-student-visa)).
4.  **Pay the Visa Application Fee**: Pay the non-refundable visa application fee ([Yocket](https://yocket.com/study-in-usa/usa-student-visa)).
5.  **Schedule an Interview**: Book an appointment for a visa interview at the U.S. embassy or consulate ([Yocket](https://yocket.com/study-in-usa/usa-student-visa)).
6.  **Attend the Interview**: Attend the visa interview and be prepared to answer questions about your academic plans and financial support ([Admission Ac Blog](https://blog.admission.ac/2025/01/21/us-student-visa-heres-how-to-apply-types-of-visas-fees-application-deadline-and-more/)).

#### Conclusion

In summary, the student visa application process is complex and varies depending on the destination country, the applicant's nationality, and the type of educational institution. The statement that "When the visa application states that an individual must be of good character, this means that they must have no criminal record or poor previous visa compliance record" is the most accurate among the options provided. Prospective students must carefully review and meet all requirements, including demonstrating financial stability, language proficiency, and good character, to successfully obtain a student visa.

### References

Credenc. (2019, May 27). *Types of Student Visa with Comparison | Student Visas | Credenc*. [https://www.credenc.com/blog/student-visa-type](https://www.credenc.com/blog/student-visa-type)

Education ONE. *A Guide for S57 Character Requirement for Student Visa Australia*. [https://www.educationone.net.au/blog/s57-character-requirement-student-visa-australia/](https://www.educationone.net.au/blog/s57-character-requirement-student-visa-australia/)

EducationUSA. *International Student U.S. Visa Information*. [https://educationusa.state.gov/foreign-institutions-and-governments/understanding-us-higher-education/international-student](https://educationusa.state.gov/foreign-institutions-and-governments/understanding-us-higher-education/international-student)

question_results.question:
As an education agent you recruited a 17-year- old student to study in an English program. The parents of the student have asked you to provide them with the student’s results. You ask the English College to give you these results. They:

Answer options:
Cannot give you the student’s results unless the student gives permission.
Ask you to pay a service fee before giving you the results.
Give you the student’s results as the student is under 18 and this is allowed by law.
correct_answers: Give you the student’s results as the student is under 18 and this is allowed by law.
extracted_answers: Cannot give you the student’s results unless the student gives permission.
question_results.full_response:
## Report on the Disclosure of a 17-Year-Old Student's Results to Parents

As an education agent, the scenario presented involves a request from the parents of a 17-year-old student for their child's English program results. The central question is whether the English College can legally provide these results to the agent for dissemination to the parents. Based on the provided information, the English College **cannot** provide the student's results unless the student gives permission. This report will delve into the legal and ethical considerations surrounding student privacy in Australia, particularly concerning the Privacy Act 1988 and related regulations.

### Legal Framework: The Privacy Act 1988

The Privacy Act 1988 is a cornerstone of Australian privacy law, governing how personal information is handled by institutions and agents ([b2-5-the-privacy-act-1988.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b2-5-the-privacy-act-1988/)). The Act emphasizes the rights of individuals to have their personal details treated confidentially. This principle is particularly relevant in the context of education, where institutions hold sensitive information about students, including academic progress and results.The Act's implications for education agents are significant. Agents working in Australia are subject to privacy laws and must understand how information about individuals can be used ([b10-1-what-should-an-agent-know-about-privacy.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b10-1-what-should-an-agent-know-about-privacy/)). Even agents working outside Australia need to be aware that certain information, such as medical details, cannot be disclosed by institutions without the student's written permission.

### Privacy Concerns and Students Aged 18 or Over

While the scenario involves a 17-year-old student, the documentation frequently references the age of 18 as a critical threshold for privacy considerations. For students 18 or older, information cannot be provided to parents without specific instruction from the student ([b10-2-when-is-privacy-a-concern.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b10-2-when-is-privacy-a-concern/)). This is because, under Australian law, an individual is legally considered an adult at 18.

Although the student in this scenario is 17, the underlying principle of respecting student privacy remains paramount. The fact that the student is not yet 18 does not automatically grant parents the right to access their academic records without the student's consent.

### Obtaining Academic Progress Information

The documentation explicitly addresses the question of whether an agent can obtain information about a student's academic progress to provide to a parent or guardian ([b10-2-when-is-privacy-a-concern.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b10-2-when-is-privacy-a-concern/)). The answer is clear:*   **Yes** – If the student gives their consent in writing for the education provider to provide the results.
*   **No** – If the student does not want to give their consent.
*   **No** – If the student is not available to give their consent. Academic results cannot be obtained even if the agent thinks that the student will agree to provide them.

This underscores the importance of obtaining explicit, written consent from the student before seeking their academic results. The agent's belief that the student would agree is insufficient; actual consent is required.

### Implications for Education Agents

As an education agent, it is crucial to understand and adhere to privacy principles when dealing with student information ([c7-1-dealing-with-student-documents.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/c7-1-dealing-with-student-documents/)). Agents should not disclose personal information to anyone who does not have a legitimate reason to access it and must take reasonable steps to ensure the proper security of student information.

Furthermore, agents have an ethical obligation to protect students' personal details ([d2-3-ethics.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/d2-3-ethics/)). This includes treating information confidentially and carefully and not passing it on to other businesses or people without the student's permission.

### The National Code 2018

The National Code 2018 also emphasizes the importance of privacy. Standard 3.3.6 states that a written agreement with a student must set out the circumstances in which personal information about the student may be disclosed by the registered provider, the Commonwealth (including the TPS), or state or territory agencies, in accordance with the Privacy Act 1988 ([b10-1-what-should-an-agent-know-about-privacy.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b10-1-what-should-an-agent-know-about-privacy/)).

### Access to Student Records Policy - ACT Education Directorate

The ACT Education Directorate's Access Student Records Policy reinforces the importance of safeguarding student records from unauthorized access ([Access Student Records Policy - Education](https://www.education.act.gov.au/publications_and_policies/corporate-policies/student-administration/student-records/access-student-records-policy/access-student-records-policy)). The policy states that the Directorate will use and disclose personal information only within the requirements of privacy and other legislation. Individuals have a right to seek access to their own personal information and personal health information.

### FERPA (United States)

While the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA) is a United States law, understanding its principles can provide additional context to the importance of student privacy ([FERPA Overview - Presidents' Alliance](https://www.higheredimmigrationportal.org/effective_practice/ferpa-overview/)). FERPA protects personally identifiable information (PII) contained in students' educational records. Although FERPA does not directly apply in Australia, it highlights the global recognition of the need to protect student data.

### Sharing Information Outside the Department (NSW)

The NSW Department of Education provides guidelines on sharing information outside the department, emphasizing that schools cannot disclose a student's personal information unless certain conditions are met ([Sharing information outside the department](https://education.nsw.gov.au/rights-and-accountability/privacy/privacy-information-and-forms/sharing-information-outside-the-department)). These conditions include:

*   The release is directly to the student.
*   The disclosure is directly related to the purpose the information was collected, and the school does not have any reason to believe the student (or their parent or carer) would object.
*   The student or their parent or carer has provided consent.
*   There is a legal requirement or authority.

### Conclusion

In conclusion, the English College is legally obligated to protect the privacy of the 17-year-old student's academic results. Unless the student provides explicit, written consent, the college cannot release the results to the education agent for dissemination to the parents. This position aligns with the Privacy Act 1988, the National Code 2018, and ethical considerations for education agents. Agents must prioritize student privacy and obtain proper consent before seeking access to sensitive information.

On CRICOS:

Answer options:
The provider code and course code will always be the same.
The provider code changes each year.
The course code is the same for every course that the education provider offers.
The course code will be different for each course that the education provider offers depending on the length and topic of the course. The provider code will always be the same for a certain education provider.
correct_answers: The course code will be different for each course that the education provider offers depending on the length and topic of the course. The provider code will always be the same for a certain education provider.
extracted_answers: The course code will be different for each course that the education provider offers depending on the length and topic of the course. The provider code will always be the same for a certain education provider.
question_results.full_response:
# CRICOS Provider and Course Codes: A Detailed Analysis

The Commonwealth Register of Institutions and Courses for Overseas Students (CRICOS) is a critical component of Australia's international education framework. It ensures that educational institutions and courses offered to overseas students meet specific standards and regulatory requirements. Understanding the structure and significance of CRICOS provider and course codes is essential for education agents, institutions, and international students alike. This report aims to provide a comprehensive analysis of CRICOS codes, focusing on their uniqueness, importance, and how they relate to educational offerings.

## Understanding CRICOS Codes

CRICOS is an online register of all courses and institutions available to students seeking an Australian student visa ([B5-cricos.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/lessons/b5-cricos/)). The CRICOS system ensures that the courses and institutions listed meet the standards mandated by the Australian Government ([themigration.com.au](https://themigration.com.au/blog/cricos-code-australia-a-comprehensive-guide/)).

### CRICOS Provider Code

Each institution registered with CRICOS receives a unique provider code. This code identifies the institution as an approved provider of education and training services to overseas students ([b5-1-cricos-provider-code.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b5-1-cricos-provider-code/)). The provider code is legally required to be included in all marketing materials, typically found at the bottom of each webpage on an institution's website ([b5-1-cricos-provider-code.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b5-1-cricos-provider-code/)).

**Importance of the Provider Code:**

*   **Identification:** It identifies the education institution as a registered provider for overseas students ([b5-1-cricos-provider-code.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b5-1-cricos-provider-code/)).
*   **Legal Responsibility:** It clarifies who is legally responsible for obligations under the Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Act ([b5-1-cricos-provider-code.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b5-1-cricos-provider-code/)).

### CRICOS Course Code

Each course registered with CRICOS is assigned a unique course code ([b5-2-cricos-course-code.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b5-2-cricos-course-code/)). Some courses may be listed more than once with different CRICOS numbers, indicating variations in course length, cost, or entrance requirements ([b5-2-cricos-course-code.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b5-2-cricos-course-code/)).

**Importance of the Course Code:**

*   **Accuracy:** It ensures that education agents and prospective students refer to the correct course information ([b5-2-cricos-course-code.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b5-2-cricos-course-code/)).
*   **Differentiation:** It distinguishes between similar courses that may have different attributes ([b5-2-cricos-course-code.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b5-2-cricos-course-code/)).

## Analysis of CRICOS Codes

Based on the information available, the following points can be established:

### Uniqueness of Codes

*   **Provider Code:** Each institution has a unique provider code that remains constant for that institution ([b5-1-cricos-provider-code.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b5-1-cricos-provider-code/)).
*   **Course Code:** Each course has a unique course code. Even within the same institution, different courses will have different codes ([b5-2-cricos-course-code.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b5-2-cricos-course-code/)).

### Variability of Course Codes

The course code is not the same for every course offered by an education provider. It varies depending on several factors:

*   **Course Content:** Different courses, such as a Bachelor of Arts and a Bachelor of Science, will have different codes.
*   **Course Length:** Variations in course duration will result in different codes ([b5-2-cricos-course-code.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b5-2-cricos-course-code/)).
*   **Entrance Requirements:** Courses with different entry criteria will have different codes ([b5-2-cricos-course-code.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b5-2-cricos-course-code/)).
*   **Delivery Mode:** Courses offered online, on-campus, or in a blended format may have different CRICOS codes ([caqa.com.au](https://caqa.com.au/blogs/news/cricos-course-codes-your-key-to-high-quality-international-education-in-australia)).
*   **Campus Location:** The same course offered at different campuses may have different codes ([caqa.com.au](https://caqa.com.au/blogs/news/cricos-course-codes-your-key-to-high-quality-international-education-in-australia)).

### Importance for International Students

CRICOS registration is essential for international students for several reasons:

*   **Visa Requirements:** Enrolment in a CRICOS-registered course is a prerequisite for obtaining an Australian student visa ([b2-3-cricos.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b2-3-cricos/)).
*   **Quality Assurance:** CRICOS registration ensures that the course meets national standards and is recognized by the Australian government ([caqa.com.au](https://caqa.com.au/blogs/news/cricos-course-codes-your-key-to-high-quality-international-education-in-australia)).
*   **Support Services:** Institutions registered with CRICOS are required to provide adequate support services to help international students adjust to life in Australia ([themigration.com.au](https://themigration.com.au/blog/cricos-code-australia-a-comprehensive-guide/)).

### Searching for Information on CRICOS

CRICOS provides an online database that allows users to search for institutions and courses. The search can be refined by:

*   **Institution Location:** Searching for providers in a specific state or territory ([b5-4-institution-search.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b5-4-institution-search)).
*   **Institution Name:** Searching for institutions with specific keywords in their name ([b5-4-institution-search.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b5-4-institution-search)).
*   **Type of Course:** Specifying the level of study, such as Bachelor Degree ([b5-3-course-search.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b5-3-course-search)).
*   **Field of Education:** Selecting a broad field of study, such as Health ([b5-3-course-search.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b5-3-course-search)).

### Responsibilities of Registered Providers

Registered providers have several responsibilities under the National Code of Practice, including:

*   **Compliance:** Meeting the requirements for CRICOS registration and ensuring that the ESOS agency has up-to-date information ([b4-1-national-code-standards.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b4-1-national-code-standards)).
*   **Complaints and Appeals:** Ensuring that overseas students have access to fair and documented complaints and appeals processes ([b4-1-national-code-standards.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b4-1-national-code-standards)).
*   **Accurate Information:** Providing accurate information about the level and field of study for each course, aligning with the Australian Qualifications Framework and the Australian Standard Classification of Education ([caqa.com.au](https://caqa.com.au/blogs/news/new-esos-regulations-for-cricos-registered-providers)).

### Education Agents and CRICOS

Education agents play a crucial role in assisting students with their study plans. They must:

*   **Verify CRICOS Registration:** Ensure that the institutions and courses they recommend are registered with CRICOS ([themigration.com.au](https://themigration.com.au/blog/cricos-code-australia-a-comprehensive-guide/)).
*   **Provide Accurate Information:** Use the correct CRICOS course code when discussing courses with prospective students ([b5-2-cricos-course-code.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b5-2-cricos-course-code/)).
*   **Avoid Misleading Conduct:** Not engage in false or misleading conduct and declare any conflicts of interest ([b4-2-responsibilities-of-registered-providers-to-education-agents.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b4-2-responsibilities-of-registered-providers-to-education-agents)).
*   **Forbidden Actions:** Agents are prohibited from offering courses not registered on CRICOS to students seeking a student visa ([b2-3-cricos.md](https://www.icef.com/academy/topic/b2-3-cricos/)).

### National Code of Practice

The National Code of Practice for Providers of Education and Training to Overseas Students 2018 provides nationally consistent standards for registered CRICOS providers ([ablis.business.gov.au](https://ablis.business.gov.au/service/ag/national-code-of-practice-for-registration-authorities-and-providers-of-education-and-training-to-overseas-students/30928)). The Australian Skills Quality Authority (ASQA) monitors VET and ELICOS providers' compliance with the National Code ([asqa.gov.au](https://www.asqa.gov.au/news-events/news/reminder-cricos-providers-new-national-code-commenced-1-january-2018)).

### Recent Updates and Changes

The ESOS Regulations were updated in 2019, requiring providers to give detailed information about the level and field of study for each course, aligning with national standards ([caqa.com.au](https://caqa.com.au/blogs/news/new-esos-regulations-for-cricos-registered-providers)). Providers must notify TEQSA of any changes that could significantly affect their ability to comply with the ESOS Act ([teqsa.gov.au](https://www.teqsa.gov.au/cricos-and-elicos/notifications-and-approvals-required-cricos-registered-providers)).

### Finding a CRICOS CodeFinding a CRICOS code is a straightforward process:

1.  **Visit the CRICOS Website:** Access the official CRICOS website ([vetresources.com.au](https://vetresources.com.au/blog/what-is-a-cricos-course-code-and-how-to-find-it/)).
2.  **Use the Search Function:** Search by course name, institution, or location ([vetresources.com.au](https://vetresources.com.au/blog/what-is-a-cricos-course-code-and-how-to-find-it/)).
3.  **Review the Course Details:** Check the course details, including the CRICOS code, course name, duration, and provider details ([vetresources.com.au](https://vetresources.com.au/blog/what-is-a-cricos-course-code-and-how-to-find-it/)).
4.  **Confirm Visa Eligibility:** Ensure that the course meets the requirements for the intended visa application ([vetresources.com.au](https://vetresources.com.au/blog/what-is-a-cricos-course-code-and-how-to-find-it/)).

### Format of CRICOS Codes

CRICOS course codes typically consist of six digits followed by a letter. The first five digits identify the institution, while the last digit and letter reference the specific course ([caqa.com.au](https://caqa.com.au/blogs/news/cricos-course-codes-your-key-to-high-quality-international-education-in-australia)). For example, "123456A" where "12345" represents the institution and "6A" represents the course.

## Conclusion

In summary, the statement that "the course code will be different for each course that the education provider offers depending on the length and topic of the course. The provider code will always be the same for a certain education provider" is **correct**. Each institution has a unique and constant provider code, while the course code varies based on course specifics such as content, length, entrance requirements, delivery mode, and campus location. Understanding these codes is crucial for ensuring compliance with Australian regulations and providing accurate information to international students. The CRICOS system plays a vital role in maintaining the quality and integrity of Australia's international education sector.
